headline: McClatchy Draws Interest From Big Hedge Fund
abstract: A couple of days after an unusual spike in shares of McClatchy prompted talk — highly speculative talk — that the newspaper chain was a takeover target, there is another intriguing, though inconclusive, development.

headline: Masters of the New Universe
abstract: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

headline: Lehman to Buy Energy Services Firm
abstract: Lehman Brothers said it would acquire Eagle Energy Partners, a Houston-based energy services company, becoming the latest investment bank to bolster its presence in the physical energy markets. “Commodities over the last several years have become a very significant asset class,” Skip McGee, Lehman’s head of global investment banking, told MarketWatch.

headline: Cerberus Said to Consider Bid for Bell Canada
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is also circling.

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Another Swing at Topps
abstract: A New York hedge fund, Crescendo Partners, on Thursday alleged that certain Topps board members have conflicts of interest that prevent the trading card and confection company from negotiating in good faith with its rival, Upper Deck, on a potential acquisition.

headline: Apollo Seeks to Sell Stake to Investors
abstract: Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black. The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said. DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.

headline: Why Should A Sale Scare Wall Street?
abstract: Why Wall Street Fears A Real Market In Mortgage Securities

headline: Are Airline Bids Like Potato Chips?
abstract: Why did W. Douglas Parker, the chief executive of US Airways, launch a hostile bid for Delta Air Lines so soon after the merger of US Airways and America West? Partly “to maximize value,” he told Fortune magazine’s Barney Gimbel as he was awaiting a decision from Delta’s creditors’ committee in January. “But it’s also kind of fun, too.”

headline: Wall St. Lobby Firm Says It Investigated Former Co-Chief
abstract: Wall Street’s largest and most important trade association acknowledged Wednesday that one of its co-chief executives resigned abruptly earlier this year after an internal investigation uncovered loose financial management by him.

headline: Big Union Takes Skeptical Look at Private Equity
abstract: In Europe, private equity firms are accustomed to feeling the heat from unions. Now, the temperature is rising in the United States as well.

headline: Barclays Settles Insider Trading Charges
abstract: Barclays Bank, which is competing to buy ABN Amro in the world’s largest banking takeover, has agreed to pay about $10.9 million to settle charges of illegal insider trading in bond securities, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Wednesday.

headline: Hedge Fund Tells Wendy’s to Sell Itself
abstract: The largest institutional shareholder of Wendy’s International is urging the hamburger chain to sell itself to the highest bidder, The Wall Street Journal reported.

headline: Dubai, Not Qatar, Is In Pole Position for Barneys, Report Says
abstract: A day after a report surfaced that the Jones Apparel Group was nearing a deal to sell Barneys New York to a private equity fund linked to the royal family of Qatar, a second report has emerged that says it is in fact Istithmar, a private equity firm owned by the Dubai government, that is in the lead to buy luxury department store.

headline: Forget Wall Street: Bankers Head to Moscow for Big Pay
abstract: In Moscow, within a mile of the tomb of Vladimir Lenin, who vowed to destroy capitalists, investment bankers are now earning double the pay of their counterparts anywhere else. Deal makers from banks like UBS and Lehman Brothers are now commonly offered between $7 million and $10 million a year in Moscow, industry recruiters said.

headline: Hugging 101 and Other Novelties
abstract: I may as well admit it: This item was submitted by a PR guy on behalf of his client. And since I’ve admitted that, I may as well just copy and paste his note.

headline: Blackstone Moves Higher in NYSE Debut
abstract: Just how immune is the Blackstone Group to the slings and arrows of Congress?

headline: Spain’s Realia Aims for $1.34 Billion I.P.O.
abstract: Realia, jointly owned by the savings bank Caja Madrid and a construction group, FCC, hopes to confound skeptics of the Spanish property sector by raising more than 1 billion euros ($1.34 billion) in an initial public offering on Wednesday, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Tribune Debt Deal Not as Sweet as Expected
abstract: Tribune, which last month agreed to go private in an $8.2 billion deal with the real-estate mogul Samuel Zell, completed a tender offer for half its shares, but the media company had to agree to difficult borrowing terms, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: NanoH2 Ceans Up With $5 Million in Fresh Funding
abstract: NanoH2O, a desalination company that grew out of research at UCLA, has raised $5 million. The company is trying to commercialize a membrane that consists of a matrix of porous polymer sheets embedded with specially designed nanoparticles that purify water. Investors include Khosla Ventures.

headline: Rival ABN Amro Bidders Still in the Race
abstract: The rival group considering a bid for ABN Amro may be down, but analysts say it’s not out.

headline: Intel Capital Takes the Wheel
abstract: Last year, Intel Capital, the venture capital arm of the giant chipmaker, invested in more U.S. deals than some of the biggest venture firms in Silicon Valley, including Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers and Sequoia Capital.

headline: Lampert Fund Takes Stake in Citigroup
abstract: Chuck, meet Eddie.

headline: Some Small Law Firms Find Strength in Numbers
abstract: The International Network of Boutique Law Firms, founded by lawyer Steven Spielvogel in 2004, aims to provide options to those lawyers who have decided against spending their days grinding out billable hours on a large firm’s time sheet.

headline: Founding Family to Take Sobeys Private
abstract: Sobeys, Canada’s second- biggest grocery chain, said its founding family agreed to take the company private by paying C$1.06 billion ($950 million) for the 28 percent stake it doesn’t already own.

headline: Boutique Bank Said to Be Prepping Rival Bid for Sanctuary
abstract: The battle for the British music group Sanctuary may not be over yet, with a London-listed investment bank, Crosby Capital Partners, preparing a counterbid to trump Universal Music Group‘s 20 pence-per-share offer, according to The Guardian. Crosby, which has offices in Hong Kong and London, has appointed lawyers from SJ Berwin to help make its offer for the troubled music group, which manages Sir Elton John and James Blunt, the report said.

headline: Hedge Funds Could Gain from Sallie Mae Deal
abstract: When Sallie Mae goes private in a $25 billion deal announced Monday, the company will be saddling itself with debt in an effort to generate even more lucrative returns. And some of the biggest winners in the debt-fiesta may be hedge fund traders.

headline: Permira Slips into Valentino Fashion Group
abstract: Permira Advisers, Europe’s biggest leveraged buyout fund, agreed to buy 29.9 percent of the Valentino Fashion Group from Marzotto family members in a deal that values the Italian fashion company at 2.6 billion euros ($3.5 billion).

headline: Business Students Put Their Start-Up Ideas to the Test
abstract: These days, hundreds of business schools hold competitions involving students presenting start-up ideas to a panel of judges. Usually, winners receive money, from $5,000 to $100,000 or more. In some cases, they are also given free legal, public relations and accounting advice.

headline: Murdoch Said to Be Close to ‘Integrity Terms’ on Journal
abstract: The News Corporation, controlled by Rupert Murdoch, and advisers for Dow Jones and its controlling Bancroft family were close Sunday night to agreeing on terms designed to protect The Wall Street Journal’s newsroom independence if the company accepts a takeover bid from Mr. Murdoch, according to The New York Times.

headline: Hong Kong Cozies Up to Hedge Funds
abstract: Hong Kong’s Securities and Futures Commission is planning to simplify licensing requirements to make it easy for hedge fund managers to set up shop there, HedgeFund.Net reported. The commission will speed up the licensing process and exempt some staff members of hedge fund firms from having to take exams. Firms that are already licensed or registered in the United States or United Kingdom will benefit from an expedited licensing process, the agency said.

headline: Swedish Green Tech: Silicon Valley’s Next Big Thing?
abstract: On a recent trip to Silicon Valley, Michael Wood, the United States ambassador to Sweden, pitched 30 Swedish green tech companies to 18 venture capitalists during a meeting at Stanford University in Palo Alto, Calif.

headline: Ameristar Bets on Chicago in Casino Purchase
abstract: Looking to expand the Chicago area’s gambling market, Ameristar Casinos of Las Vegas has agreed to pay $675 million to acquire the Resorts East Chicago casino in East Chicago, Ind. Resorts International Holdings is an affiliate of an investment group, Colony Capital. Ameristar said it expects to close the deal sometime in the fourth quarter.

headline: Deutsche Hires Bankers from Three Rivals
abstract: Deutsche Bank has lured an 18-year veteran investment banker from Goldman Sachs to join its mergers and acquisitions group. The banker, Bruce Evans, who was a managing director in Goldman’s consumer retail investment group, will report to Jean Manas, Deutsche’s head of mergers and acquisitions in the Americas — and a former Goldman banker, the New York Post reported.

headline: Calpine Bondholders Agree to Reduce Claims
abstract: Calpine, the bankrupt power generator, said it had reached a preliminary settlement with a group of bondholders that would eliminate a large group of duplicate claims filed in its bankruptcy case. The settlement, which requires United States bankruptcy court approval, will reduce $12 billion in claims tied to bonds in a Calpine unit to a single claim of $3.5 billion, the company said. Calpine, based in San Jose, Calif., also said it would seek approval from HSBC Bank, the indenture trustee on the bonds.

headline: Chicago Bank Tries to Break Up Bear’s Bid for Doral
abstract: FBOP, a privately held Chicago bank holding company, is trying to muscle in on Bear Stearns‘s deal for a controlling stake in cash-strapped Doral Financial of Puerto Rico.

headline: Weekend Reading: Letters from Robert Chapman
abstract: Shareholder activism has proven especially popular — and lucrative — for hedge funds over the past year, but few practitioners show the epistolary flair of, say, Third Point‘s Daniel Loeb, known for his eloquently barbed letters to companies that he thinks need to change their ways. Another expert in this art is Robert Chapman, who is at it again — with the kid gloves firmly off.

headline: Monaco Grand Prix retrospective
abstract: There is probably no other Formula One event that invites a photographer to go quite so mad as at Monaco. I have just completed a day-by-day photo retrospective of the Monaco Grand Prix from the Wednesday to the Sunday, with explanatory descriptions. It seems that it is now or never to take a look at this before we become involved in the Canadian Grand Prix, for which practice starts tomorrow.

headline: Activist Shareholders Hit a Hot Streak
abstract: As activist investors like Carl Icahn, who is currently waging a proxy war with Motorola to gain a seat on its board, become more determined, the companies’ boards are apparently getting softer.

headline: Suit Says Bronfman Didn’t Pay Up in Warner Deal
abstract: A dispute between two top figures in the corporate media establishment spilled into public view Monday when Richard Snyder, the former chairman of Simon & Schuster, sued Edgar Bronfman Jr., the chairman of the Warner Music Group, saying he had not compensated him for his role in Mr. Bronfman’s $2.6 billion acquisition of the music company three years ago.

headline: S.E.C. Sues Boston Hedge Fund for Fraud
abstract: Securities regulators sued a Boston hedge fund and two principals, alleging they misled investors about the risk of a $33 million scheme involving fraudulent life insurance policies.

headline: With New Hire, Yahoo Sends Out Deal Vibe
abstract: By hiring a veteran investment banker, Blake Jorgensen, as its chief financial officer, Yahoo sent out signals that there is deal making in its future, but analysts and industry observers seemed unable to decide what kind.

headline: Listening in on Customer Service
abstract: You’re about to meet a guy who’s already had two killer ideas.

headline: Meet the Bancrofts
abstract: Who does Rupert Murdoch need to win over in his $5 billion bid to acquire Dow Jones? To answer that question, The New York Observer drew up a family tree of the Bancrofts, who control the publishing company through a special class of stock. Family members include a champion power-boat racer, a retired American Airlines pilot and the head of a Texas private equity firm.

headline: Providence Equity Buys Equity Stake in NexTag
abstract: A private equity firm, Providence Equity Partners, has bought a two-thirds equity-only stake in a privately held Internet shopping site, NexTag, for $830 million, The Deal.com reported. Morgenthaler Ventures, which has backed NexTag since 1999, will retain an equity stake in the company, which allows people to compare prices for a wide range of goods from real estate to car insurance to groceries, according to the report.

headline: Major Parts Maker in Talks With Auto Unions
abstract: The auto parts maker Magna International, which is considering a bid for Chrysler, is in talks with Canadian and American auto unions about adding Magna’s tens of thousands of workers to their ranks, according to the president of the Canadian union.

headline: British Hotel Group Drops $3.4 Billion I.P.O.
abstract: A British hotel group, Vector pulled the plug on its planned 1.7 billion pound ($3.4 billion) initial public offering Wednesday night after investors failed to support what would have been the biggest share sale in London this year.

headline: Prosecutors Rest Case in Conrad Black Trial
abstract: Prosecutors rested their racketeering and fraud case against the media mogul Conrad M. Black on Wednesday, minutes after announcing they were dropping one money-laundering count against him.

headline: Settlement Sought With Interpublic
abstract: The Interpublic Group of Companies said Thursday that it had received a letter from federal regulators in a continuing investigation into earnings restatements by the company. The so-called Wells notice from lawyers at the Securities and Exchange Commission signals that its staff is likely to recommend civil action regarding possible S.E.C. violations.

headline: Dubai Mercantile Exchange Says I.P.O. Is Possible
abstract: The Dubai Mercantile Exchange‘s chairman told Reuters that the company is considering an initial public offering as one of its options for growth, but added that it is “still early days.” The exchange, which is backed by the New York Mercantile Exchange, opened on June 1, trading futures contracts in Oman sour crude.

headline: Burkle to Team with Dow Jones’ Union
abstract: Is Dow Jones becoming a case of deja vu all over again?

headline: Insight Closes $1.25 Billion Fund
abstract: Insight Venture Partners wrapped up its latest investment vehicle, Insight Venture Partners VI, with $1.25 billion, a closing that gives the New York firm about $3 billion under management. Founded in 1995, Insight Venture focuses on software and Internet services investments that cover the entire range of private capital investment – from early-stage venture capital deals to buyouts.

headline: Investors Bet That More Bidders Will Eye Bausch & Lomb
abstract: Will more bidders emerge for Bausch & Lomb, the troubled eye care firm that said Wednesday it had accepted a $4.5 billion takeover offer from Warburg Pincus?

headline: Private Equity Mania Sours Plays for Short Sellers
abstract: Is private equity raining on short-sellers’ parade?

headline: More Buyout Jitters: Bond Offering Is Postponed
abstract: Investors looking for signs that the buyout boom of the past two years may be hitting a wall have two new ones to ponder. US Foodservice, the American unit of the Dutch supermarket Royal Ahold, has postponed its sale of $650 million in bonds that were expected to finance the unit’s equity buyout. Before the decision, US Foodservice had twice scaled back its debt offering to help finance its $7.1 billion buyout by the equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Clayton Dubilier & Rice.

headline: Rival Bids for EMI Unlikely, Reports Say
abstract: The private equity firm Corvus Capital, controlled by the financier Andrew Regan, ruled itself out of the running for EMI Group, the British music group, yesterday, following a report in The New York Post that the company was preparing a rival bid in conjunction with a former EMI executive, Jim Fifield.

headline: How Samuel Zell Scaled Tribune Tower
abstract: Chicago Tribune columnist Phil Rosenthal offers a quick and handy guide to the months of machinations leading up to the agreement to sell Tribune Company — which also happens to be Mr. Rosenthal’s employer — to real-estate magnate Sam Zell.

headline: San Francisco and Shanghai Groups Team up on Venture Fund
abstract: Two leading business groups in San Francisco and Shanghai are teaming up to invest in Chinese start-ups, adding to the growing ranks of venture capitalists looking to tap China’s booming economy.

headline: Northwest Airlines Exits Bankruptcy Protection
abstract: Northwest Airlines emerged from bankruptcy protection Thursday, and its new shares were set to begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Speaking with the Star Tribune, Doug Steenland, the company’s chief executive, acknowledged that the airline considered various options during its Chapter 11 stay, including a merger with another airline — such as Delta Air Lines — or bringing in a private equity investor.

headline: Sirion Gets $45 Million Injection from New Investors
abstract: Sirion Therapeutics has picked up five new institutional investors in a Series B private equity financing that raised $45 million for the company. A new investor, Aisling Capital, led the latest round of funding. Other new investors include Advent International and Bear Stearns.

headline: Oaktree Raises $800 Million in Landmark Offering
abstract: Oaktree Capital Management, an investment firm that oversees about $40 billion in assets, became the first company to list on a new market created by Goldman Sachs as a way for private firms to raise money without going public. Oaktree raised more than $800 million selling a stake of about 14 percent to fewer than 50 other large investors, The Los Angeles Times reported.

headline: Quayle Joins in Offering a $500 Million ‘Blank Check’
abstract: Former Vice President Dan Quayle and the ex-Notre Dame football coach Lou Holtz are joining with the chief executive of the sporting goods maker K2 in a bid to raise as much as $500 million in the second-largest initial public offering of a “blank check” shell company on record.

headline: Palm Stock Falls as Takeover Buzz Fades
abstract: Shares of Palm were down 2.6 percent to $17.16 in late-afternoon trading Monday, even as the major stock indexes hardly budged. Investors may simply have been nervous ahead of Palm’s analyst and investor day on Tuesday. Or they may have been reacting to statements by Palm chief executive Ed Colligan in an interview with Bloomberg News, in which he said that he is not concerned about calls for his company to be sold. Just a few weeks ago, reports on Unstrung.com, CNBC and elsewhere fueled takeover speculation about Palm, which makes the Treo smartphone, lifting its shares as high as $19.50 in intraday trading. No bid materialized, and the stock has fallen more than 11 percent.

headline: Visage Gets Cash to Help Start-Ups Avoid Amp’d Pitfalls
abstract: Despite some high-profile setbacks in its target market of mobile virtual network operators, Visage Mobile closed a $10 million fifth round of venture capital, bringing total investment in the six-year-old company to more than $80 million to enhance boost its subscriber management services.

headline: Bradley Pharmaceuticals’ C.E.O. Makes Buyout Offer
abstract: The chief executive of Bradley Pharmaceuticals has bid $21.50 a share to buy the company, valuing it at about $363 million, the company said in a regulatory filing. The chief executive, Daniel Glassman would remain in his position and would retain the current top management, the company said.

headline: K.K.R. Wins Bidding for Air Canada Division, Report Says
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has won the auction for Air Canada Technical Services in a deal valued at around C$900 million ($840 million), The Globe and Mail reported. In buying the controlling stake in the Air Canada maintenance division, the buyout shop aiming to create a leading Canadian-based aircraft maintenance firm that services airlines around the world

headline: Visa Names Chief Ahead of I.P.O.
abstract: Visa hired Joseph W. Saunders to find a chief executive for the company as it prepares for an initial public offering and he found — drum roll, please — himself.

headline: Should Music Labels Try a Silicon Valley Approach?
abstract: The beleaguered recorded-music business has to do something to pull itself out of its current predicament, which stems partly from outside forces it cannot control (the Internet) but also from its own clumsy or outdated strategies. According to Fortune magazine’s Tim Arango, Warner Music Group‘s rumored deal to buy Front Line Management — the nation’s largest artist-management firm, with a roster of big-name clients including Christina Aguilera and Aerosmith — may offer “a new economic model for the major record companies.” He compares this model to venture capital investing, but with the record labels nurturing new talent instead of new technologies.

headline: Some Contrarian Advice on Chrysler: Keep It
abstract: Amid the rampant speculation about who might buy Chrysler — private equity firms? Canadians? — and what they might do with the beleaguered automaker, one analyst is putting forward an unusual argument. Mark B. Warnsman of Prudential Equity Group is asserting that DaimlerChrysler should stick with its Chrysler unit rather than dump it (though he said he suspects it will end up getting sold anyway).

headline: Colony Capital Head Demands Sale of Carrefour Property
abstract: The founder of Colony Capital, Thomas Barrack, says he wants Carrefour, the European retailer, to raise as much as 30 billion euros ($40 billion) from property sales, more than what Carrefour says its real-estate assets are worth, Bloomberg News reported. Mr. Barrack, who bought 9.1 percent of Carrefour with the French billionaire Bernard Arnault, said the company should consider selling and leasing back stores to finance expansion.

headline: Answering the Unanswerable: Tips for That First Interview
abstract: By MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

headline: McClatchy Draws Interest From Big Hedge Fund
abstract: A couple of days after an unusual spike in shares of McClatchy prompted talk — highly speculative talk — that the newspaper chain was a takeover target, there is another intriguing, though inconclusive, development.

headline: Masters of the New Universe
abstract: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

headline: Lehman to Buy Energy Services Firm
abstract: Lehman Brothers said it would acquire Eagle Energy Partners, a Houston-based energy services company, becoming the latest investment bank to bolster its presence in the physical energy markets. “Commodities over the last several years have become a very significant asset class,” Skip McGee, Lehman’s head of global investment banking, told MarketWatch.

headline: Cerberus Said to Consider Bid for Bell Canada
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is also circling.

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Another Swing at Topps
abstract: A New York hedge fund, Crescendo Partners, on Thursday alleged that certain Topps board members have conflicts of interest that prevent the trading card and confection company from negotiating in good faith with its rival, Upper Deck, on a potential acquisition.

headline: Apollo Seeks to Sell Stake to Investors
abstract: Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black. The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said. DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.

headline: Why Should A Sale Scare Wall Street?
abstract: Why Wall Street Fears A Real Market In Mortgage Securities

headline: Are Airline Bids Like Potato Chips?
abstract: Why did W. Douglas Parker, the chief executive of US Airways, launch a hostile bid for Delta Air Lines so soon after the merger of US Airways and America West? Partly “to maximize value,” he told Fortune magazine’s Barney Gimbel as he was awaiting a decision from Delta’s creditors’ committee in January. “But it’s also kind of fun, too.”

headline: Wall St. Lobby Firm Says It Investigated Former Co-Chief
abstract: Wall Street’s largest and most important trade association acknowledged Wednesday that one of its co-chief executives resigned abruptly earlier this year after an internal investigation uncovered loose financial management by him.

headline: Big Union Takes Skeptical Look at Private Equity
abstract: In Europe, private equity firms are accustomed to feeling the heat from unions. Now, the temperature is rising in the United States as well.

headline: Carlyle Says Going Public Is an Option
abstract: The Carlyle Group is apparently evaluating an option to go public, despite speculation  that the private equity industry’s boom may be close to hitting a wall and the news that the Blackstone Group‘s stock closed below its offering price Tuesday.

headline: K.K.R. Applies for Broker-Dealer License, Report Says
abstract: In a move that would enable it to branch into new businesses and possibly bolster its value should it go public, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts plans to obtain a securities broker-dealer license, according to The Deal.com.

headline: Two Views on How the Buyout Boom Might End
abstract: Much of Wall Street has been trying to figure out what factors could bring an end to the recent run of big buyout deals. Wilbur Ross, the billionaire financier, has his own view, and it sounds pretty grim.

headline: In Hot Ad Deal Environment, Are Big Agencies the Next Target?
abstract: How far will Google, Microsoft, Yahoo or other Internet powerhouses go in their effort to dominate digital advertising, the fastest-growing part of the marketing business?

headline: Citigroup Closes in on Deal for Hedge Fund
abstract: Citigroup is expected to announce a deal to buy Wall Street veteran Vikram Pandit’s hedge fund Old Lane at its annual meeting Tuesday, according to The New York Times. The deal, which has been the subject of numerous reports this week, would put a former top executive at Morgan Stanley at the head of its alternative investments group, but it is also being suggested that it would give Citigroup chief Charles O. Prince III a viable successor.

headline: More China Trouble for Carlyle?
abstract: Carlyle Group, the giant Washington-based private equity fund, has reportedly suffered a new setback in China. The weekly business magazine Caijing reported that Chinese government regulators have rejected Carlyle’s bid to take a 7.99 percent stake in Chongqing Commercial Bank, ostensibly because of a banking rule that prevents foreign investors with total assets of less than $10 billion from becoming a major shareholder in Chinese commercial banks. The rule, which is not consistently applied in China, would virtually disqualify all regional private-equity funds active in the Asia-Pacific area, Forbes.com reported.

headline: What Is Texas Pacific Worth?
abstract: The Texas Pacific Group is mulling selling a 20 percent stake in itself to a couple of pension funds, in a move that could signal an initial public offering of the private equity group, The Deal.com reported.

headline: Sallie Mae in Deal Talks With Private Equity
abstract: Sallie Mae, the nation’s largest lender to college students, is in talks to be bought out by private equity in what could be a deal for more than $20 billion. A buyout, if completed, would be an impressive show of muscle-flexing by private equity firms, which have grown emboldened over the last two years by acquiring ever larger targets. Shares of Sallie Mae, formally known as SLM Corporation, jumped more than 11 percent Friday in premarket trading.

headline: Goldman Alum Keeps the Hedge in Hedge Fund
abstract: When Dinakar Singh isn’t giving investment tips at charity events, the former head of Goldman Sachs‘s proprietary equities trading desk runs a long/short-oriented hedge fund.

headline: Germany Will Block Cerberus’ Deal for RAG
abstract: Germany will not let Cerberus Capital Management buy RAG, a major industrials group, even though the private equity firm is ready to pay up to 8 billion euros ($10.65 billion) for the conglomerate, a government official told Reuters on Friday.

headline: BlackBerrys: A Spy Tale of Three Cities
abstract: As Wall Street workers consider new guidelines on how and when to use their BlackBerrys, Paris has taken the issue a bit further, deciding that the ubiquitous hand-held devices may pose a threat to French national security.

headline: Deal Makers Expect to Stay Busy, Survey Says
abstract: Last year’s record for global deal activity could be a short-lived one, if the predictions of a group of deal makers surveyed by Mergermarket turn out to be correct. Many of the bankers, buyout professionals and chief executives said in the survey that they expect to see continued strength in 2007 in both mergers and acquisitions and leveraged buyouts. In fact, more than half of the respondents are looking for another increase this year in M&A among large-cap companies. Most of the rest believe the level of deals will remain about the same as last year’s. Just four percent said they expect deal activity to recede.

headline: Citigroup May Trim Its Compliance Corps
abstract: Charles O. Prince III spent his first two years as chief executive of Citigroup adding more compliance officers and improving the bank’s controls after a series of messy scandals. Now, Mr. Prince is looking to slim its bulging compliance ranks in an effort to keep the bank from getting bogged down.

headline: For His Next Act, Indian Tycoon Considers Buying Airline Stake
abstract: An Indian tycoon, Vijay Mallya, is pursuing another takeover deal, soon after buying a stake in a rival airline, as well as a Scottish liquor company.

headline: Bell Canada Agrees to Ontario Teachers-Led Buyout
abstract: Bell Canada‘s directors endorsed a privatization offer worth 35 billion Canadian dollars ($33 billion) from the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan, Providence Equity Partners and Madison Dearborn Partners early Saturday, The New York Times reported.

headline: British Game Developer Signs 2 Deals
abstract: The founding family behind British video game developer Codemasters Software has sold its ownership stake to Balderton Capital, while Goldman Sachs has invested 50 million pounds ($100 million) in the company.

headline: With No Rival Offers, TXU Agrees to Buyout
abstract: Texas power company TXU said on Wednesday it would proceed with its planned buyout by private equity firms Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group after failing to attract a superior offer. TXU, which agreed in February to be bought for $45 billion by the private equity firms and other investors, said that during a 50-day “go-shop” period, in which it had the right to solicit other bids, it received no offer that could reasonably be expected to result in a superior proposal.

headline: I.B.M.’s $1.6 Billion Tax Shelter Now an I.R.S. Target
abstract: For the second time in 12 months, the government has moved to block a tax shelter that had been aimed at converting billions of dollars of corporate profits, on which taxes have yet to be paid, into profits that will never be taxed.

headline: Hedge Fund Signals Support for Clear Channel Deal
abstract: In their tortured quest to take Clear Channel Communications private, the radio giant’s two bidders have locked up a key constituent. One of the company’s largest shareholders disclosed Wednesday that it would approve the latest version of the deal, which has dragged amid resistance from some investors.

headline: Lehman Appoints First Asia-Based Vice Chairman
abstract: Lehman Brothers said it had appointed Kunho Cho as the firm’s first Asia-based vice chairman. Mr. Cho, who has been with Lehman Brothers since 1989, previously led the company’s investment-banking division in the Asia-Pacific region and has been involved in major financing transactions in South Korea, China and Japan.

headline: Doubts Pile Up in Gold Fields Bid
abstract: More details emerged about a fishy report by Bloomberg News yesterday — picked up by news services including DealBook — that an American financier was planning a bid for Gold Fields, one of the world’s largest gold producers.

headline: AMC Brings Curtain Down on I.P.O.
abstract: It was curtains for AMC Entertainment‘s market debut, as the theater chain’s owners yanked its planned $789-million initial public offering from the stock market Thursday rather than cut the proposed share price in response to tepid investor demand at its asking price.

headline: Behind the Curtain at Blackstone’s Hedge Fund
abstract: While Wall Street eyes the Blackstone Group‘s looming initial public offering with jealousy, investors looking for an edge into learning how one of the world’s most-connected money manager’s trades can study the holdings of its equity hedge fund. The New York Post takes a look at filings made by Blackstone’s Kailix Advisors fund and finds that the $1.3 billion fund has made a massive wager on the energy sector.

headline: J.P. Morgan Tower Should Go on a Diet, Critics Say
abstract: The “bump” on the planned new J.P. Morgan Chase tower near the World Trade Center site is not — as US Magazine might put it if the subject were a pregnant movie star — a fashionable one, according to some critics. The architect has said he might change the design, but only slightly.

headline: Dow Jones Inquiry Could Be Awkward for Hong Kong
abstract: Many in Hong Kong were surprised to learn that a local aristocrat and business magnate, David K.P. Li, may come under scrutiny in relation to stock trading ahead of Rupert Murdoch’s $5 billion for Dow Jones. But the investigation by American regulators into the possible leak of confidential information could have wider effects, potentially damaging the city’s attempts to shake its reputation for financial regulations that are weaker than the West’s, The New York Times reports. Hong Kong only made insider trading a criminal offense in 2003, and has not yet brought any prosecutions under the statute.

headline: What’s Next in Mr. Murdoch’s Playbook?
abstract: Dow Jones‘s controlling Bancroft family is expected to sit down today with Rupert Murdoch for a meeting that could determine the fate of his $5 billion bid for the company. The next hurdle in the negotiations will likely be what bankers call “social issues,” The New York Times’s DealBook wrote Sunday — specifically, how Mr. Murdoch plans to protect the editorial independence of The Wall Street Journal. On Monday, The Times’s Media Equation column looked at how Mr. Murdoch might play his role as ardent suitor to a skeptical audience.

headline: Funds Said to Consider $45 Billion Bell Canada Bid
abstract: One of Canada’s largest pension funds is in early talks with other pension funds and a private equity firm to form a consortium to mount a $45 billion takeover bid for BCE, the parent company of Bell Canada, The New York Times reported Tuesday, citing people briefed on the discussions. Such a takeover bid would be the largest buyout in history and represent a rare effort by a pension fund, rather than a private equity firm, to lead a buyout of this size.

headline: Bankruptcy Pay in Focus on Capitol Hill
abstract: A top lawmaker said Tuesday that the House Judiciary Committee is working on legislation to rein in compensation and bonuses paid to executives of bankrupt companies. Rules for bonuses to such executives were revamped in 2005, but many companies have found ways around the restrictions in the revised bankruptcy code, lawyers say.

headline: Judge Halts Bank Sale in ABN Amro Takeover Duel
abstract: Hold that deal.

headline: Bear Stearns Sets $3.2 Billion Rescue for Hedge Fund
abstract: Moving to placate lenders and stabilize what has become an embarrassing situation for the investment bank, Bear Stearns said Friday that it would provide a secured loan of up to $3.2 billion to one of two troubled hedge funds. Bloomberg News described the loan as the biggest bailout since 1998; The New York Times said it was a tacit acknowledgment that Bear’s portfolio managers “made brash bets on a mortgage market that has been jarred by a rising delinquencies and foreclosures.”

headline: Australian Group Buys Canadian Casinos
abstract: Australia’s biggest gaming company, Publishing & Broadcasting, which is owned by James D. Packer, agreed Wednesday to buy casinos in Canada for 1.37 billion Canadian dollars ($1.2 billion). Mr. Packer joined with the Macquarie Bank to buy Gateway Casinos Income Fund, a casino operator in western Canada, for 886 million Canadian dollars, Publishing & Broadcasting said. The venture also offered to buy two closely held casino management companies.

headline: J.P. Morgan Adds Another Financial Institutions Banker
abstract: J.P. Morgan Chase has hired former UBS investment banker Joe Jiampietro, marking the latest addition to its financial institutions group. Mr. Jiampietro will join J.P. Morgan in July as a managing director in its banks coverage team, the firm said in an internal memo. Earlier this month, J.P. Morgan recruited Tod Perkins, formerly of HSBC Securities, as a managing director in its financial institutions group. The firm also recently brought in Eric Warmstein, who previously worked at UBS, for the financial institutions group as well.

headline: Second Company Bids for Canadian Newspapers
abstract: A chain of small newspapers that was once among Conrad M. Black’s Canadian holdings became the object of a bidding war on Wednesday.

headline: Tribune Auction Earns Banks $150 Million
abstract: The investment banks that handled the recent auction of Tribune are set to collect nearly $150 million in advisory and financing fees, or a quarter of the total $590 million it will cost real estate magnate Samuel Zell to purchase the 40 percent of the media company.

headline: Microsoft Takes Stake in Chinese Game Maker
abstract: Microsoft will take a stake in Shanghai-listed Changhong Electric and work with the firm to jointly develop entertainment products that can be accessed via the Internet, Changhong said. Changhong Electric said in a statement on Monday that Microsoft would take a 94-million-yuan ($12.3 million) stake in the firm by purchasing 15 million new shares.

headline: Nymex In Talks to Sell to Larger Rivals, Report Says
abstract: The New York Mercantile Exchange, the world’s largest energy market, is exploring a sale to NYSE Euronext, Deutsche Borseor Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Avaya Is Said to Be Exploring a Sale
abstract: The telecommunications company Avaya is in negotiations to sell a part or all of itself, in what may be the latest round of deal making in its industry, The New York Times reported.

headline: Southern California Takes Silver in the Latest V.C. Race
abstract: Southern California is starting to muscle out New England for second place behind Silicon Valley as a magnet for venture capital. A report scheduled to be released Monday by the research and consulting firms Ernst & Young and Dow Jones VentureOne underscores Southern California’s attractiveness, especially to financiers of the healthcare and biotechnology industries in San Diego County and information technology firms in Los Angeles.

headline: Starbucks Chairman’s Two-Way Funding Bet
abstract: Starbucks chairman and founder Howard Schultz, through his venture capital firm, has made a strategic investment decision that is rare, if not unprecedented, The Red Herring reports. He put money into two companies with opposing missions: one that promotes so-called typosquatting, the buying of Internet domain names that closely resemble big brand names, and another that combats it.

headline: Eni Buys Gulf Of Mexico Assets for $4.8 Billion
abstract: Eni, the European oil company, agreed to buy Dominion Resources‘ exploration and production assets in the Gulf of Mexico for $4.8 billion to triple its output from the region. The purchase will raise Eni’s production in the Gulf to 110,000 barrels of oil equivalent a day by the second half of 2007, from 36,000 barrels a day now, the Rome-based company said Monday.

headline: Macy’s Shares Jump Amid Buyout Rumors
abstract: Shares of Macy’s surged Friday on speculation the company was the target of private equity buyout. In the largest jump since November 2005, Macy’s stock climbed $2.56, or 6.6 percent, to $41.43, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Nuveen Shareholders Sue to Block Madison Dearborn Deal
abstract: Nuveen Investments, an asset management firm, said in a regulatory filing late Tuesday that two separate lawsuits have been filed by shareholders seeking to block a $5.75 billion buyout of the company.

headline: In the Venture Capital World, a Helping Hand for Women and Minorities
abstract: The chief executive of the Center for Venture Education offers a dismal assessment when it comes to the organization’s track record for developing and training minorities and women as venture capitalists. “Our numbers are awful,” the center’s chief executive, Patrick Von Bargen, told The New York Times’ Matt Richtel. “But they’re better than in the industry” as a whole.

headline: Hedge Funds Accuse Bear of Loan Market Manipulation
abstract: Hedge fund managers are accusing Bear Stearns of trying to manipulate the market in securities based on subprime mortgages, according to press reports.

headline: At AOL, the World’s News Is One Big Blog
abstract: AOL restructures its news site as a blog.

headline: Lear Delays Vote on Icahn Deal
abstract: Lear, the auto parts maker, has delayed a shareholder vote on a $2.9 billion buyout offer from Carl Icahn. The vote was rescheduled to July 12 from June 27 in response to criticism of the bid from shareholders and proxy advisory services. Mr. Icahn made the bid, valued at $36 a share, through his American Real Estate Partners.

headline: Texas Pacific and Warburg Team Up for British Retail Bid
abstract: In an era of mammoth buyouts, private equity firms Texas Pacific Group and Warburg Pincus  are apparently determined to exercise control in their bid for British retail chain New Look.

headline: J.P. Morgan Official Withdraws from Treasury Nomination
abstract: JPMorgan Chase executive Timothy Ryan has withdrawn from consideration to become the U.S. Treasury Department’s top international official, the White House said on Thursday. “He withdrew himself from this opportunity for personal reasons,” White House spokesman Tony Fratto told Reuters.

headline: Wesfarmers Seeks $10 Billion from Banks for Coles Bid
abstract: A buyout group led by Wesfarmers, Australia’s biggest home improvement retailer, is seeking to raise about 12 billion Australian dollars ($10 billion) to pay for an offer for Coles Group, according to Bloomberg News. The group met with 11 international and domestic banks in Melbourne Wednesday about loans and a possible bond sale, Bloomberg reported.

headline: Wachovia to Hire 300 Private Bankers
abstract: Wachovia said on Thursday it would hire nearly 300 private bankers to cater to affluent customers as it revamps its wealth management unit. Over the next three years, the Charlotte bank plans to more than double the 240 relationship managers in its private banking unit aimed at clients with investable assets between $250,000 and $5 million. The bankers will target high-growth markets such as Florida, Texas, California and New York.

headline: Has Hedge Fund Activism Run Its Course?
abstract: Among hedge funds, the activists have been in the klieg lights for a while now — and have reaped big returns for themselves and for shareholders. But a new academic study, which Financial News described as the most comprehensive yet produced, has found that those returns are falling as more funds chase fewer attractive targets.

headline: Ex-Citi Executives’ Buyout Shop Makes Investment
abstract: Brysam Global Partners, a private equity firm set up by two former Citigroup executives, has made its first investment, taking a $230 million stake in a Mexican financial services group. Brysam, which was started earlier this year by Robert Willumstad, former president and chief operating officer of Citi, and Marge Magner, former chairman and chief executive of Citi’s global consumer group, will take a 28 percent stake in Ixe Grupo Financiero.

headline: M.B.A.’s Dream of Google and Goldman
abstract: As business school students prepare for graduation, they will face an inevitable barrage of questions from friends and relatives — most prominent among them: So, where are you going to work?

headline: As Qwest Chief Retires, Is a Buyout on the Horizon?
abstract: Richard C. Notebaert, who is credited with bringing Qwest Communications back from an accounting scandal and the brink of bankruptcy, surprised investors Monday by announcing that he planned to resign as chief executive and chairman.

headline: Siemens Considers Suitors for Auto Unit
abstract: Siemens‘ board of management is examining letters of intent from buyout firms interested in buying the German conglomerate’s automotive engineering unit, valued at up to 9 billion euros ($12 billion). Siemens shares traded up 2.1 percent at 87.44 euros by Monday morning, after the Financial Times Deutschland earlier reported Siemens could get a price of more than 10 billion euros.

headline: Rival Suitors for ABN Amro to Wield Carving Knife, Report Says
abstract: A consortium of three banks that is threatening to gate-crash merger talks between Barclays and ABN Amro are considering an offer that would reportedly lead to the break-up of the Dutch bank’s assets. The three bidders, the Royal Bank of Scotland, Santander Central Hispano and Fortis, which on Friday said that they have asked ABN Amro to enagage in exploratory talks, are proposing to carve up ABN Amro and give its shareholders a package of shares in each of their institutions, The Guardian reported.

headline: As Sallie Mae’s Stock Jumps, Eyes Turn to Washington
abstract: Shares of Sallie Mae were up as much as 11 percent in early trading Friday as investors reacted to a report that the United States’ largest lender to college students was in talks about a possible buyout. The New York Times said the negotiations for Sallie Mae, formally known as SLM Corporation, were at a late stage and named Blackstone Group as one of the potential bidders. Sallie Mae’s stock surged $4.44 to $45.19 early Friday, giving the company a market capitalization of about $18.6 billion. Despite the rise, however, the shares are still well below their 52-week high of $55.21, which they reached in May 2006.

headline: Societe Generale Denies Imminent Deal
abstract: The chief executive of Société Générale, the French bank that has been at the center of takeover speculation for weeks, denied Monday any immediate plans for a merger. But he left the door open for a future deal as banks in Europe look to consolidate across borders.

headline: Carrefour Buys Brazilian Discounter
abstract: Carrefour, the French retailer, said it had agreed to buy a Brazilian discounter, Atacadão, for about $1.09 billion in a deal that would make it the largest food retailer in Brazil. Atacadão operates 34 discount hypermarkets in Brazil, 17 of which are located in São Paulo state. Atacadão’s property portfolio consists of 2.3 million square feet.

headline: Carlyle’s Deal for PQ Reaps Big Windfall for JPMorgan
abstract: PQ, a specialty chemical manufacturer, is being sold for the second time in less than three years, bringing its owner a huge profit. The Carlyle Group said Friday that it had agreed to pay $1.5 billion for the company, making it a home run for the private-equity arm of JPMorgan Chase, which bought PQ for $626 million in February 2005.

headline: McClatchy Draws Interest From Big Hedge Fund
abstract: A couple of days after an unusual spike in shares of McClatchy prompted talk — highly speculative talk — that the newspaper chain was a takeover target, there is another intriguing, though inconclusive, development.

headline: Masters of the New Universe
abstract: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

headline: Lehman to Buy Energy Services Firm
abstract: Lehman Brothers said it would acquire Eagle Energy Partners, a Houston-based energy services company, becoming the latest investment bank to bolster its presence in the physical energy markets. “Commodities over the last several years have become a very significant asset class,” Skip McGee, Lehman’s head of global investment banking, told MarketWatch.

headline: Cerberus Said to Consider Bid for Bell Canada
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is also circling.

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Another Swing at Topps
abstract: A New York hedge fund, Crescendo Partners, on Thursday alleged that certain Topps board members have conflicts of interest that prevent the trading card and confection company from negotiating in good faith with its rival, Upper Deck, on a potential acquisition.

headline: Apollo Seeks to Sell Stake to Investors
abstract: Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black. The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said. DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.

headline: Why Should A Sale Scare Wall Street?
abstract: Why Wall Street Fears A Real Market In Mortgage Securities

headline: Are Airline Bids Like Potato Chips?
abstract: Why did W. Douglas Parker, the chief executive of US Airways, launch a hostile bid for Delta Air Lines so soon after the merger of US Airways and America West? Partly “to maximize value,” he told Fortune magazine’s Barney Gimbel as he was awaiting a decision from Delta’s creditors’ committee in January. “But it’s also kind of fun, too.”

headline: Wall St. Lobby Firm Says It Investigated Former Co-Chief
abstract: Wall Street’s largest and most important trade association acknowledged Wednesday that one of its co-chief executives resigned abruptly earlier this year after an internal investigation uncovered loose financial management by him.

headline: Big Union Takes Skeptical Look at Private Equity
abstract: In Europe, private equity firms are accustomed to feeling the heat from unions. Now, the temperature is rising in the United States as well.

headline: Law Firms Help Drive Chrysler Deal
abstract: The winner of the auction for Chrysler, Cerberus Capital Management, is widely refered to as a private equity shop these days. But the firm’s longtime legal adviser, Schulte Roth & Zabel, reflects Cerberus’s roots as a hedge fund — and one that knows its way around a bankruptcy courtroom. Schulte Roth, which counseled Cerberus in the Chrysler negotiations, is known as one of the top legal advisers to hedge funds, and it claims to represent more than one half of the 100 largest hedge funds listed in Institutional Investor. On many occasions, it has advised Cerberus when it bid for assets of bankrupt companies (or when Cerberus’s portfolio companies tumbled into bankruptcy protection themselves).

headline: Carlyle to Offer Rival Valentino Bid, Report Says
abstract: The Carlyle Group is planning to go head to head with European rival Permira Advisers for control of Valentino Fashion Group, the Italian company that controls Hugo Boss, according to Reuters.

headline: A Set-Top Box for the Junk Heap
abstract: I was never very impressed with Akimbo, the set-top box that was going to give you access to any TV show ever aired, on demand, via the Internet. The problem wasn’t the concept; it was that they couldn’t get the rights to any decent shows.

headline: Lazard Hires Longtime Perelman Lieutenant
abstract: Donald G. Drapkin, who had been vice chairman of Ronald Perelman’s investment firm, MacAndrews & Forbes, has taken a position at Lazard, the publicly traded investment bank run by Bruce Wasserstein. Lazard said in a news release Tuesday that Mr. Drapkin joined Lazard as of May 1 as vice chairman of its international unit and chairman of its investment committee. Among other things, he will help the firm look for strategic investments and initiatives, Lazard said.

headline: HSBC Executive to Take Top Post at ANZ
abstract: The head of HSBC‘s Asian business, Michael Smith, unexpectedly resigned to become chief executive of the Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, signaling that ANZ will continue an aggressive expansion into Asia. Mr. Smith, 50, who worked for HSBC for 29 years, succeeds John McFarlane, who ran the bank for a decade.

headline: Liz Claiborne Dresses Up with Narcisco Rodriguez Deal
abstract: Few dresses have attained the glamour than the dress that Carolyn Bessette wore to marry John F. Kennedy Jr. in 1996. But its designer, Narcisco Rodriguez, has since fallen on hard times. In a rare move in the fashion world, however, he asked for help.

headline: For Schumer, New Tax Legislation Demands a Balancing Act
abstract: Hedge fund managers and private equity titans are not the only ones who find themselves in an awkward position as Congress contemplates legislation that would raise taxes on publicly traded private equity firms.

headline: Monster C.F.O.’s Resignation Reignites Buyout Rumors
abstract: Shares of Monster Worldwide, parent of the jobs Web site Monster.com, fell more than 2 percent on Wednesday after it said its chief financial officer, Larry Baker, was resigning in a management shake-up. Timothy Yates will succeed Mr. Baker, who was leaving to pursue other interests, the company said.

headline: AT&T Drops Offer to Invest in Italian Phone Company
abstract: AT&T on Monday withdrew its offer to buy a stake in the company that controls Telecom Italia, the largest Italian telecommunications company, for about two billion euros, or $2.7 billion. In a terse statement, AT&T did not give any reason for the decision to pull back its offer to buy a third of the controlling company, Olimpia. But The New York Times reports that AT&T became disenchanted with the idea following intense political pressure in Italy against a sale to a foreign company.

headline: Indian Law Bars Essar Takeover by Vodafone
abstract: In a letter to the Indian finance ministry obtained by the Financial Times, Vodafone has acknowledged that it would be in breach of limitations on foreign direct investment if it attempts to take direct ownership of India’s Hutchison Essar. The proposed deal for the mobile operator is valued at $11.1 billion.

headline: Today’s Teens, Today’s Entrepreneurs
abstract: Michael S. Dell sold stamps to collectors when he was 12 and Bill Gates founded Microsoft when he was 19. Facebook, the social networking site, was the brainchild of Mark Zuckerberg, a Harvard sophomore at the time. A study by the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor showed that the United States was unusual among developed countries in having a higher business start-up rate among its 18- to 24-year-olds than its 35- to 44-year-olds.

headline: Former Enron Official Sentenced to 2 Years
abstract: The former chief operating officer of Enron‘s broadband Internet division, Kevin P. Hannon, was sentenced to two years in federal prison and fined $125,000 for his role in the fraud that led to the company’s collapse, a court official said on Monday. Mr. Hannon was sentenced by Judge Vanessa Gilmore of United States District Court in Houston.

headline: Goldman Asset Management Co-Head to Step Down
abstract: Eric Schwartz, Goldman Sachs‘ co-head of asset management, will step down from his day-to-day responsibilities this summer after 23 years at the firm, Bloomberg News reported citing an internal memo. Mr. Schwartz, 44, will become a senior director, the memo said, although it did not give a reason for his stepping down.

headline: Sharper Image Jumps on Buyout Speculation
abstract: A Buyout firm, Sun Capital Partners, has doubled its stake in Sharper Image, raising the prospect that the ailing specialty retailer might be taken private as it tries to bounce back. Sharper Image’s stock rose 15 percent Thursday after it said in a regulatory filing that an affiliate of Sun Capital had paid $13.78 million for 1.49 million shares held in a trust set up by the company’s founder and former chief executive, Richard Thanheimer.

headline: The Other Struggle Over a Top Business Paper
abstract: As Rupert Murdoch vies for control of Dow Jones and The Wall Street Journal, another newspaper battle is taking place across the Atlantic. Pearson, the British publisher that owns The Financial Times, is considering a sale of French financial daily Les Echos to LVMH, which already owns rival daily La Tribune.

headline: Prosecutors Seek to Freeze Nacchio Assets
abstract: Federal prosecutors have asked a judge to immediately freeze the assets of Joseph Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications International, who was convicted last month of making $52 million from insider trading. In a motion filed Friday in Denver federal court, prosecutors said Mr. Nacchio and his wife, Anne Esker, have assets derived from the sales of Qwest stock worth “more than $100 million,” which is subject to forfeiture under federal law.

headline: Talks for Chip Software Maker Are Said to Bog Down on Price
abstract: Buyout talks between Cadence Design Systems, one of the largest makers of the software used to design computer chips, and two private equity firms appear to have stalled over price, The New York Times reported.

headline: China Tightens Bank Credit Again
abstract: For the second time this month, China has ordered banks to hold more of their deposits in reserve as it seeks to prevent credit and investment growth from destabilizing the economy. The People’s Bank of China said on its Web site on Sunday that big banks would have to hold 11 percent of their deposits in reserve at the central bank beginning on May 15, up from 10.5 percent now.

headline: Wild Racing Weekend Outside F1
abstract: Is wild the word? How can yesterday’s races in Champ Car and Nascar be defined? I did not see the Nascar race, but the race at the Infineon Raceway road course in Sonoma, California does give some food for thought, and I wrote a few words about Juan Pablo Montoya’s first Nascar victory elsewhere.

headline: Results of the “Photoshop Pogue” Contest
abstract: Oh, dear God.

headline: Calls to Remove CVS/Caremark Director
abstract: An investment advisory firm is calling for the board of CVS/Caremark to remove a director, Roger L. Headrick, amid concern that his re-election was aided by “phantom votes,” or votes cast without guidance from shareholders.

headline: Conrad Black Loses Bid to Recall a Witness
abstract: The former media baron Conrad M. Black, charged with fraud and racketeering, lost his motion on Wednesday to recall the chief prosecution witness, F. David Radler. At the same time, the judge denied a request for a mistrial by one of Mr. Black’s co-defendants, Mark S. Kipnis.

headline: Alcoa to Bid $33 Billion for Alcan
abstract: Alcoa, the world’s No. 1 aluminum company, said Monday it would make an unsolicited bid it valued at $33 billion for Alcan, a Montreal-based rival. Alcoa said the proposed bid came after lengthy negotiations between the two aluminum giants failed to produce a mutually agreed deal. “This offer follows almost two years of discussions between our companies regarding a variety of potential business combination transactions, including unsuccessful board-level discussions of a merger transaction last fall,” Alcoa’s chief executive Alain J.P. Belda said in a statement. “We are very disappointed that those efforts did not result in a negotiated transaction — a conclusion we would have strongly preferred.”

headline: Housing Keeps Sinking
abstract: Home prices are falling across most of America.

headline: Steven Cohen Gets His House (Almost) at the Beach
abstract: He may be a hedge fund billionaire, but Steven Cohen still knows how to bargain.

headline: Blackstone Flipping
abstract: Blackstone’s timing was perfect, but not for the public

headline: In Suit, Ex-A.I.G. Chief Says Others Are Liable for Restatement
abstract: Maurice R. Greenberg, former chief executive of the American International Group, sued 16 current and former executives and directors Wednesday, seeking to hold them liable for a results restatement and a $1.64 billion regulatory settlement he considered unnecessary.

headline: Motorola Reveals Extent of Icahn’s Loss in Proxy Fight
abstract: Motorola on Wednesday revealed the final tally of votes in the proxy fight waged by the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn, and according to the numbers, Mr. Icahn lost soundly.

headline: A Buyout Fund by Any Other Name…
abstract: As the private equity industry gets a lot less private, The Financial Times’s Thorold Barker suggests it should be thinking about finding a new name for itself. He brings up one possibility that describes what buyout funds do — long-term capital management — but notes that a certain ill-fated hedge fund seems to have ruined that one for everybody. DealBook visited this question in a column in The New York Times in March, and readers responded with plenty of suggestions, including “adaptive equity,” “enterprise capital” and “constructive finance.”

headline: Cadbury Says It Favors Sale of Beverages Unit
abstract: Cadbury Schweppes said Tuesday that it sees a sale of its American beverage unit, rather than a spinoff, as the most likely option as the world’s biggest confectioner also announced plans to cut 15 percent of its work force — some 7,500 jobs — in an efficiency drive.

headline: Orbitz Shoots for $750 Million I.P.O.
abstract: Back so soon?

headline: Citadel Gets Active With Networking Firm 3Com
abstract: Kenneth Griffin doesn’t shy away from unloved assets. As the market for subprime mortgages — loans to homeowners with weak credit histories — began to fall apart this year, his $13.5 billion fund, the Citadel Investment Group, snapped up assets in the industry. Now, Citadel is putting a chunk of money into a beaten-down technology company. Citadel has spent $135 million to buy an 8.4 percent stake in 3Com, a maker of networking equipment that was a Wall Street darling in the 1990’s, before it spun off its Palm subsidiary and the technology boom subsided. Times have changed, and 3com’s stock has lost about half its value since early 2004.

headline: Edwards Finds Campaign Treasure in Fortress
abstract: John Edwards, one of the Democratic contenders for the presidency in 2008, has long expressed support for legislation to plug tax loopholes for United States companies with offshore headquarters. But The Washington Post suggests that his time as a consultant for Fortress Investment Group, which houses many of its funds in the Cayman Islands, could make it tougher for him to maintain his image as a champion of the poor — especially now that Mr. Edwards (who is already trying to live down a pair of $400 Beverly Hills haircuts) has scooped up a pile of campaign cash from Fortress employees.

headline: Hedge Fund Blasts Topps Deal, Again
abstract: Hoping to convince Topps‘s shareholders that its current $385.4 million acquisition agreement is inadequate, board member Arnaud Ajdler on Thursday blasted the maker of trading cards and Bazooka bubblegum for selling the company low and not pursuing negotiations with another potential suitor.

headline: Owner of Elvis’s Image to Go Private
abstract: Even Elvis Presley is getting in on the recent run of management-led buyouts.

headline: Sirius, XM Peeved Over Broadcasters’ Sponsored Report
Whitney Withdraws Herbalife Offer
abstract: J.H. Whitney will withdraw its $2.7 billion offer for the nutritional and weight-loss supplement makerHerbalife, the group said Friday. Its offer was rejected and the group may sell the roughly 25 percent of Herbalife it currently owns or could even buy more shares.

headline: Justice Department Clears C.B.O.T-Merc Deal
abstract: The Justice Department said Monday that the proposed $10.3 billion merger between Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings and Chicago Board of Trade Holdings would not pose a threat to competition. The decision gives a leg up to the Merc as it tries to fend off an $11.2 billion unsolicited offer from the IntercontinentalExchange of Atlanta.

headline: Swiss Investigating BAE in Money Laundering Case
abstract: Law enforcement authorities in Switzerland confirmed Monday that they had opened a criminal investigation into possible money laundering at BAE Systems, adding to the international scrutiny of the company, the top British military contractor.

headline: About That Gold Fields Bid …
abstract: It appears someone may have pulled a fast one on Bloomberg News — and, by extension, DealBook. Bloomberg reported early Wednesday morning that Edward Pastorini, an American investor, was planning a bid for Gold Fields, the world’s fourth-largest mining company. DealBook included a link to the Bloomberg item in Wednesday’s e-mail newsletter. One problem: More and more, the story looks like a hoax.

headline: G.E. to Sell Plastics Unit for $11.6 Billion
abstract: General Electric said Monday it had agreed to sell its struggling GE Plastics business to Riyadh-based chemicals company Saudi Basic Industries in an $11.6 billion cash deal. G.E. said it would receive net after-tax proceeds of about $9 billion, which would be primarily put toward the company’s current stock buyback.

headline: Barclays Bid Gets Boost from Court Adviser
abstract: Barclays got a big boost in its takeover battle for ABN Amro when an adviser to the Dutch Supreme Court said that it should allow the Dutch Bank to sell its Chicago-based LaSalle unit to Bank of America.

headline: Private Equity Fund Back on Bidding List for Alitalia
abstract: Italy has allowed the American private equity firm MatlinPatterson to re-enter the auction for the national airline Alitalia — in what Reuters calls an apparent about-face amid fears that one of the two existing bidders may pull out.

headline: Outback Steakhouse Accepts Higher Bid
abstract: OSI Restaurant Partners, owner of the Outback Steakhouse chain, has agreed to a higher $3.1 billion takeover offer from a group led by Bain Capital Partners and Catterton Partners.

headline: Buyout Shops Prep I.P.O. for Hedge Fund Administrator
abstract: The hedge fund administrator GlobeOp is planning to make an initial public offering on the London Stock Exchange. GlobeOp said it hoped to get $102 million for the 20.4-million-share offering. A Boston buyout specialist, TA Associates, and Mezzanine Management are offering the stock and will both retain a “significant holding” in GlobeOp after the shares are sold.

headline: 2 Ex-Putnam Managers Settle Market-Timing Charges
abstract: Two former fund managers for Putnam Investments of Boston agreed to pay a total of $1.5 million to settle allegations they inappropriately traded mutual fund shares and potentially harmed other fund investors, federal and state regulators said on Tuesday.

headline: RBS Group Cries Foul over ABN’s Demands
abstract: A trio of banks seeking to buy ABN AMRO said on Thursday the Dutch bank was setting unreasonable conditions on opening its books, increasing the chance they could launch a hostile bid, Reuters reported. ABN, which agreed an $88 billion takeover by Britain’s Barclays on Monday, said it was prepared to open its books to rival suitors Royal Bank of Scotland, Banco Santander Central Hispano and Fortis, who have proposed a higher offer but will break up the Dutch bank.

headline: In Chasing Dow Jones, What Does Murdoch Want?
abstract: Synergies aside, is Rupert Murdoch’s $5 billion bid for Dow Jones & Company really about the media mogul’s desire to acquire the patina of respectability that has eluded him as he built his News Corporation empire?

headline: Yukos Shareholders Accuse Auditor of Bowing to Kremlin Pressure
abstract: PricewaterhouseCoopers has withdrawn all its audit reports on the bankrupt Yukos oil company amid a tax-evasion investigation into the accounting firm, a decision that some of the oil producer’s shareholders said Monday was “spineless.” The auditor said that it had withdrawn its audits of Yukos from 1995 to 2004 because of new information that could have influenced those reports had it come to light earlier.

headline: London Hedge Fund GLG to Go Public in U.S.
abstract: GLG Partners, one of Europe’s largest hedge funds, will go public in the United States through a $3.4 billion merger with an investment company, Freedom Acquisition Holdings, according to The New York Times.

headline: Cerberus to Quit Delphi Investment Group
abstract: Confirming earlier reports, Delphi said on Thursday that Cerberus Capital Management is dropping out of a group planning a $3.4 billion investment in the bankrupt car parts maker. Reuters reported that Cerberus may still participate in the reorganization as part of the company’s exit financing package, and the other investors in the plan, including Appaloosa Management, are staying in.

headline: F.T.C. Seeks to Block Whole Foods-Wild Oats Deal
abstract: Concerned that one company might corner the market on organic broccoli and all kinds of other natural fare, federal regulators are suing to block Whole Foods Market‘s $565 million acquisition of a rival grocery chain, Wild Oats Markets, the two companies said Tuesday. The companies added that they will file a challenge in court.

headline: Biotech on an M&A Tear
abstract: The pace of mergers and acquisitions in the biotechnology industry is expected to continue at a torrid pace through 2007, said panelists at the Biotechnology Industry Organization conference in Boston on Wednesday. The bullish forecast was issued after a recent Ernst & Young report found that biotech deals in the United States were valued at a record $23 billion in 2006 while high premiums drove the value of acquisitions to the second highest level in history.

headline: G.E. to Double Down on Clean Tech Investments
abstract: General Electric plans to double its clean technology venture capital investments from $25 million this year to $50 million a year by 2008. G.E. plans to make investments across the clean-tech sector including solar, biofuels and batteries. In January, G.E. led a $40 million investment round in A123Systems, a company developing lithium ion batteries for plug-in hybrid vehicles.

headline: As Triarc Reshuffles, Some See a Future Bid for Wendy’s
abstract: Adding fuel to the speculation it could be a suitor for Wendy’s, The Triac Companies said Monday that it was selling its controlling stake in the money management firm Deerfield & Company for about $300 million to become a pure play restaurant operator.

headline: Symbion Says Yes to Buyout Firms
abstract: Symbion Health, an Australian health care company, accepted a new, higher bids for its vitamins and pharmacy businesses, paving the way for a buyout of the company for 2.8 billion Australian dollars ($2.4 billion). Ironbridge Capital and Archer Capital matched a rival bid by Sigma Pharmaceuticals to clinch the Melbourne-based company’s recommendation, according to a statement to the Australian Stock Exchange Wednesday.

headline: Future F1 stars everywhere
abstract: Lewis Hamilton, Felipe Massa, Kimi Raikkonen and Fernando Alonso continue to stake out their territory. Massa takes his second pole in a row and Hamilton qualifies in second after qualifying fourth in the first two races, this time beating Alonso, who takes fourth – behind Raikkonen. But as I write these words there is another name attracting attention as the final lap of the first race of the GP2 series comes to an end, marking the first race in the career in the Formula One support series for Bruno Senna.

headline: Fidelity Starts $500 Million Buyout Fund
abstract: Fidelity Equity Partners, an arm of Fidelity Investments, has opened a $500 million buyout fund. The new private equity shop, which officially and quietly started operating in January, is funded internally and the vehicle’s limited partners are Fidelity shareholders.

headline: Getting the Most Out of Your Wi-Fi Menu
abstract: Whoa, did I learn my lesson!

headline: ABN Amro Clears More Legal Hurdles to Barclays Deal
abstract: Barclays Bank‘s 80 billion pound ($158 billion) merger with ABN Amro took another step forward as ABN rushed to settle legal action over money transfers and the government regulator in The Netherlands said that, in principle, it did not object to takeovers by foreign banks. The Telegraph reported that ABN is attempting to reach an agreement with the United States Department of Justice over certain deficiencies in its anti-money-laundering systems.

headline: McClatchy Draws Interest From Big Hedge Fund
abstract: A couple of days after an unusual spike in shares of McClatchy prompted talk — highly speculative talk — that the newspaper chain was a takeover target, there is another intriguing, though inconclusive, development.

headline: Masters of the New Universe
abstract: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

headline: Lehman to Buy Energy Services Firm
abstract: Lehman Brothers said it would acquire Eagle Energy Partners, a Houston-based energy services company, becoming the latest investment bank to bolster its presence in the physical energy markets. “Commodities over the last several years have become a very significant asset class,” Skip McGee, Lehman’s head of global investment banking, told MarketWatch.

headline: Cerberus Said to Consider Bid for Bell Canada
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is also circling.

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Another Swing at Topps
abstract: A New York hedge fund, Crescendo Partners, on Thursday alleged that certain Topps board members have conflicts of interest that prevent the trading card and confection company from negotiating in good faith with its rival, Upper Deck, on a potential acquisition.

headline: Apollo Seeks to Sell Stake to Investors
abstract: Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black. The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said. DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.

headline: Why Should A Sale Scare Wall Street?
abstract: Why Wall Street Fears A Real Market In Mortgage Securities

headline: Are Airline Bids Like Potato Chips?
abstract: Why did W. Douglas Parker, the chief executive of US Airways, launch a hostile bid for Delta Air Lines so soon after the merger of US Airways and America West? Partly “to maximize value,” he told Fortune magazine’s Barney Gimbel as he was awaiting a decision from Delta’s creditors’ committee in January. “But it’s also kind of fun, too.”

headline: Wall St. Lobby Firm Says It Investigated Former Co-Chief
abstract: Wall Street’s largest and most important trade association acknowledged Wednesday that one of its co-chief executives resigned abruptly earlier this year after an internal investigation uncovered loose financial management by him.

headline: Big Union Takes Skeptical Look at Private Equity
