abstract: In Europe, private equity firms are accustomed to feeling the heat from unions. Now, the temperature is rising in the United States as well.

headline: A.I.G. Sues Ex-Officers Over Deals and Earnings
abstract: The American International Group sued its former chief executive, Maurice R. Greenberg, and its former chief financial officer, Howard I. Smith, on Wednesday, becoming the sole plaintiff in a case seeking more than $1 billion in damages.

headline: Bancrofts Are Not United
abstract: A significant part of Dow Jones’ controlling family has not signalled opposition to the Murdoch offer.

headline: Ripples from the Last Takeover Wave
abstract: By MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

headline: Goldman’s Profits Rise, But Just Barely
abstract: Goldman Sachs, the world’s most-profitable investment bank, reported earnings of $2.33 billion in the second quarter, a modest increase from last year’s second-quarter profit of $2.31 billion.

headline: The Price of a Break-Up in a Clear Channel Deal
abstract: Though most analysts are focusing on whether Clear Channel Communications‘s shareholders will even accept the $27 billion buyout on the table, the New York Post points out another (and relatively lesser) issue. Should the radio network giant break off its agreement with Thomas H. Lee Partners and Bain Capital for another suitor, the company will pay a $200 million breakup fee.

headline: Why People Hate, and Love, Jim Cramer
abstract: Jim Cramer wants to know why he has become “a polarizing figure” since he started his CNBC stock-picking show, “Mad Money,” in which he yells and sweats a lot, throws things, and sometimes wears a diaper or jumps into a pile of lettuce “to illustrate,” he cheekily writes, “the finer points of investing.”

headline: Carlyle Confirms Its Next Fund Will Be Publicly Traded
abstract: The Carlyle Group confirmed Monday that it would offer shares of an affiliate, Carlyle Capital Corporation Limitedm on Euronext Amsterdam in the second or third quarter of the year. Carlyle Capital is seeking to raise $400 million in the offering, giving the private equity shop’s affiliate a total capitalization of about $1 billion following the listing, the buyout shop said.

headline: Venture Capital Group Hires Lobbyist on Carried Interest
abstract: The army of lobbying firms hired to battle the effort to increase federal taxes for private-equity managers and venture capitalists continues to grow: A filing made public on Wednesday shows that the law firm Proskauer Rose has signed on to represent the National Venture Capital Association on the matter.

headline: Will Private Equity Dial Up Telecoms Deals?
abstract: Following The New York Times report this week that one of Canada’s largest pension funds is in early talks with other pension funds and a private equity firm to form a consortium to mount a $45 billion takeover bid for BCE, the parent company of Bell Canada, analysts and industry watchers are wondering if more such buyouts are in the offing.

headline: CardioVasc Secures a Merger and Venture Funding
abstract: Along with its purchase of ActaVascular Systems this week, CardioVasc, a medical device company, said it had raised $20.3 million in venture funding. The companies will combine to be called Nfocus Neuromedical.

headline: Jazz Pharmaceutical Cuts I.P.O. Price
abstract: Jazz Pharmaceuticals, a biopharmaceutical company, priced its initial public offering below the forecast range, which had already been reduced. The 6-million-share offering raised $108 million, providing sorely needed cash for the money-losing drugmaker. Since 2003, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and other private equity firms have invested $265 million in Jazz, whose main product, gamma hydroxybutyrate, is used to treat narcolepsy but also has a history of use in date rape and risks of overdose.

headline: Paracor Raises $44 Million for Pivotal Trial
abstract: In a Series D funding, Paracor Medical raised $44.35 million to complete a pivotal clinical trial of a device to prevent congestive heart failure, says TheDeal.com.

headline: A Business Opportunity
abstract: Bid for Tweeters

headline: Infinera Captures Big First-Day Gains
abstract: Share of Infinera, a maker of optical computer chips, rose as much as 63 percent in their market opening on Thursday, a day after the company raised $182 million in an initial public offering.

headline: China Citic Banks $5.4 Billion in I.P.O.
abstract: China Citic Bank sold $5.4 billion of stock in the world’s biggest offering this year, according to Bloomberg News. The bank, one of the 10 largest in China, sold shares in Shanghai and Hong Kong on Friday, raising the maximum it targeted,the report said, adding that the sale values the state-owned company at $28.9 billion.

headline: Blackstone Going Public? Who Knew?
abstract: In lawmaking, as in comedy, timing is everything.

headline: Rosneft Buys More Yukos Assets
abstract: A subsidiary of Russia’s state-controlled oil company Rosneft bought the remaining production and refining assets of bankrupt Yukos on Thursday at an auction for 165.5 billion rubles ($6.42 billion).

headline: Buy My Eyeballs
abstract: Free Magazines, if you watch video ads.

headline: Signs of Investor Burnout in Ethanol I.P.O.’s
abstract: The initial public offering Thursday of BioFuel Energy was described in the Red Herring as “lackluster.” But worse adjectives might be applied to the public debut of the ethanol maker. It cut its offering price several times in the weeks leading up to the I.P.O. It had filed to sell 9.5 million shares for between $16 and $18. It ended up selling 5.25 million shares at $10.50 each. After a bumpy first day of trading, the stock closed up a penny. And at midday Friday, they were trading at $10.37.

headline: Will Hedge Fund Bailout Put Bear in Play?
abstract: Bear Stearns‘s recent hedge-fund troubles could affect more than just the investment bank’s reputation. They could jeopardize its independence as well.

headline: Mortgages Get Tight
abstract: Banks are reducing their mortgage loans outstanding

headline: The Reviews Are In
abstract: The iPhone reviews from major media.

headline: Cott Adopts Hostile Takeover Defense
abstract: Cott, whose stock is fizzing up because of rumors of a merger with Cadbury Schweppes‘ drinks division, said Wednesday that its board has approved a shareholder rights plan to discourage a hostile takeover.

headline: Rival Bidders Offer $95.5 Billion for ABN Amro
abstract: The takeover battle for the Dutch bank ABN Amro gained momentum Tuesday when a consortium led by the Royal Bank of Scotland, which has openly coveted ABM Amro for weeks, formally offered 71.1 billion euros ($95.6 billion) for it. The proposal trumped ABN’s agreed deal with Barclays, already the largest banking takeover.

headline: Are Investment Banks Running Too Lean?
abstract: Top investment banks are struggling to cope with the record volume of deals, and their overworked staffs are in danger of making costly mistakes, The Financial Times reports. Many banks are reluctant to bulk up their staff and the shortages are especially keen in financial hubs in continental Europe and Asia, the article says. One headhunter tells the newspaper that “vice presidents are very stretched with many junior staff working beyond their experience.”

headline: With ABN Amro, Barclays Sees Growth in Asia
abstract: If ABN Amro and Barclays seal their $91 billion merger pact, the newly formed behemoth will be making a big push into Asia, following a stream of Wall Street investment banks which have headed aggressively into India and into smaller Asian markets like Vietnam while bolstering their operations in China.

headline: Of Hedgehogs and Courtroom Moles
abstract: Like fedora-sporting reporters in old movies, hedge fund employees lately have been known to jump up from their courtroom seats as rulings are issued to get breaking news back to headquarters. But they’re not rushing to the bank of payphones in the lobby (which probably aren’t there anymore anyway). “These guys are texting the hedge fund, so they can short the stock” of whatever company just lost a patent suit, Ron Laurie, of Inflexion Point Strategy, an intellectual-property investment bank, told the trade publication IP Law and Business.

headline: Jurors Are Expected to Get Conrad Black’s Case Today
abstract: After nearly 15 weeks in court, lawyers in the trial of the former media baron Conrad M. Black neared the end of their arguments Tuesday, with the jury expected to begin poring over 100 pages of instructions starting Wednesday.

headline: Proxy Firm Adds to Pressure on Times Company
abstract: Critics of The New York Times Company‘s corporate governance have gained a powerful ally. Institutional Shareholder Services, a proxy advisory firm, on Thursday advised the media company’s shareholders to withhold their votes for directors seeking re-election in order to send a “strong message” that changes are needed. The firm’s recommendation came less than three weeks before the Times’s annual shareholder meeting, which is likely to be a contentious affair. A fund managed by Morgan Stanley has been pressuring the Times Company to dissolve the two-tiered stock structure that gives voting control to the Sulzberger family, something the Times has said it will not do.

headline: Pogue’s Picks
abstract: David Pogue picks the best electronics.. for now.

headline: Icahn Takes Pitch to Motorola’s Shareholders
abstract: Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire activist investor, continued his campaign to gain a seat on Motorola‘s board, this time making his pitch directly to the cellphone maker’s shareholders. In a letter to shareholders filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission Friday, Mr. Icahn said that the company’ financial woes “reflect not only operational failures, but are also symptoms of a passive and reactive board.”

headline: Citi Executive Joins University Pension Fund
abstract: The University of Texas Investment Management Company, the investing arm of the University of Texas’s pension system, has hired Bruce Zimmerman, former chief investment officer and global head of pension investments at Citigroup, as its new chief executive.

headline: ABN Amro’s Finance Chief to Step Down
abstract: ABN Amro, the Dutch bank at the center of one of the biggest bidding wars in history, said Thursday that its chief financial officer, Hugh Scott-Barrett, would resign in August. News of Mr. Scott-Barrett’s departure came as ABN is trying to fend off an unsolicited $98 billion takeover approach so it can be acquired in a friendly deal by Barclays of Britain. ABN said late Wednesday it would appeal a decision in a Dutch court that halted the sale of the LaSalle Bank, its Chicago subsidiary, to the Bank of America. That side deal was widely seen as an attempt to drive off the rival bidding group, led by the Royal Bank of Scotland.

headline: Proxy Firm Urges a Rejection of the Clear Channel Deal
abstract: As Clear Channel Communications bidders Bain Capital and Thomas H. Lee Partners scramble to persuade shareholders to back their $19.4 billion bid for the company, a proxy advisory firm has dealt the potential deal another blow.

headline: Deal to Form Big Company to Train Prisoners
abstract: A company based in New Jersey that provides training and treatment programs to prison inmates is announcing today that it has bought a similar Massachusetts company, creating one of the largest correctional services companies in the country. The two companies – Community Education Centers of Roseland, N.J., and CiviGenics of Marlborough, Mass. – are trying to capitalize on the growing number of inmates and tight financing for new prisons that have led federal, state and local governments to contract out more of their operations to private businesses.

headline: Farallon to Acquire Affordable Residential Unit for $1.8 Billion
abstract: Farallon Capital Management, the $26 billion hedge fund, has agreed to buy the manufactured home community business of Affordable Residential Communities for about $1.8 billion. In a statement, Affordable said it would keep its insurance business and use the sale’s proceeds to finance additional acquisitions. The company owns and operates about 57,264 home sites in 275 communities in 23 states.

headline: Apax Mulls Deal for Indian Software Firm, Report Says
abstract: The private equity investor Apax Partners Worldwide is in talks with Patni Computer Systems, a software company based in Mumbai, regarding a possible stake in the company, but it may find itself in competition with an existing shareholder, General Atlantic, and other potential buyers, says The Deal.com.

headline: Take-Two’s Mr. Fix-It Inherits a Handful
abstract: Strauss Zelnick, Take-Two Interactive Software‘s new chairman, has taken on risky corporate overhauls in the past, but none have been as complex as the turnaround of Take-Two, which he called “the biggest thing we’ve done.”

headline: A Flip to Make a Venture Investor Proud
abstract: Fred Wilson has made some lucrative exits in his career. The venture capitalist, of Union Square Ventures and Flatiron Partners, was an early investor in the Web site hosting service GeoCities.com, for example. That site was acquired by Yahoo for $3.6 billion in 1999, while the Internet boom was still in full swing.

headline: CBS Buys Wallstrip, Going Long on Finance Humor
abstract: Wallstrip, the offbeat financial Web show whose host has been known to frolic with hogs for a segment on pork producer Premium Standard Farms, has found a home with Big Media. CBS on Tuesday confirmed that it bought the quirky start-up, whose backers include venture investor Fred Wilson, for an undisclosed price.

headline: Cisco Spies Deal in Surveillance Software Maker
abstract: The networking equipment maker Cisco Systems said Tuesday it would buy privately-held BroadWare Technologies, a provider of Internet-based video surveillance software. Financial terms were not disclosed. The company said BroadWare’s software allows users to monitor, manage, record and store audio and video online, and helps customers gain access to live and recorded surveillance video for faster investigation response.

headline: The Money Binge
abstract: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

headline: CDW Agrees to $7.3 Billion Buyout by Madison Dearborn
abstract: CDW, a technology products retailer aimed at business, said late Tuesday that it has agreed to sell itself to Madison Dearborn Partners for about $7.3 billion in cash. In a statement Tuesday, CDW said that the deal values the company at $87.75 a share, or a 16.3 percent premium over its closing stock price on Friday.

headline: Buyout Boom Could Slow as Investors Push Back
abstract: The buyout boom may be about to hit a bump.

headline: Amp’d Bankruptcy May Delay Pornography on Cellphones
abstract: Amp’d Mobile‘s filing for protection from bankruptcy on June 1 may have one unexpected side effect: a delay in the introduction of sex-oriented programming on cellphones.

headline: Group Is Said to Offer Bid for Macquarie Stake in Rome Airports
abstract: A group of investors based in Italy made an informal offer on Tuesday to buy out Macquarie‘s 45 percent stake in Rome’s airports for about 1.1 billion euros ($1.5 billion), The Financial Times reported. The Australian financial firm is considering whether to take the offer or to counter by buying the Italian group’s 51 percent stake, the paper said.

headline: Talking Shop With Cisco’s Dealmaker
abstract: Cisco isn’t afraid to make surprising deals — even big ones. In March, it announced a $3.2 billion acquisition of WebEx, causing several pundits to wonder why the company, which makes networking gear, would buy a videoconferencing firm. That deal came just after the much smaller acquisition of Tribe.net, a social-networking Web site that had long been eclipsed by MySpace, Facebook, and others.

headline: Sana Security Closes $12 Million Funding Round
abstract: Sana Security, a maker of antivirus software, said it had received $12 million in venture funding in its latest round of financing, led by El Dorado Ventures, bringing its total venture funding to $40 million. Sana also named Don Listwin, who previously led Openwave Systems, as its chief executive officer.

headline: Logical Therapuetics Gets $30 Million Injection
abstract: A drug developer, Logical Therapeutics, has raised $30 million in Series B funding, as venture capitalists eye an opportunity created by the spectacular fall of anti-inflammatory drug Vioxx three years back.

headline: Bear Stearns Said to Withdraw Everquest I.P.O.
abstract: Everquest Financial, a firm with ties to a troubled hedge fund run by Bear Stearns, has called off its proposed initial public offering, The Financial Times reported.

headline: A Clash of Alternative Investment Titans
abstract: Hedge funds and private equity firms have grown colossally over the past few years, often working in tandem to shake up underperforming companies. But as they continue to expand and the lines between the two blur, conflicts between the these investment pools may increase, attendees at the 2007 MARHedge conference in San Francisco told MarketWatch.

headline: Hedge Fund Targets Movie Gallery
abstract: An activist hedge fund, Schultze Asset Management, vowed Tuesday to press Movie Gallery to take steps to increase shareholder value.

headline: MuleSource Takes $12.5 Million in New Funding
abstract: MuleSource, a provider of open-source business software, said Tuesday that it had raised $12.5 million in its second round of venture funding, adding to an initial $4 million it raised last fall. This latest round was led by Lightspeed Venture Partners.

headline: A Battery of Questions
abstract: Joe Nocera, the Saturday columnist for the Times, took Apple to task for designing a cell phone with a battery that cannot be replaced by the consumer.

headline: Ex-Chief of Cendant Denied Bid for Release
abstract: A federal appeals court has denied a request by the former Cendant chairman, Walter A. Forbes, to be released pending an appeal of his conviction in a case over one of corporate America’s biggest accounting scandals.

headline: Yahoo to Buy Online Ad Company Right Media
abstract: Weeks after Google spent $3.1 billion to buy the Internet advertising company DoubleClick, a rival search giant is reaching into its wallet in a bid to compete. Yahoo has agreed to pay about $680 million to acquire the rest of Right Media, a privately held company that runs an advertising marketplace, in part to bolster its position as a seller and broker of ads outside its own sprawling network of Web sites, The New York Times reported.

headline: Senna Mania!
abstract: It was an absolute zoo after the GP2 race in Barcelona today as Bruno Senna, Ayrton’s nephew, won the race in only his third GP2 race and with not quite three years of car racing behind him. He moves to third place in the series, which is a Formula One support race, and a final stepping stone to the highest level of racing. I wrote a little about Bruno after the first GP2 race in Bahrain, so I thought I should continue with the theme. In fact, I could not avoid the theme this time.

headline: Finding the Next Data Processing Buyout
abstract: Does Kohlberg Kravis Roberts‘ planned $29 billion acquisition of First Data, one of the biggest credit-card payment processors, signal a field ripe for dealmaking? Adam Frisch, an analyst with UBS, on Monday suggested some other payment-processors that might also be good candidates for a leveraged buyout. Among them were Global Payments and Ceridian.

headline: Roche Fires Up Tender Offer for Ventana
abstract: The Swiss drug maker Roche said Monday that it would start a tender offer to acquire Ventana Medical Systems for about $3 billion, or $75 a share, after its efforts to negotiate a merger were rebuffed.

headline: Firm Launches Synthetic Fund Amid Fee Debate
abstract: Jerome Abernathy, former head of research at the hedge fund giant Moore Capital Management, opened a new fund on Tuesday that tries to replicate returns generated by the industry, but with lower fees.

headline: McClatchy Draws Interest From Big Hedge Fund
abstract: A couple of days after an unusual spike in shares of McClatchy prompted talk — highly speculative talk — that the newspaper chain was a takeover target, there is another intriguing, though inconclusive, development.

headline: Masters of the New Universe
abstract: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

headline: Lehman to Buy Energy Services Firm
abstract: Lehman Brothers said it would acquire Eagle Energy Partners, a Houston-based energy services company, becoming the latest investment bank to bolster its presence in the physical energy markets. “Commodities over the last several years have become a very significant asset class,” Skip McGee, Lehman’s head of global investment banking, told MarketWatch.

headline: Cerberus Said to Consider Bid for Bell Canada
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is also circling.

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Another Swing at Topps
abstract: A New York hedge fund, Crescendo Partners, on Thursday alleged that certain Topps board members have conflicts of interest that prevent the trading card and confection company from negotiating in good faith with its rival, Upper Deck, on a potential acquisition.

headline: Apollo Seeks to Sell Stake to Investors
abstract: Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black. The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said. DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.

headline: Why Should A Sale Scare Wall Street?
abstract: Why Wall Street Fears A Real Market In Mortgage Securities

headline: Are Airline Bids Like Potato Chips?
abstract: Why did W. Douglas Parker, the chief executive of US Airways, launch a hostile bid for Delta Air Lines so soon after the merger of US Airways and America West? Partly “to maximize value,” he told Fortune magazine’s Barney Gimbel as he was awaiting a decision from Delta’s creditors’ committee in January. “But it’s also kind of fun, too.”

headline: Wall St. Lobby Firm Says It Investigated Former Co-Chief
abstract: Wall Street’s largest and most important trade association acknowledged Wednesday that one of its co-chief executives resigned abruptly earlier this year after an internal investigation uncovered loose financial management by him.

headline: Big Union Takes Skeptical Look at Private Equity
abstract: In Europe, private equity firms are accustomed to feeling the heat from unions. Now, the temperature is rising in the United States as well.

headline: Merrill Names New Investment Banking Executives
abstract: Merrill Lynch‘s Andrea Orcel, who took over investment banking and capital markets two weeks ago, named his deputies, Bloomberg News reported, citing a company memorandum.

headline: Time Inc. Chief Imagines ‘Marriage’ With Scripps
abstract: Ann Moore’s dream house would apparently include parts of E.W. Scripps.

headline: Times Investors Withhold 42% of Director Votes
abstract: Shareholders in The New York Times Company, led by a Morgan Stanley fund, withheld 42 percent of their votes from directors at Tuesday’s annual meeting. Though largely symbolic, the show of protest over the company’s dual-class stock structure was even greater than last year, when 30 percent of shareholders withheld their votes.

headline: Sovereign Ex-Chief Says His Exit Was ‘Misinterpreted’
abstract: When Jay Sidhu resigned as chief executive of Sovereign Bancorp last October amid pressure from investors over his deal-making, the Philadelphia-based bank said he was leaving for “family health reasons.” Later, though, Sovereign disclosed in regulatory filings that Mr. Sidhu had faced “threatened termination by the company without cause.”

headline: Nasdaq May Buy Philly Exchange, Report Says
abstract: The Nasdaq Stock Market is in talks to buy the Philadelphia Stock Exchange to gain a stake in the fast-growing options business, according to The Wall Street Journal. The report said Nasdaq has been discussing a link with the regional exchange for months, but a deal is not expected to be reached any time soon.

headline: Housing With Higher Rates
abstract: With Treasury yields above 5 percent, will housing market suffer again?

headline: It’s Hard Out There for an S.P.A.C.
abstract: You might think that shopping with other people’s money would be an easy mission in life. But for the dozens of “blank-check companies” — which raise cash through initial public offerings for the sole purpose of making acquisitions — sealing the deal can take a lot of effort.

headline: Data Domain Aims for $100 Million I.P.O.
abstract: Data Domain, which makes data-storage appliances, filed to raise as much as $100 million in an initial public offering. The company’s backers include venture firms Greylock Partners, New Enterprise Associates and Sutter Hill Ventures.

headline: Ocean Power Raises $100 Million in Nasdaq Listing
abstract: Ocean Power Technologies, which develops systems that generate electricity through the energy of ocean waves, raised about $100 million in its first stock listing in the United States. The New Jersey-based company said Wednesday it sold 5 million shares, to be listed on the Nasdaq, at $20 each. Shares of Ocean Power already traded on the AIM market of the London Stock Exchange.

headline: Will Activist Investors Flex Their Muscles in Puma Deal?
abstract: Activist investors in Europe have been increasingly flexing their muscles to block unwanted deals and encourage break-ups of under-performing companies. And now that French luxury group PPR has tabled a friendly $7 billion bid for the German sportswear outfit Puma, industry watchers are wondering if another battle royale is in the offing.

headline: Pressure Mounts on Times Co. as 2d Proxy Firm Enters Debate
abstract: A second corporate advisory firm is urging shareholders of The New York Times Company to withhold their votes for directors at the company’s annual meeting this month, underscoring the mounting investor discontent over the dual-class share structure of the Times Company and some of the strategic decisions taken by management.

headline: Bear Stearns Will Write Down $225 Million
abstract: Bear Stearns will write down $225 million in the value of its specialist business as the switch to automated trading at the New York Stock Exchange reduces the need for floor traders.

headline: K.K.R. Brings in Adviser from Tech Sector
abstract: When it comes to investing in technology companies, the private equity giant Kohlberg Kravis Roberts may be just warning up.

headline: Peoples United Inks $1.9 Billion Deal for Chittenden
abstract: People’s United Financial has agreed to buy Chittenden for $1.9 billion in cash and stock, in a deal that will create the largest locally owned bank in New England, with $21 billion in assets and more than 210 branches.

headline: Former Chief of EMI Said to Prepare Rival Bid
abstract: It took EMI Group years to reach a consensual takeover agreement, but another bidder may emerge much, much sooner. The New York Post reported Wednesday that at around 12:30 p.m. Tuesday — exactly 24 hours after EMI agreed to be acquired by Terra Firma Capital Partners for 265 pence per share — private equity firm Corvus Capital and former EMI chief executive Jim Fifield were in the final stages of preparing a bid of 278 pence per share for the British music company.

headline: Ex-Goldman Head Calls Wall St. Pay ‘Shocking’
abstract: This is bound to be creating some buzz down on 85 Broad: John C. Whitehead, who retired as co-chairman of Goldman Sachs in 1984, called current compensation levels at the giant securities firm “shocking” and said he was “appalled” at Wall Street pay in general. In an interview with Bloomberg News, Mr. Whitehead, 85, urged his former employer to curb bonuses, even if it means losing some valued employees. “I would take the chance of losing a lot of them and let them see what happens when the hedge fund bubble, as I see it, ends,” he told Bloomberg earlier this week.

headline: A New Investing Tactic: Hedging Hedge Funds
abstract: Can you hedge a hedge fund? An investment currently being marketed to the rich is trying in essence to do just that, and the approach is bound to be offered to the rest of us soon, The New York Times reports.

headline: Citigroup in Deal for Bisys
abstract: Citigroup agreed to buy a fund administrator, the Bisys Group, for $1.47 billion. Citigroup will pay $11.85 a share and a special dividend of 15 cents a share at closing, the New York-based bank said today in a statement distributed by Business Wire.

headline: Blackstone Prices at $31 a Unit in $4.13 Billion I.P.O.
abstract: They did it.

headline: Bank of America Names Global Markets Head
abstract: Bank of America said Friday that it promoted Thomas G. White to head of global markets and that Mark Werner, who became chief executive of its investment banking arm less than two years ago, is leaving the company “to pursue other opportunities.” Bloomberg News said three of Mr. Werner’s top executives are leaving with him.

headline: Tom Hicks Wants a $400 Million ‘Blank Check’
abstract: Thomas O. Hicks, the owner of the Texas Rangers and a veteran of the leveraged buyout business, is seeking to raise $400 million for his “blank check” company, Hicks Acquisition. He is jumping into a crowded field: Nearly 100 blank check companies have held initial public offerings since August 2003, creating a small army of shell companies, each prowling for an acquisition target.

headline: Spain’s Iberdrola Fires Up Deal for Energy East
abstract: The Spanish power company Iberdrola plans to buy the regional utility owner Energy East Corporation for $4.5 billion in cash, the companies announced Monday. The boards of the utilities, meeting in New York and Madrid, agreed to the deal, which would give Energy East shareholders $28.50 a share, representing a 27 percent premium over the closing stock price Friday of $22.37.

headline: UBS to Dispose of $3.3 Billion Julius Baer Stake
abstract: UBS, the world’s biggest money manager, plans to sell its 4.1 billion-Swiss franc ($3.3 billion) stake in bank Julius Baer Holding and use the proceeds to buy back shares.

headline: Tudor Investment Shutters Small-Stock Fund
abstract: Tudor Investment, the hedge-fund firm run by Paul Tudor Jones, is shutting its $550 million small-company stock fund after returns failed to meet expectations.

headline: Expedia Going Private? ‘Absolutely Not,’ Company Says
abstract: Buyout speculation sent Expedia.com‘s stock on a wild trip Friday. But for now, at least, it seems the travel Web site isn’t going anywhere.

headline: Allianz Sells Stake in Hana Financial
abstract: Allianz, Europe’s biggest insurer, sold 463 billion won ($497 million) of shares in Hana Financial Group, a South Korean bank, ending a seven-year equity partnership with the company, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Clear Channel Accepts Higher Bid
abstract: Sometimes more turns out to be less. Just as soon as Clear Channel Communications announced Wednesday that its private equity suitors had raised their offer to $39 per share from $37.60 per share — confirming a report in that morning’s New York Times — the company’s stock started to fall. The shares were down more than 1 percent at $36.28 in the hour before the close of trading.

headline: More Cuts Expected at Top Tribune Papers
abstract: Tribune, which has agreed to be taken private in an $8.2 billion deal, is expected to announce staffing reductions as early as Monday at its flagship Chicago Tribune as well as its largest-circulation newspaper, The Los Angeles Times, as revenue in the newspaper industry declines.

headline: Commerzbank Jumps on Rumors of a Citigroup Deal
abstract: Shares in Germany’s Commerzbank, which has been persistently cited as a possible takeover target, jumped more than 3 percent on Tuesday to near a seven-year peak on market talk that Citigroup was likely to bid about 45 euros ($61) per share for the bank, traders said.

headline: TD Banknorth Shareholders Approve Sale to Parent
abstract: TD Banknorth shareholders have approved a plan by Toronto-Dominion Bank, which already owns nearly 60 percent of the Bank, to acquire the rest of the shares for $3.6 billion. The transaction is expected to close April 20, at which time TD Banknorth’s shares will be delisted from the New York Stock Exchange, the company said Wednesday. TD Banknorth, which is based in Portland, Maine, will then become a subsidiary of Toronto-dominion Bank, which is based in Toronto.

headline: J.P. Morgan Reports Record Profit in First Quarter
abstract: J.P. Morgan Chase said its profit jumped 55 percent from a year ago to $4.8 billion in the first quarter, a record for the firm. It also raised its stock dividend by 12 percent, marking the firm’s first dividend increase in six years.

headline: Ex-Qwest Official Testifies on Stock Buyback
abstract: Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communicationswho is on trial on charges of insider trading, called for a repurchase of $1 billion in company stock in 2001, a former Qwest president testified on Monday. Mr. Nacchio, 57, is accused of selling $101 million in Qwest shares from January 2001 to May 2001, before the stock price plunged, based on inside information that the company would miss its revenue targets.

headline: Prosecutors May Add Charges in ‘Squawk Box’ Retrial
abstract: Three ex-brokers at Citigroup, Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers  face a November retrial on charges they conspired to commit fraud by letting day traders eavesdrop on the firm’s internal “squawk boxes.”

headline: Morgan Stanley Analyst Defects to Hedge Fund
abstract: A well-known property analyst at Morgan Stanley in Hong Kong has left the Wall Street firm for an alternative investment manager based in the United States, joining an industry-wide migration in recent years.

headline: Blackstone I.P.O. May Test Unusual Tax Treatment
abstract: As the Blackstone Group considers holding a $4 billion public offering, the private equity firm’s unusual structure as a master limited partnership could leave room for the Internal Revenue Service to challenge its tax-law assumptions, some analysts and academics told Reuters.

headline: UniCredit and Capitalia Confirm Merger Talks
abstract: UniCredit and Capitalia, two of the largest Italian banks, confirmed Tuesday for the first time that they were in merger talks, but said no accord had been reached. The shares of Capitalia, which is considered by investors as the takeover target in any deal, rose 40 cents, or 5.3 percent, to 7.91 euros, valuing the company at 20.5 billion euros, or $27.8 billion.

headline: Bidders Raise Offer for Affiliated Computer
abstract: The group staging a management buyout of Affiliated Computer Services, the technology services provider, raised their bid on Monday to $62 from $59.25 a share, saying that the company’s board had rejected an earlier proposal.

headline: Drug Maker to Plead Guilty to Making False Statements
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb said Thursday that it would plead guilty to criminal charges that it made false statements to the government, a move meant to end a federal antitrust investigation of the drug maker’s botched efforts last year to preserve a lucrative monopoly for the anti-clotting medicine Plavix.

headline: Quebecor Sees Potential for Media Unit I.P.O.
abstract: Canada’s Quebecor might consider an initial public offering for its media division if conditions become right, a move that would help facilitate stock-based acquisitions, Quebecor’s chief executive, Pierre Karl Péladeau told The Globe and Mail.

headline: The Private-Equity Approach to Executive Pay
abstract: With scrutiny of executive pay practices heating up in the United States, the private equity industry may have something to add to the debate.

headline: Senior Executives Quit Proxy Firm
abstract: Two senior executives have quit the proxy advisory firm Glass Lewis & Company amid questions over whether its China-based parent, Xinhua Finance Media, withheld unfavorable information about its former chief financial officer. Barron’s reported on Sunday that the prospectus of Xinhua Finance Media, controlled by Xinhua Finance, based in Tokyo, withheld details about business dealings of the finance chief, Shelly Singhal.

headline: This Start-Up Would Like You to Meet Your Virtual Doorman
abstract: The doorman occupies a complex spot in the New York City class system: the doorman is at once status-symbol, diplomat and taxi-hailer. And now, he may be virtual, if one start-up has its way.

headline: MGM Mirage Sets Advisers for Kerkorian Talks
abstract: Negotiations with your own controlling investor are bound to be complicated. To help navigate its talks with majority shareholder Kirk Kerkorian, MGM Mirage has enlisted some help. The casino company said Friday that a special transaction committee of independent directors has hired UBS and the law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges as advisers as it considers the recent proposal from Mr. Kerkorian’s investment firm, Tracinda.

headline: Manor Care Hires Financial Adviser
abstract: Manor Care, a nursing-home operator, said Wednesday it had hired J.P. Morgan Chase to help it explore a “full range of opportunities” to add shareholder value. The company did not give any specifics about the alternatives under review but said in a news release that it was “well-positioned to consider taking advantage of currently attractive conditions in the financial markets.” Manor Care’s stock surged after the announcement, rising 11 percent in early trading Wednesday to $61.65, a 52-week high. At that price, the company has a market capitalization of about $4.5 billion.

headline: The Pre-Trial Limbo of the NatWest Three
abstract: Since their extradition from Britain in July, three London bankers – known as the NatWest three – have been living in a peculiar limbo, as they await trial in Houston his fall on charges stemming from the collapse of Enron.

headline: Manufacturers Seen as Potential Buyout Bait
abstract: Options traders are apparently not the only ones who see Illinois Tool Works as a possible candidate for a leveraged buyout. The company, whose products include industrial fasteners and commercial meat slicers, was one of the manufacturers that Victor Consoli, a credit strategist at Bear Stearns, flagged this week as potentially attractive to private equity firms.

headline: Dial C for Citigroup, and for the Chief
abstract: Have a beef about Citigroup‘s stock price? Or did you find a strange charge on your bank account? Either way, you can take your idea straight to the top. Charles O. Prince III, Citi’s chief executive, took investor relations to a bizarre extreme Tuesday when he gave out his e-mail address (princec@citigroup.com) and phone number (212-793-8854) at the bank’s annual shareholder meeting. As The New York Times’s Eric Dash reported, Citi’s meeting ended up being a marathon session where myriad grievances were aired, including gripes about bank customer service or policies.

headline: Adviser on TXU Deal Warns on Texas Energy Bill
abstract: The chief adviser to the two private equity firms that have agreed to buy TXU suggested that the buyout shops might walk away if the Texas House of Representatives decides that the deal for the energy company will require state approval. Texas lawmakers on Thursday will debate whether the $45 billion buyout of TXU by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group should require state regulatory approval.

headline: RBS Alliance Publishes Details of ABN Amro Bid
abstract: The consortium that wants to buy and break up ABN Amro on Monday published confidential details of its offer, which the Dutch bank rejected last week. The consortium, which includes Royal Bank of Scotland, Santander, and Fortis, said their proposal had “lower execution risk” than an agreed deal between ABN and Britain’s Barclays Bank and was worth more.

headline: The Dangers of Sitting in Line
abstract: Waiting for an iPhone isn’t all fun and games. John F. Street, the Philadelphia mayor, according to an Associated Press story, was waiting in line when he was approached by a citizen:

headline: Topps Fields New Takeover Offer from Rival
abstract: Another player has stepped into the brawl over the baseball card maker Topps, which agreed in March to be acquired by the private equity firm Madison Dearborn and Tornante, the investment vehicle of former chief executive of Disney, Michael Eisner. The new pitch is coming from Upper Deck, a rival baseball card company, which is offering $10.75 a share in cash for Topps — 10 percent more than the Madison Dearborn team’s $9.75-per-share bid, which had a value of $385 million. Three Topps directors are bitterly opposed to the latter offer, calling it too low, and have urged shareholders to reject it at a June 28 vote.

headline: Electronic Arts to Reorganize
abstract: Electronic Arts, the world’s biggest video game publisher, said on Friday it would reorganize into four units in an efficiency drive by its new chief executive, John Riccitiello. Under the plan, Electronic Arts will consist of units that focus on sports, casual games, the Sims franchise and other games.

headline: Regulators Expand Biovail Inquiry
abstract: Biovail, a Canadian drug maker, said regulators in the United States had expanded their investigation into questionable accounting and possibly misleading financial disclosures. The company said it had received a so-called Wells notice from the Securities and Exchange Commission relating to its 2003 accounting, a 2002 acquisition, and how it accounts for revenue.

headline: H&R Block Shares Rise Amid Buyout Speculation
abstract: Will a slimmed-down H&R Block look more appealing to private equity? That is what an analyst at UBS Investment Bank was suggesting Monday.

headline: News Corp. Shareholders Accept Liberty Deal
abstract: Shareholders of the News Corporation have approved an $11 billion asset swap that increases Rupert Murdoch’s control over the company and transfers the DirecTV Group to Liberty Media, controlled by John C. Malone.

headline: Activist Shareholders Demand A Vodafone Shake-Up
abstract: John Mayo, the former deputy chief executive of Marconi, is backing a group of investors who are seeking to restructure Vodafone and unlock up to 38 billion ($76 billion) in value from the mobile phone group.

headline: Tom Wolfe on Hedge Funds: Not a Pretty Picture
abstract: There are ellipses. Oh, yes. And exclamation points. You bet! But not as many as might be expected.

headline: 2 Buyout Firms to Acquire Ahold’s U.S. Foodservice
abstract: Royal Ahold, the Dutch food retailing giant, will sell its U.S. Foodservice business to two United States-based private equity firms for $7.1 billion. Clayton Dubilier & Rice and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts agreed to buy the unit, which was the focus of an accounting scandal that emerged in 2003. U.S. Foodservice is the second-largest food service company, behind Sysco.

headline: Amazon Adds Brilliance to Its Stable
abstract: Amazon.com announced Wednesday its acquisition of an audio-book publisher, Brilliance Audio, in a move to tighten its tie with book publishers and expand the number of audio-book titles it sells. Amazon is seeking to expand beyond offering only best-sellers under an audio-book format. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

headline: G.E. Should Shed NBC, Citi Analyst Says
abstract: Some Citigroup analysts have big plans for General Electric, the world’s second-largest company by market capitalization after ExxonMobil.

headline: McClatchy Draws Interest From Big Hedge Fund
abstract: A couple of days after an unusual spike in shares of McClatchy prompted talk — highly speculative talk — that the newspaper chain was a takeover target, there is another intriguing, though inconclusive, development.

headline: Masters of the New Universe
abstract: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

headline: Lehman to Buy Energy Services Firm
abstract: Lehman Brothers said it would acquire Eagle Energy Partners, a Houston-based energy services company, becoming the latest investment bank to bolster its presence in the physical energy markets. “Commodities over the last several years have become a very significant asset class,” Skip McGee, Lehman’s head of global investment banking, told MarketWatch.

headline: Cerberus Said to Consider Bid for Bell Canada
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is also circling.

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Another Swing at Topps
abstract: A New York hedge fund, Crescendo Partners, on Thursday alleged that certain Topps board members have conflicts of interest that prevent the trading card and confection company from negotiating in good faith with its rival, Upper Deck, on a potential acquisition.

headline: Apollo Seeks to Sell Stake to Investors
abstract: Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black. The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said. DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.

headline: Why Should A Sale Scare Wall Street?
abstract: Why Wall Street Fears A Real Market In Mortgage Securities

headline: Are Airline Bids Like Potato Chips?
abstract: Why did W. Douglas Parker, the chief executive of US Airways, launch a hostile bid for Delta Air Lines so soon after the merger of US Airways and America West? Partly “to maximize value,” he told Fortune magazine’s Barney Gimbel as he was awaiting a decision from Delta’s creditors’ committee in January. “But it’s also kind of fun, too.”

headline: Wall St. Lobby Firm Says It Investigated Former Co-Chief
abstract: Wall Street’s largest and most important trade association acknowledged Wednesday that one of its co-chief executives resigned abruptly earlier this year after an internal investigation uncovered loose financial management by him.

headline: Big Union Takes Skeptical Look at Private Equity
abstract: In Europe, private equity firms are accustomed to feeling the heat from unions. Now, the temperature is rising in the United States as well.

headline: EMI Says Bidders Are Circling
abstract: British music group EMI, home to Robbie Williams and Coldplay, said on Friday it had received a number of takeover approaches, following a report that private equity firm One Equity Partners had joined the list of suitors.

headline: Blackstone I.P.O. Could Reach $4.75 Billion
abstract: Blackstone Group pulled back the veil a little further on its closely watched initial public offering on Monday, as it filed an amended prospectus with regulators. The major addition was the terms of its planned $3 billion investment from China, but the financial aspects of the offering were fleshed out as well. The private equity giant said that it planned to offer 133.3 million units at a price of $29 to $31 each and was giving underwriters the option of selling 20 million more. At the maximum, the I.P.O. could raise a whopping $4.75 billion (an amount that doesn’t include the $3 billion infusion from China’s investment arm).

headline: Wanna Buy A (Zimbabwean) Dollar at 98% Off?
abstract: Ata 98% discount, this currency is still overvalued.

headline: Ex-Ahold Official Sentenced
abstract: A former marketing executive of the American-based food distribution unit of the Dutch food retailer Ahold was sentenced to seven years in prison by a federal judge yesterday for his role in an $800 million accounting fraud.

headline: Consumer Group Cries Foul on Google’s DoubleClick Deal
abstract: A consumer group asked the Federal Trade Commission on Friday to investigate and block Google’s proposed $3.1 billion purchase of the online advertising company DoubleClick unless the companies improve consumer privacy protections.

headline: Inland American’s Pushiness Pays Off with Winston Acquisition
abstract: After forcing its way into the bidding, the Inland American Real Estate Trust has won the fight for Winston Hotels for about $458 million. In February, Winston Hotels of Raleigh, N.C., agreed to be acquired by private-equity interests in New York, but last month Inland American pushed its way into the picture by making an unsolicited $15-a-share proposal.

headline: Trans-Atlantic Exchange to Be Listed Today
abstract: The chiefs of the merged New York Stock Exchange and Euronext said Tuesday, on the eve of the opening day of trading of its shares, that they were determined to create a truly global market that would include operations in China.

headline: Buyout Shop Swallows Sam’s Wine and Spirits
abstract: Family control of Sam’s Wines and Spirits has ended with a deal announced Friday to sell 80 percent of the third-generation business to a Chicago private-equity firm. The deal with buyout shop Arbor Investments provides Sam’s with access to capital that would allow it to expand at a time when Internet sales are putting pressure on wine-and-spirits stores.

headline: UniCredit Sizes Up Societe Generale and Capitalia
abstract: UniCredit, Italy’s biggest bank, is on the hunt and has Societe Generale and Capitalia in its sights. The bank, which just 18 months ago shelled out $21 billion to take over the HVB Group of Germany, said it is considering making a move either on the French bank or the Italian lender, which is controlled by a group of investors including ABN Amro.

headline: A First for Private Equity as Fortress Reports Results
abstract: The Fortress Investment Group became the first American hedge fund and private equity firm to report quarterly earnings Tuesday, and the disclosures highlighted the difficulties the public markets have in dealing with businesses whose income streams are volatile and difficult to predict.

headline: Hertz Backers Plan $1 Billion Offering
abstract: Hertz Global Holdings said Clayton Dubilier & Rice, Merrill Lynch and the Carlyle Group plan to sell shares valued at almost $1 billion after the stock gained 40 percent since its initial offering in November.

headline: Cerberus Plans Bell Canada Bid
abstract: BCE, the parent of Bell Canada, the largest communications company in Canada, said that a group led by Cerberus Capital Management had joined the bidding for the company. While the other investors were not identified, they will be vital to any deal because Canadian law bans foreign control of telephone companies. Three groups are now vying to take BCE private. BCE’s largest shareholder, the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan, has allied itself with other institutional investors for a possible bid.

headline: Charterhouse Plans for Saga I.P.O.
abstract: A British private equity firm, Charterhouse, is considering an initial public offering of Saga, a company that sells holiday travel packages and insurance to elderly consumers. Charterhouse provided financial alssistance for a management buyout of the company three years ago. Saga has appointed Close Brothers to work with the board in “exploring future ownership options” for the business, according to reports. An initial public offering would take place in the latter half of 2007 while analysts believe a float would value Saga at more than £2.5 billion.

headline: Rival Group Launches Hostile Bid for ABN Amro
abstract: A group led by Royal Bank of Scotland Group said on Friday it will make an unsolicited offer for ABN Amro Holding, escalating the fight with Barclays  for control of the biggest Dutch bank.

headline: Ebay In Talks for StumbleUpon, Report Says
abstract: Ebay is in talks to buy StumbleUpon, a Web site rating system that has been the subject of deal speculation for some time, according to the blog TechCrunch.

headline: Black’s Lawyers Hammer Former Partner’s Testimony
abstract: It was an enormous betrayal by his former associates – and not any act of criminal fraud – that led Conrad M. Black to the Chicago courtroom where, if convicted, he could face the rest of his days in prison, lawyers for the media baron said in their closing arguments.

headline: Ex-Brokers in ‘Squawk Box’ Case Face Retrial
abstract: Three former brokers for Citigroup, Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers face a second trial on charges that they conspired to commit fraud by allowing day traders to eavesdrop on orders on internal “squawk boxes.” Four current and former executives at the day trading firm A.B. Watley Group will also be retried on charges that they had a role in the scheme, the United States attorney’s office in Brooklyn said Monday.

headline: Another Tough Day in Court for Former Black Lieutenant
abstract: Former Chicago Sun-Times Publisher and Hollinger International President F. David Radler spent a third day fending off harsh questions and assertions that he is a liar, as his cross-examination in the criminal fraud trial of ousted Hollinger Chief Executive Conrad Black continued Monday.

headline: ‘Oceans 13’ Writers Delve Into Hedge-Fund Life
abstract: Given the recent troubles in the hedge-fund business — a $3.2 billion bailout at Bear Stearns, a 16-month losing streak at Goldman Sachs‘s flagship fund — one cannot help but wonder about the timing of the forthcoming HBO series about hedge-fund managers. Will it turn out to be something akin to, say launching a new series in early 2000 about hotshot venture capitalists?

headline: Closing Arguments Begin in Trial of Ex-Qwest Chief
abstract: A federal prosecutor, Colleen Conry, portrayed Joseph P. Nacchio, former chief executive of Qwest International, on Tuesday as a man who knowingly and unlawfully concealed Qwest’s growing money troubles, while simultaneously cashing in on his stock options.

headline: Investors Tune in to Border Media
abstract: Spanish-language radio station operator Border Media Partners has raised $111 million from a private equity consortium, that includes Vestar Capital Partners, Goldman Sachs Urban Investment Group and Darby Overseas Investments.

headline: A Home That Heats and Cools Itself
abstract: This week, on my blog, I’ve been writing about the inventions I saw at last week’s Modern Marvels/Invent Now finals. About 25,000 inventors from all walks of life entered this annual contest, which is run by the History Channel and the National Inventors Hall of Fame. I was among the six judges who were asked to declare a winner from among the 25 finalists still standing.

headline: Southwest Airlines Chief Says Buyout Is Unlikely
abstract: Could private equity try to board Southwest Airlines? One credit analyst says the carrier, known for its quirky, no-frills style, could be a tempting buyout candidate. But Southwest’s chief executive, Gary Kelly, sounds skeptical.

headline: The Goal Is Superimmunity; The Status, Almost There
abstract: Green tech may capturing all the headlines in venture capital deals these days, but a broad renaissance in vaccine research and development is nonetheless capturing the attention (and cash) of V.C.’s and big-name charities like the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.

headline: Why Live Near the Office?
abstract: A boss who won’t live near the office may not make many friends.

headline: Qatar Fund Said to Be in Lead for Barneys
abstract: A private equity fund linked to the royal family of Qatar appears to be the favored bidder for the upscale department store Barneys New York, Women’s Wear Daily reported. The trade paper said that an unnamed fund was edging out bids from other suitors with an offer of more than $1 billion for Barneys, which is owned by the Jones Apparel Corporation.

headline: To Win Key Player, Citigroup May Buy His Hedge Fund
abstract: In an effort to bring Wall Street veteran Vikram Pandit into the fold, Citigroup is considering shelling out as much as $600 million for the former Morgan Stanley banker’s hedge fund, Old Lane.

headline: Thomson and Reuters Agree to $17 Billion Merger
abstract: Reuters Group and the Thomson Corporation said Tuesday that they had agreed to a $17.2 billion combination that will create one of the world’s largest financial news providers. The announcement came less than two weeks after the two companies said they were in talks about a possible merger. The deal is not without obstacles, however. Antitrust regulators, and especially those in the European Union, are likely to take a close look at the transaction and its effects on competition. An analyst in London told Bloomberg News there was a “75 percent chance” the deal would go through.

headline: J.P. Morgan’s Dimon Talks Deal Making
abstract: Following comments last year by James Dimon that J.P. Morgan Chase was ready to do some deal making, the bank’s chief executive provided a few more details on the subject, but still appeared to be hedging his bets.

headline: Will Blogging Software Firms Attract Buyers?
abstract: For the social software side of Enterprise 2.0, there may be a short window of opportunity for M&A, according to the analyst firm The 451 Group, which takes a look at the potential buyers and sellers in the market for wiki and blogging software. Among the potential acquisition targets named in the report are Six Apart and Atlassian Software Systems; 451 Group analyst Kathleen Reidy considers the software giant Oracle to be the most logical buyer of such assets.

headline: Will RBS Crash the ABN Amro Party?
abstract: As Barclays and ABN Amro continue to thrash out a deal, speculation mounted Wednesday that the Royal Bank of Scotland could foil the British bank’s proposed takeover of the Dutch giant.

headline: AirTran Raises Midwest Bid Again
abstract: AirTran Holdings, the discount airline company, is planning to raise its hostile bid for the Midwest Air Group a third time, to $15 a share, people briefed on the offer said Sunday night. The company plans to announce the new bid Monday, these people said.

headline: Netgear Bulks Up with Infrant Buy
abstract: Netgear, a Santa Clara, Calif. maker of equipment that lets customers set up household Internet networks, agreed to buy closely held Infrant Technologies for $60 million to gain access to its data storage products. Additionally, Netgear may pay as much as $20 million in cash over three years if Infrant meets revenue goals, Netgear said Thursday in a statement.

headline: Battery Ventures Buys Quovadx for $136.7 Million
abstract: A software company, Quovadx, has reached an agreement to be sold to Battery Ventures for $136.7 million, the company said. Battery Ventures is a venture capital and private equity firm with offices in Boston and the Silicon Valley.

headline: Bank Settles Claims Over Lost Tax Papers
abstract: Mellon Bank has agreed to pay $16.5 million to the federal government to settle claims that it allowed overwhelmed employees to destroy thousands of federal tax returns and payments in 2001. In turn, the government will not pursue any civil or administrative monetary claims against Mellon, the United States district attorney’s office and Mellon Bank said Thursday.

headline: Navteq Stock Rises Amid Buyout Speculation
abstract: Navteq shares hit a 10-month high after an analyst said a buyout firm may be interested in acquiring the company, which makes maps used in car navigation systems. William Benton of William Blair & Company wrote in a research note that a private equity fund could be attracted to Navteq’s growth potential, strong cash flow and lack of debt. It has a market capitalization of about $4 billion.

headline: No Rival Bids Emerge for First Data
abstract: Private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts can go ahead with its $29 billion takeover of First Data without worrying about another suitor. First Data, one of the nation’s largest credit-card processing companies, said Tuesday that a period for soliciting competing bids passed without any other takeover proposals.

headline: A $12 Billion Start for I.P.O.’s in 2007
abstract: In the first quarter of the year, initial public offerings have raised about $12 billion, 18 percent more than in the comparable period last year. The hedge fund manager Fortress Investment Group was the biggest first day earner with a pop of 67 percent at its opening and is the second-richest offering to open this year with a purse of $634 million.

headline: Cisco May Be Stalking Big Game
abstract: Cisco Systems may be gearing up for some big plays, according to BusinessWeek. In an effort to increase growth at the networking company, Ned Hooper, who heads up business development, which includes mergers and acquisitions as well as venture capital investments, is looking to make bigger-and potentially riskier-acquisitions than the company has ever done before, according to the magazine.

headline: Bronfmann Sues Vivendi Over Pension Payments
abstract: Vivendi‘s former vice chairman Edgar Bronfman Jr. sued the company Tuesday, alleging it improperly cut his pension payments by 65 percent. In a lawsuit filed in United States District Court in Manhattan, Mr. Bronfman, now chief executive of the Warner Music Group, contends that Vivendi, the French entertainment group, reduced his pension last year after claiming it had erroneously been crediting him for 15 years of service beyond the 20 years of actual service Bronfman had already accrued.

headline: Lexicon Strikes Two Deals with Private Equity
abstract: Lexicon Pharmaceuticals, a developer of treatments for diseases like irritable bowel syndrome, has signed deals with two private equity firms that will invest nearly $300 million into the 12-year-old publicly held company.

headline: For Buyout Firms, Patience Is a Virtue
abstract: Low interest rates aren’t the only reason that private equity firms are having a buyout bonanza, Derek DeCloet writes in The Globe and Mail. These firms have something that fund managers and the public markets seem to lack: A long-term perspective.

headline: EGL Chooses Apollo Over Its Founder
abstract: The logistics company EGL has ended its buyout agreement with its chief, James R. Crane, and has accepted a higher offer from Ceva Logistics, which is owned by the private equity firm Apollo Management.

headline: Fortress Drives off With Interpool
abstract: the Fortress Investment Group, the private equity and hedge fund manager that went public in February, has agreed to buy Interpool for $2.4 billion. Through several of its private equity funds, Fortress is bidding $27.50 in stock and debt for Interpool, a transportation equipment and services company based in Princeton, N.J. Interpool said that the deal represents a 6 percent premium over its closing price on Friday of $25.59.

headline: Bank of America to Lose Executive in U.S. Trust Deal
abstract: The Bank of America said Tuesday that Peter Scaturro, the chief executive of U.S. Trust, will not join the bank as originally planned when the two companies combine later this year. Mr. Scaturro, 47, will step down from U.S. Trust before the transaction is completed, a Bank of America spokeswoman said, declining to comment on the reason for his departure. Mr. Scaturro had been expected to become head of Bank of America’s private-banking business after it purchased U.S. Trust from Charles Schwab.

headline: Institutional Venture Partners Raises $600 Million for Late-Stage Deals
abstract: A Silicon Valley venture firm, Institutional Venture Partners, raised $600 million in the largest venture fund in its 26-year history, double the size of its previous fund, as it shifts its focus to late-stage investments.

headline: Rival Offer Reignites Topps Battle
abstract: Some board members and shareholders of Topps, the baseball card maker, are furious with the company after it shunned a higher bid from its rival Upper Deck in favor of a $385 million deal with Disney’s former boss Michael D. Eisner, The New York Post reported.

headline: In Search for a New Financial Sheriff, One Stands Out
abstract: As New York attorney general, Eliot Spitzer won national attention by becoming the new sheriff in finance, taking on Wall Street and mutual funds and the insurance industry.

headline: Dow Jones and Murdoch Said to Agree on Journal Protections
abstract: The board of directors at Dow Jones and the News Corporation have reached a deal on the make up of an editorial board that would oversee Dow Jones’ flagship newspaper, the Wall Street Journal, paving the way for a takeover of the entire company, MarketWatch reported, citing an unnamed source. Reuters, citing two separate sources, said the two “basically agreed” to a structure Monday night, but that several items needed to be discussed.

headline: Citigroup Wants to ‘Get It Done’
abstract: Cititgoup‘s new tagline, “Let’s Get It Done”, could double as a rallying cry for the bank’s chief Charles O. Prince III.

headline: In Hedge Fund Haven, a Golf Course Goes Begging
abstract: Presidential hopefuls have been traveling hat in hand to Greenwich, Conn., usually leaving with wads of hedge-fund money. But the town’s own public golf course has been far less successful at prying cash out of the hands of Greenwich’s well-heeled citizens.

headline: CommScope to Buy Cable Maker for $2.6 Billion
abstract: CommScope, a maker of communications equipment, said Wednesday it would buy the Andrew Corporation for $15 per share, or about $2.6 billion. Last year, CommScope offered to buy Andrew, which sells cables and antennas, but quickly withdrew its bid.

headline: Energy Investors Look to Private Equity Partners
abstract: Venture investors are searching for a new model for alternative energy deals, and partnerships with private equity funds may be part of the solution, The Deal reports. These investors want to get high returns on early developments so they are not diluted when the time comes for raising capital for building production facilities. Volatile energy prices only add to the uncertainty. “It’s a very difficult balancing act for venture capital investors in energy right now,” the head of the energy ventures group at Portland, Ore.-based law firm Stoel Rives tells The Deal.

headline: Ackman’s Pershing Opposes Ceridian Sale
abstract: Ceridian‘s largest shareholder, Pershing Square Capital Management, has opposed the company’s sale to Thomas H. Lee Partners and Fidelity National Financial, saying the offer is too low.

headline: Citigroup Unit in Australia Cleared of Insider Trading
abstract: Citigroup, the world’s largest financial company, was cleared of insider trading in Australia on Thursday in a case that challenged the way investment banks operate.

headline: Clear Channel Accepts Revised Takeover Bid
abstract: Clear Channel Communications is hoping that an extra 20 cents a share, plus the option to own a piece of the company, will finally clear the way for its controversial buyout to go through. The radio broadcasting giant said Friday that it had agreed to amend the terms of the buyout to include $39.20 in cash for each Clear Channel share, up from $39, and a provision allowing shareholders to take stock in the post-takeover company instead of cash. The “stub equity,” as the stock portion is commonly called, would be limited to 30 percent of Clear Channel’s equity and would not be listed on any exchange, Clear Channel said in a press release.

headline: Dimon Was the Only Source for Dow Chemical Firings
abstract: The story behind the firing of two Dow Chemical executives for allegedly being “involved in unauthorized discussions with third parties about the potential acquisition of the company” became even more bizarre – and clouded – as the two men sued Dow Chemical, contending that they were defamed. The company, in turn, has sued both men.

headline: I.B.M. Settles Suit Over Stock Expenses
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission said Tuesday that I.B.M. had settled a case in which it had been accused of misleading investors by overestimating the impact of stock-based compensation expenses on quarterly earnings in 2005.

headline: Nordstrom to Sell Façonnable to Lebanese Investment Firm, Report Says
abstract: Nordstrom appears to have reached a deal to sell its Façonnable chain to a Lebanese private equity firm for about $200 million, The New York Post reported. The report said that Façonnable employees received word of the impending sale on Tuesday, along with the potential for some job cuts.

headline: New Century Dismisses 2 Top Executives
abstract: New Century Financial, the bankrupt housing lender, disclosed on Tuesday that it had fired its chief executive and an executive vice president and named its chief restructuring officer to the post of chief executive.

headline: McClatchy Draws Interest From Big Hedge Fund
abstract: A couple of days after an unusual spike in shares of McClatchy prompted talk — highly speculative talk — that the newspaper chain was a takeover target, there is another intriguing, though inconclusive, development.

headline: Masters of the New Universe
abstract: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

headline: Lehman to Buy Energy Services Firm
abstract: Lehman Brothers said it would acquire Eagle Energy Partners, a Houston-based energy services company, becoming the latest investment bank to bolster its presence in the physical energy markets. “Commodities over the last several years have become a very significant asset class,” Skip McGee, Lehman’s head of global investment banking, told MarketWatch.

headline: Cerberus Said to Consider Bid for Bell Canada
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is also circling.

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Another Swing at Topps
abstract: A New York hedge fund, Crescendo Partners, on Thursday alleged that certain Topps board members have conflicts of interest that prevent the trading card and confection company from negotiating in good faith with its rival, Upper Deck, on a potential acquisition.

headline: Apollo Seeks to Sell Stake to Investors
abstract: Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black. The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said. DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.

headline: Why Should A Sale Scare Wall Street?
abstract: Why Wall Street Fears A Real Market In Mortgage Securities

headline: Are Airline Bids Like Potato Chips?
abstract: Why did W. Douglas Parker, the chief executive of US Airways, launch a hostile bid for Delta Air Lines so soon after the merger of US Airways and America West? Partly “to maximize value,” he told Fortune magazine’s Barney Gimbel as he was awaiting a decision from Delta’s creditors’ committee in January. “But it’s also kind of fun, too.”

headline: Wall St. Lobby Firm Says It Investigated Former Co-Chief
abstract: Wall Street’s largest and most important trade association acknowledged Wednesday that one of its co-chief executives resigned abruptly earlier this year after an internal investigation uncovered loose financial management by him.

headline: Big Union Takes Skeptical Look at Private Equity
abstract: In Europe, private equity firms are accustomed to feeling the heat from unions. Now, the temperature is rising in the United States as well.

headline: May Could Bring a Sweet I.P.O. Market
abstract: Start-ups preparing to go public and the bankers backing them are hoping for a merry, merry month of May. The Red Herring notes that bankers are hoping to raise $1.4 billion this week with six new stocks coming to market, and have $1.3 billion lined up for the following week.

headline: Spain Orders Search and Capture of Odyssey’s Ships
abstract: The story of the discovery of a disputed undersea trove of gold and silver valued at $500 million by an American company continues to unfold like a pirate adventure.

headline: Inflation Soars — But Wall Steet Ignores It
abstract: Wall Street thinks inflation is low. Consumers know it isn’t.

headline: Funds Seek Break-Up of Britain’s Prudential
abstract: Yet another group of hedge fund shareholders is on the move, this time urging Prudential Chief Officer Mark Tucker to break up Britain’s second-biggest insurer. New Star Asset Management Group, Jupiter Asset Management and Canada Life of London, which together oversee about $91 billion, say Prudential’s British division is dragging down faster-growing units in Asia and the United Sates. Earnings in Britain fell 7.9 percent in 2006, while profit in Asia jumped 20 percent, according to Bloomberg News.

headline: A New Warning on Real Estate
abstract: An expert was wrong once. Can we depend on him to be wrong again?

headline: Bally Total Fitness to Restructure in Bankruptcy
abstract: Bally Total Fitness, the health-club chain, said Thursday it would file for bankruptcy protection as part of a plan to reduce its debt. The proposed restructuring would make Phil Anschutz, a Denver financier, a major shareholder. Tennenbaum Capital Partners and Goldman Sachs would also get stock in the reorganized company in exchange for their notes.

headline: Virtual Tennis on a Sunny Saturday
abstract: Love of the Nintendo Wii brings tennis players to a Brooklyn bar.

headline: For Online Brokers, Another Deal Option
abstract: Steven Cohen of the hedge fund SAC Capital may want TD Ameritrade to strike a deal with Charles Schwab or E*Trade Financial, but an analyst at Banc of America Securities has other ideas.

headline: British Airways May Make a Play for Iberia
abstract: British Airways is considering a bid for Iberia Lineas Aereas de Espana of Spain along with a group of private equity investors to protect its interest in the carrier. British Airways said it had approached “a number of private equity companies.” The airline has not made a final decision on the future of its 10 percent Iberia stake and may sell the holding, the company said.

headline: Intercasting Nets New Funding
abstract: Once narrowly focused on a mobile blog publishing application, Intercasting of San Diego now hopes to be the largest intermediary between mobile phone carriers and social networking sites. Its investors have shown their support for the second time, providing $12 million in new capital to support Intercasting’s growth initiatives. Venrock Associates, the venture capital vehicle of the Rockefeller family, led the new round.

headline: Citic Could Raise $4 Billion in Dual Listing
abstract: China Citic Bank, which jumped the final hurdle for its dual listing in both Hong Kong and Shanghai on Monday, could raise more than $4 billion in its planned initial public offering on April 27. Finance Asia suggests the listings could provide a genuine test of investor appetite for Chinese financial stocks.

headline: J.P. Morgan to Testify on Greek Bond Role
abstract: A J.P. Morgan executive will testify to the Greek parliament on Tuesday about its recent role in underwriting a controversial 280 million euro ($374 million) structured bond that was sold to local pension funds this year.

headline: End of the road for Universal boss?
abstract: The S.E.C. tries to halt a fraud

headline: Are Web 2.0 Startups Missing the I.P.O. Party?
abstract: Initial public offerings “are back – and tech I.P.O.’s are really back,” writes Brian Caulfield of Forbes.com. But “the most heavily hyped segment of the tech boom — the glitzy ‘Web 2.0’ companies — has produced a grand total of zero stock offerings. What gives?” There are various meanings of Web 2.0, and this article doesn’t quite offer up a definition, but it makes reference to the kind of buzzy, Web-based companies backed by venture investors such as Benchmark Capital, Draper Fisher Jurvetson and Sequoia Capital and contrasts them with the networking- and telecom-related tech firms that have held I.P.O.’s this year.

headline: Shareholders Approve Outback Buyout
abstract: Shareholders of the owner of the Outback Steakhouse restaurant brand on Tuesday approved a $3.2 billion takeover offer from a private investor group. The consortium, which includes Bain Capital Partners and investment funds affiliated with Catterton Management offered $41.15 a share in cash for OSI Restaurant Partners.

headline: Cramer on Murdoch: Patience Will Pay Off
abstract: James Cramer says he knows first-hand how badly Rupert Murdoch wants Dow Jones. Writing this week in New York magazine, Mr. Cramer, the former hedge fund manager who is now host of the “Mad Money” show on CNBC, tells the story of how Mr. Murdoch called him 11 years ago to discuss the notion of a bid for Dow Jones, which publishes The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Goldman’s Top Hedge Fund Dropped 5.7 Percent in February
abstract: Goldman Sachs‘s flagship hedge fund, Global Alpha, lost 5.7 percent in February, hurt by positions in stocks, global bonds and currencies including the Japanese yen. The decline left the $10 billion fund down 2 percent for the year through Feb. 28, according to a monthly update sent to investors. That compared with an average gain of 1.9 percent for hedge funds worldwide, according to data compiled by Hedge Fund Research in Chicago.

headline: Dell Unveiled (Minus the Lovely Assistant)
abstract: Dell unveils its new line of redesigned notebook PCs.

headline: A Royal Moment at the Malaysian Grand Prix
abstract: Formula One is definitely an “us” and “them” sport.
