There is what Jackie Stewart likes to call the “inner sanctum” of the paddock, and then there are the cramped grandstands or grass and dirt areas surrounding the circuits where the spectators assemble. There are several levels of spectator areas, from concrete seats to Paddock Club lodges. Some people attend races on buses, others in their cars left in dusty or muddy parking lots, and others fly in by helicopter. The eating habits of race goers ranges from gourmet in the Paddock Club to hot dogs or their equivalent in the outer reaches of the circuit area. The F1 parties vary from the camp fire get togethers to galas with the cream of the Paddock club and a region’s social elite.

headline: NovaStar May Put Itself Up for Sale
abstract: NovaStar Financial, the struggling subprime lender, said Wednesday that it was exploring strategic alternatives, including a possible sale of the company. The company also said it had obtained a $100 million financing commitment arranged by Wachovia Capital Markets.

headline: On Hedge Funds, Batting Averages and Fat Tails
abstract: Hedge funds and those who do business with them were warned Monday by a Treasury official not to operate “under the false illusion” that systemic risk from their activities was not a “real possibility.”

headline: Prudential to Close Equity Research Unit
abstract: The analysts at Prudential Equity Group have issued their last buys, holds and sells (or, to be more exact, their last overweights, neutral weights and underweights).

headline: ValueAct Prevails Over Acxiom
abstract: Acxiom, a data-management company, is being acquired by two investment firms and will be taken private, the chief executive of Acxiom, Charles D. Morgan, announced Wednesday. In a deal worth $2.25 billion, a partnership being formed by the equity firms ValueAct Capital and Silver Lake Partners will pay $27.10 a share in cash, Mr. Morgan said.

headline: Europe Considers Stance on Private Equity
abstract: For most of the last decade, the private equity firms in Germany have argued for preferential tax treatment on the basis of national interest. The breaks are needed, private equity managers said, to help Germany catch up with London and New York, the global centers of the buyout business.

headline: A Fat Wallet Doesn’t Mean Better Hedge Fund Picks
abstract: Wealthy investors say they are no better than anyone else at finding the world’s best hedge funds, those loosely regulated portfolios that can enrich the people who run them and those who invest in them. Three out of four wealthy investors polled by U.S. Trust, a company that has served high net-worth families for more than 150 years, said hedge funds are difficult to investigate and that it is difficult to find a good fund.

headline: Are There Benefits?
abstract: There are benefits as well as costs in Sarbanes-Oxley

headline: In Comments About Apple Chief, Questions of Motive
abstract: When the former chief financial oficer of Apple, Fred D. Anderson, suggested that he had been misled by his former boss, Steven P. Jobs, over the improper back-dating of options, the shot echoed through Silicon Valley.

headline: UBS Researchers Say Banks May Be in for a Merger Binge
abstract: Expectations of a spate of bank mergers are “the highest since the turn of the millennium,” according to UBS research analyst Philip Finch.

headline: K.K.R. May Still Pursue Australia’s Coles
abstract: It may have been spurned once, but Kohlberg Kravis Roberts hasn’t given up on Australia’s Coles yet. Though the supermarket giant said it has received an A$19.7 billion ($16 billion) buyout offer from Wesfarmers and others, K.K.R. said its consortium was still in pursuit. “The consortium continues to look at the Coles business,” a spokesman for the private equity firm told Reuters on Wednesday.

headline: Will Yahoo’s Semel Be Shown the Door?
abstract: Are Terry Semel’s days numbered? As Yahoo delivered a disappointing set of first quarter results and the good news that investors expected from company’s Panama project — the nickname for the firm’s major overhaul of its search advertising system — was not yet a reality, some industry watchers speculated that it may be curtains for the chief executive.

headline: Cash in Hand, AstraZeneca Remains on the Prowl
abstract: AstraZeneca, the British drugmaker, plans to continue making acquisitions to fill its product pipeline, its chief executive, David Brennan, told Bloomberg News.

headline: In Managing Money for the Rich, UBS Comes Out on Top
abstract: UBS, the biggest money manager for the wealthy, widened its lead over Citigroup and Merrill Lynch last year as rising stock markets attracted new funds, according to consulting firm Scorpio Partnership.

headline: Caxton-Iseman to Buy KCP Income Fund
abstract: The KCP Income Fund of Canada will sell itself to a private equity firm, Caxton-Iseman Capital of New York, for about 493 million Canadian dollars ($426 million). The deal was announced Monday. Caxton-Iseman will also assume about 311 million Canadian dollars of debt. The Globe and Mail pointed out that KCP, a bleach and consumer products manufacturer based in Toronto, has become the latest income trust to respond to Ottawa’s new tax regime by selling out to an American private equity firm.

headline: Mandriva Gets Funds to Exit Bankruptcy and Seal a Deal
abstract: Mandriva, a struggling French seller of the Linux operating system, is in the process of raising “a minimum of 3 million euros,” or $4.1 million, the company said Monday. The funds will be used to exit bankruptcy protection and to complete the acquisition of a server software company, Linbox.

headline: Murdoch’s Next Move: Charming the Bancrofts
abstract: And now for the charm offensive.

headline: Apple’s Ex-Top Lawyer May Face Backdating Charges
abstract: Apple‘s former general counsel, Nancy Heinen, may be sued by the Securities and Exchange Commission this week for backdating two stock option grants, including one made to the company’s chief executive, Steve Jobs, her lawyers told Bloomberg News.

headline: Léon in F1 paddock breakout in Monaco
abstract: I could not let a Monaco Grand Prix go by without doing a Stars ‘n Cars post. A few minutes ago I saw within the same two minutes Gordon Ramsay, the British celebrity chef, and Jean Reno, the French tough guy actor. The bigger crowd of photographers was around Ramsay, and I managed to get a photo of him too.

headline: Lawmaker Plays Down Private-Equity Tax Chatter
abstract: Private equity chiefs worried about a much bigger tax bite can take some comfort — though it’s unclear just how much — from Senate Finance Committee Chairman Max Baucus. The Democratic lawmaker from Montana told the National Press Club on Monday that his committee is “nowhere close” to drafting a bill that could affect the amount of tax that private equity funds and hedge funds have to pay. Mr. Baucus called recent reports that such legislation is already being drafted “pure speculation,” according to Bloomberg. “People need to keep their shirts on here.”

headline: An Increasingly Visible D.E. Shaw Hires Its First P.R. Executive
abstract: As D.E. Shaw continues to ramp up its public persona — increasingly taking an active role in pressuring companies to shape-up — it seems the firm felt it needed someone to take care of its burgeoning new image.

headline: Weekend Reading: The State of Investment Banks
abstract: The Economist this week offers a huge package on investment banks, tracing their history and all the “thrills and spills” along the way to the highly profitable present and the highly uncertain, risk-laden future. According to the magazine, while buyout firms and hedge funds are getting most of the attention, glory and money these days, investment bankers don’t mind. When “bankers discuss the fabulous fortunes accruing to these firms’ founders, they do so without envy,” The Economist writes.

headline: It’s Not “All Geek to Me”
abstract: Arrrgh, bad news: evidently, the ratings for “It’s All Geek to Me” (my funny tech show) were low. So Discovery execs have decided NOT to broadcast the final 2 episodes on the Science Channel. Instead, they intend to put those two episodes, complete, here on the Web. (That’s what they SAY. They’re still not posted.)

headline: Hong Kong I.P.O. Creates 2 New Billionaires
abstract: The world’s billionaire ranks became a little more crowded on Wednesday with the listing in Hong Kong of China’s leading retailer of ladies footwear.

headline: Greenspan Finds a Client in Bond Management Firm
abstract: Alan Greenspan, the former Federal Reserve chairman whose pronouncements continue to jolt world markets, has signed a consulting deal with Pimco, the giant bond management firm.

headline: Two Ritchie Funds File for Bankruptcy Protection
abstract: Ritchie Capital put two of its Ireland-based funds into bankruptcy protection Thursday, marking the latest setback for the hedge-fund firm founded by A.R. Thane Ritchie, a former college football star. The funds lost more than $700 million investing in life-insurance policies covering wealthy individuals, and Ritchie has sued Coventry First, which sold it some of the policies, over the losses.

headline: Is Buffett Mulling Move on Kraft?
abstract: Is Warren Buffett waking up and smelling the Maxwell House? Rumors that the chief of Berkshire Hathaway is eyeing Kraft Foods caused a surge in call option activity in the company.

headline: After Failed Bid, Qantas Chairwoman Decides to Retire
abstract: Margaret A. Jackson, the chairwoman of Qantas Airways, who was one of the proponents of a failed attempt to take the airline private, will retire, a company spokesman said Thursday. Ms. Jackson, 54, told the board that she would not seek re-election at the airline’s annual meeting in October.

headline: ABN Amro Fills China Post
abstract: ABN Amro has appointed 26-year banking veteran Soh Wah Siaw as its head of consumer banking in China. The former HSBC executive will replace Linda Wong, who was promoted to the head of China operations for the investment bank last year.

headline: Wall Street Journal Editors Held News of Murdoch Bid
abstract: One of the trickiest things for a news organization to do is cover itself.

headline: Fund Said to Seek Changes at Sprint
abstract: Relational Investors, an activist fund led by Ralph Whitworth, has built a stake of nearly 1 percent in Sprint Nextel, the wireless carrier, and is calling for major changes, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing unidentified sources. Mr. Whitworth has met with Sprint’s management and urged them to reduce capital spending and consider selling Sprint’s fiber-optic networking and long-distance operation, the Journal said.

headline: Palm Is Said to Sell Stake to Equity Firm in Revamping
abstract: Palm, the struggling hand-held device company that makes the Treo, reached a deal on Sunday to sell a quarter of the company to Elevation Partners, a private equity firm, for about $325 million as part of a plan to reorganize the company, The New York Times reported.

headline: U.S. Said to Investigate Kickbacks in Stock Lending
abstract: Federal prosecutors are close to bringing criminal charges against as many as a dozen current and former Wall Street employees in connection with a kickback scheme involving loans of stocks and bonds to hedge funds and short sellers, BusinessWeek reported. So far, federal prosecutors have reportedly secured guilty pleas from three confidential witnesses in the case.

headline: Copper Refiner to Buy Smelter Company
abstract: Norddeutsche Affinerie, the largest European copper refiner, said Sunday that it had agreed to buy Cumerio of Brussels, owner of the biggest copper smelter in southeastern Europe, for 777 million euros, or $1.05 billion.

headline: Arcelor Mittal Is Said to Eye AK Steel
abstract: Deal making in the metals sector is flourishing. The Financial Times’s Alphaville blog reported Tuesday that Arcelor-Mittal, the steel empire run by Lakshmi Mittal, is considering a deal for AK Steel, a smaller Ohio-based rival. Arcelor-Mittal may offer as much as $4.5 billion, or $40 a share, Alphaville said. Shares in AK jumped 3.5 percent to $32 in New York on Monday as news of the impending deal appeared to emerge.

headline: Buyout Firms Reach Deal to Buy Avaya
abstract: Silver Lake Partners and the Texas Pacific Group agreed Monday night to acquire Avaya, the computer-networking company, for $8.2 billion. The deal, priced at $17.50 a share, puts the two private equity firms in control of the world’s biggest maker of corporate phone equipment, letting them go head to head with Cisco Systems in the $5 billion market for Web-based gear. Monday’s agreement calls for Avaya to seek out other potential buyers over the next 50 days.

headline: Kleiner Perkins Expands in China
abstract: The technology investment firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers is opening offices in Shanghai and Beijing and plans to invest a $360 million fund in Chinese Internet, energy, media and communications start-ups, The New York Times reported.

headline: Another Couple’s Sweet Nothings Lead to Insider Trading Charges
abstract: In the latest crackdown on illicit pillow talk, the Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday accused a former Oracle vice president of improperly profiting from his wife’s knowledge about two deals engineered by her boss, Oracle’s chief executive, Lawrence J. Ellison.

headline: McClatchy Considers Parting with CareerBuilder Stake
abstract: Beset by shrinking advertising revenues, newspaper companies have been flailing to find solutions to prop up their income. One solution that McClatchy, the company that bought Knight Ridder last year, is now entertaining: selling its stake in CareerBuilder, the job search Web site. McClatchy, one of the nation’s largest publishers, co-owns the site along with Tribune and Gannett.

headline: Cable & Wireless Says Spinoff Talk Is Premature
abstract: Cable & Wireless, Britain’s second-biggest phone company, said it has no immediate plans to sell or spin off its businesses after the Observer said the company might split itself in two. “Any discussion of spinning off our businesses is premature,” the company said Monday. Cable & Wireless is focused on building its British and international units and the strategy is “progressing well.”

headline: Hollinger Money Was Disclosed, Witness Says
abstract: Defense lawyers at the fraud trial of the former media baron Conrad M. Black produced documents on Monday that a prosecution witness agreed showed that payments at the heart of the case had been publicly disclosed.

headline: Google C.E.O. On Dealmaking Strategy
abstract: Google, which last month announced a deal to buy online ad firm DoubleClick for $3.1 billion, said that while it has become more comfortable doing big acquisitions, it still sees small technology deals as its primary thrust for buying businesses.

headline: McClatchy Draws Interest From Big Hedge Fund
abstract: A couple of days after an unusual spike in shares of McClatchy prompted talk — highly speculative talk — that the newspaper chain was a takeover target, there is another intriguing, though inconclusive, development.

headline: Masters of the New Universe
abstract: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

headline: Lehman to Buy Energy Services Firm
abstract: Lehman Brothers said it would acquire Eagle Energy Partners, a Houston-based energy services company, becoming the latest investment bank to bolster its presence in the physical energy markets. “Commodities over the last several years have become a very significant asset class,” Skip McGee, Lehman’s head of global investment banking, told MarketWatch.

headline: Cerberus Said to Consider Bid for Bell Canada
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is also circling.

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Another Swing at Topps
abstract: A New York hedge fund, Crescendo Partners, on Thursday alleged that certain Topps board members have conflicts of interest that prevent the trading card and confection company from negotiating in good faith with its rival, Upper Deck, on a potential acquisition.

headline: Apollo Seeks to Sell Stake to Investors
abstract: Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black. The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said. DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.

headline: Why Should A Sale Scare Wall Street?
abstract: Why Wall Street Fears A Real Market In Mortgage Securities

headline: Are Airline Bids Like Potato Chips?
abstract: Why did W. Douglas Parker, the chief executive of US Airways, launch a hostile bid for Delta Air Lines so soon after the merger of US Airways and America West? Partly “to maximize value,” he told Fortune magazine’s Barney Gimbel as he was awaiting a decision from Delta’s creditors’ committee in January. “But it’s also kind of fun, too.”

headline: Wall St. Lobby Firm Says It Investigated Former Co-Chief
abstract: Wall Street’s largest and most important trade association acknowledged Wednesday that one of its co-chief executives resigned abruptly earlier this year after an internal investigation uncovered loose financial management by him.

headline: Big Union Takes Skeptical Look at Private Equity
abstract: In Europe, private equity firms are accustomed to feeling the heat from unions. Now, the temperature is rising in the United States as well.

headline: Handicapping the Moguls
Hot Summer Box Office May Lift Theatre I.P.O.’s
abstract: An initial public offering from the movie theater operator Cinemark Holdings raised $532 million Monday, at the top of the range the company expected. That might set a good tone for Cinemark’s rival, AMC Entertainment, which hopes to raise $800 million in a stock sale next month.

headline: ABN Amro Agrees to Meet with New Suitors
abstract: A consortium of banks on Thursday accepted an invitation to hold merger talks with ABN Amro next week, even though the Dutch bank by then may have recommended a pact with Barclays to form the world’s fifth-largest bank.

headline: Teaching a Door New Tricks
abstract: I’ll wrap up my coverage of this year’s Modern Marvels Invent Now competition with one more of my favorites.

headline: To Win Alliance Boots, K.K.R. May Need More Honey
abstract: Celesio, owner of Lloyd’s Pharmacy, has emerged as a third potential bidder for Britain’s Alliance Boots. Celesio would be in competition with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Stefano Pessina, the deputy executive chairman of Alliance, who have already announced a $19.7 billion bid for Alliance, a chain of health and beauty stores.

headline: Eiffage Says Non to Spanish Bid
abstract: Eiffage, a French construction company, said its board had rejected a takeover bid of 6.6 billion euros ($9 billion) from a Spanish rival, Sacyr Vallehermoso, for the two-thirds of Eiffage it does not already own. Eiffage, which is based near Paris, challenged the strategic sense of the approach and accused Sacyr of violating merger rules by collaborating with other investors in making its bid.

headline: Private Equity Lobby Girds for Tax Fight
abstract: The private equity industry is not just sitting back and waiting for Congress to raise their taxes. The Private Equity Council, a less-than-year-old trade group representing many large buyout firms in the United States, has hired big guns from the lobbying world to defend their interests in Washington.

headline: A Deal To-Do List for Warren Buffett
abstract: After Warren Buffett said would “love” to find a $40 billion acquisition, BusinessWeek has put together its list of possible targets for the Berkshire Hathaway chieftain.

headline: Former Cendant Unit Affinion Files for I.P.O.
abstract: Affinion Group Holdings, a marketing-services business that the private equity firm Apollo Management bought from Cendant in 2005, filed to raise as much as $600 million in an initial public offering.

headline: 8-Year Sentence in Coca-Cola Secrets Case
abstract: A former secretary at Coca-Cola was sentenced Wednesday to eight years in prison for conspiring to steal trade secrets from the company, as her tearful plea for mercy failed to sway a federal judge. Judge J. Owen Forrester of Federal District Court told the former secretary, Joya Williams, 42, that he was giving her a longer sentence than recommended by federal prosecutors and sentencing guidelines because “this is the kind of offense that cannot be tolerated in our society.”

headline: Starwood C.E.O.’s Ouster Sparks Buyout Rumors
abstract: The ouster of Steven Heyer as chief executive of Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide came as a surprise to analysts, who said that the company’s strategy was sound. Of course, the news also prompted many to consider whether Starwood was a viable buyout candidate.

headline: Ivy Owner Sells Pizza Chain to Blackstone Firm
abstract: Richard Caring, the millionaire owner of the British celebrity haunt The Ivy, has sold off his Strada pizza chain for 140 million pounds ($277 million), less than a month after buying a 3 percent stake in the Carluccio‘s restaurant chain, prompting speculation that he could bid for the company.

headline: Law Firm Preps for Private Equity Flameouts
abstract: Amid concerns that the recent buyout boom could take an ugly turn, yet another law firm is gearing up to be in the right place at the right time if and when it does. O’Melveny & Myers said Thursday that it hired a trio of bankruptcy specialists and the co-chair of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan‘s restructuring practice in preparation for portfolio company blowups involving its private equity and distressed-debt fund clients.

headline: Black’s New York Pad Worth Triple What He Paid, Witness Says
abstract: A New York real estate appraiser testified Tuesday in the federal fraud trial of Conrad Black that the Manhattan apartment bought by the former media baron in 2000 had a market value nearly three times the $3 million he paid the newspaper company for it.

headline: Journal Reporters Start Anti-News Corp. Campaign
abstract: Hoping to fend off the News Corporation‘s $5 billion bid, employees at Dow Jones & Company are pushing back. Jesse Drucker, a Wall Street Journal reporter and representative of the paper’s union, has written an e-mail to his colleagues, asking them to write short letters to three members of the Bancroft family, which controls more than 60 percent of Dow Jones.

headline: Duff & Phelps Plans $200 Million I.P.O.
abstract: Duff & Phelps, a financial advisory firm and investment bank, said it plans to raise up to $200 million in an initial public offering of stock on the New York Stock Exchange. The New York-based firm has grown through a series of acquisitions in recent years, including the purchase of Standard & Poor’s Corporate Value Consulting business in 2005 and Chanin Capital Partners, a boutique investment bank with a large restructuring practice, in 2006.

headline: Salesforce.com Boosts Web Offerings with Koral Purchase
abstract: Salesforce.com, best known for its hosted sales applications, is pushing into Web content management. The company on Tuesday expects to detail new products and the acquisition of start-up Koral, which created a Web content management service tied to Salesforce.com. Terms of the purchase of Koral, a nine-person firm based in San Mateo, Calif., which first launched its product last fall, were not disclosed.

headline: AstraZeneca C.F.O. Leaves for Goldman Post
abstract: The British drugmaker AstraZeneca on Wednesday said its chief financial officer, Jon Symonds, is quitting after 10 years, opting for an investment-banking post instead. Mr. Symonds is leaving AstraZeneca in July, and in September he will become a managing director at Goldman Sachs.

headline: “Geek” Schedule
abstract: This past weekend marked the broadcast debut of my Science Channel show, “It’s All Geek to Me.” Thanks to everyone who tuned in! (*Especially* those of you with Nielsen meters.)

headline: BHP Billiton Selects a Chief Executive
abstract: BHP Billiton, the mining company, chose the head of its copper and aluminum division, Marius Kloppers, to succeed its American chief executive, Charles W. Goodyear, when Mr. Goodyear steps down Oct. 1.

headline: G.E. and NBC Launch $250 Million Media Fund
abstract: General Electric is launching a $250 million equity fund to invest in media and technology companies, part of a broader push by traditional media companies to get into hot areas such as digital advertising or social networks.

headline: Space Shuttle Supplier Denies Sales Rumors
abstract: MacDonald Dettwiler, a Canadian firm that makes components for the Space Shuttle, has denied reports that it is in talks to sell its surveillance and space business, but that hasn’t seemed to quash analysts’ speculation.

headline: Ex-Chief of Chip Maker May Lose Proxy Fight
abstract: The former chief executive of Atmel, George Perlegos, appears unlikely to win back control of his company on Friday when his plan to replace five board members goes before shareholders, according to The San Jose Mercury News.

headline: Worth a Lot, but Are Hedge Funds Worth It?
abstract: When Institutional Investor’s Alpha magazine released its annual list of the highest paid hedge fund managers last month, the eye-popping sums caused grumblings among some investors about the high fees that hedge fund managers are collecting.

headline: Where Will Zell Lead The Los Angeles Times?
abstract: Now that Samuel Zell has won Tribune, is he planning to sell off The Los Angeles Times? That question was on industry observers’ minds after Mr. Zell and his wife, Helen, dined Friday with Hollywood mogul David Geffen, who has for some time now been angling to gain control of the newspaper.

headline: High-Tech Offerings Make a Comeback
abstract: The window for public offerings is slowly beginning to open after largely being closed to technology companies since the double whammy of the dot-com downturn and the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, which imposed expensive accounting responsibilities on public companies, The New York Times writes.

headline: Black Defense Says Payments Were Backed by Board
abstract: Defense lawyers at the criminal fraud trial of the media baron Conrad M. Black sought to show on Wednesday that millions of dollars of payments received by Mr. Black and his co-defendants were approved by the board of his former company. Prosecutors contend that Mr. Black and three former executives diverted some $60 million from the media conglomerate, Hollinger International, by sending the payments to entities closely controlled by Mr. Black.

headline: Adviser Backs Icahn for Motorola Board
abstract: Carl Icahn is on a roll. Building on a string of successful efforts to push for change at various companies, the billionaire financier has won the endorsement of an influential advisory firm in his face-off with Motorola. Institutional Shareholder Services, which gives voting recommendations to institutional investors, on Wednesday urged the cellphone company’s shareholders to elect Mr. Icahn as a director — despite Motorola’s ardent desire to keep him out of the boardroom.

headline: Icahn Takes Stake in Anadarko
abstract: Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire investor, has purchased a big stake in Anadarko Petroleum, according to regulatory filings, suggesting the billionaire investor is betting on further consolidation in the oil services sector. Icahn Management, one of Icahn’s investment vehicles, took a stake of about 3.1 million shares in Anadarko, worth about $133.5 million as of March 31, the filing said Tuesday.

headline: Dow Jones Shares Surge on Bancroft News
abstract: Dow Jones & Company‘s stock is off and running.

headline: CVC Calls Off Sainsbury Offer
abstract: The bidding for J Sainsbury came to an end on Wednesday, as CVC Capital Partners called off the 10 billion pound ($19.7 billion) bid for the British grocer after failing to meet the founding family’s desired price. Though CVC offered the board 582 pence a share, the family, which holds about 18 percent of the retailer, wanted at least 600 pence a share.

headline: Fremont General to Sell Loan Business
abstract: Fremont General said Monday that it had found a buyer for most of its home loan business, suggesting that the struggling lender might have found a way out of the troubled subprime mortgage industry. Its stock surged more than 25 percent.

headline: G.M. to Help Delphi Exit Bankruptcy, Report Says
abstract: General Motors and bankrupt auto parts maker Delphi are “very close” to a deal with the United Auto Workers union that would help the supplier emerge from bankruptcy, Reuters reported citing an unnamed source.

headline: A new art to F1 photography
abstract: Did anyone notice fewer photos of the winning team in the press after Ferrari won the Bahrain Grand Prix last Sunday? I did. But it’s no surprise. The job of photographer and photo editor has become exponentially more difficult this season as all of the teams except Ferrari have ceased to use tobacco sponsorship. Bahrain was the first race of the season at which Ferrari chose to display the name of its tobacco sponsor. It is not only the tobacco companies and the teams – except Ferrari and its sponsor – who have decided to fall in line with legislation that is quickly expanding worldwide against tobacco sponsorship, it is also much of the print media – although not so much television. So it is that many newspapers and magazines no longer use images of cars with tobacco sponsors. Moreover, it is clear to me that Ferrari’s very occasional use of its tobacco sponsor’s name and logo this year is actually going to seriously backfire against Ferrari, its tobacco sponsor and Formula One in general. It has already started.

headline: Advanced Semiconductor’s Shares Rise After Carlye Drops Bid
abstract: The market cheered the withdrawal of the Carlyle Group‘s $5.5 billion bid for the world’s largest computer-chip tester, Advanced Semiconductor Engineering. The announcement late Tuesday night that the buyout shop had abandoned its bid sent Advanced Semiconductor’s shares up 7 percent.

headline: G.E. Kicks Off Soccer Partnership
abstract: General Electric said that its commercial finance division has teamed up with Hermes Sports Partners, a sports finance advisory boutique in London, to help finance soccer club buyouts and other deals related to the sport. G.E. has already helped the Texas oil magnate Malcolm Glazer finance his 790 million pound ($1.6 billion) acquisition in 2005 of Manchester United.

headline: For Citi, Old Lane Could Mark New Strategy
abstract: Amid reports that Citigroup may buy the hedge fund Old Lane, The Financial Times writes that Citi’s chief executive, Charles Prince, once dismissed the notion of acquiring a hedge fund manager as the “flavor of the moment.” Breakingviews suggests Old Lane could bring both financial and personnel headaches for Citi.

headline: Convictions of Samsung Executives Upheld
abstract: An appeals court on Tuesday upheld the conviction of two senior executives at the Samsung Group on charges that they helped the only son of its reclusive chairman, Lee Kun Hee, inherit control of Samsung, the country’s largest conglomerate.

headline: One Investor’s Dow Jones Dream: $100 Per Share
abstract: Many Wall Street analysts are still gaping over the $5 billion unsolicited bid that Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation made for Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal. At $60 per share, it was 67 percent above the company’s recent stock price and represented a multiple of about 16 times Dow Jones’s projected 2007 Ebitda. (Other recent newspaper deals have come in at about eight times Ebitda.) A former financial adviser to the Bancroft family, which controls Dow Jones, has called the bid “absolutely, insanely high.”

headline: Blockbuster Unloads U.K. Chain
abstract: Bockbuster, the No. 1 U.S. movie retail chain, said on Wednesday it had sold its British video game retailer, Game Station, to Game Group of Britain for $150 million. The move is part of Blockbuster’s ongoing efforts to sell off non-core assets and some international operations, while it heightens Game Group’s presence in the British market.

headline: Defending the Orbitz I.P.O.
abstract: A number of analysts and industry watchers are predicting that Orbitz Worldwide‘s $750 million initial public offering will end in tears, as DealBook noted Friday. Among the reasons that detractors think the online travel site’s I.P.O. will flop are its complex financial arrangements with its parent, Travelport, as well as the company’s history of losses.

headline: In Deal for Reuters, Thomson Continues Its Evolution
abstract: The Thomson Corp.’s $17.2 billion acquisition of the Reuters Group, the global news and financial data service, comes in the middle of an information revolution as easy distribution over the Internet has turned news and data into a commodity. Media companies, including newspapers, cable companies and financial publishers, are all struggling to turn their content into new services that their customers are willing to pay for.

headline: Morgan Stanley Fund Said to Approach $8 Billion
abstract: Morgan Stanley is reportedly close to completing fundraising for an $8 billion real estate investment fund, The Financial Times reported. It would be the securities firm’s largest real estate fund to date. The newspaper said that 40 percent of the investment bank’s sixth real estate fund will be invested in Japan. The fund is expected to close as early as next month amid strong demand from mostly non-Japanese investors, the Financial Times said.

headline: The Trillion-Dollar Question: What Are Hedge Funds?
abstract: As Monday brought reports that Citigroup is pursuing a deal to buy a hedge fund, Old Lane, New York magazine observes that many otherwise well-informed people are still not entirely clear on what, exactly, a hedge fund is. For these people, the magazine’s latest cover story offers a refreshingly simple (but long) introduction to hedge funds, as well as a few voyeuristic sidebars about fund managers’ spending and marrying habits. One of the article’s best passages is this pithy definition of a hedge fund from Cliff Asness of AQR Capital:

headline: China Citic Bank Starts With a Surge
abstract: Shares in the China Citic Bank rose 21 percent in their Hong Kong debut and surged more than 59 percent in Shanghai on Friday during its $5.4 billion offering, the world’s largest this year.

headline: Blackstone Holds Firm on I.P.O. Price
abstract: Last week’s surprise out of Washington — a bill that could jack up the tax rate for publicly traded private equity firms — does not seem to be much of a concern for the Blackstone Group‘s underwriters. Or Fortress Investment Group‘s shareholders, for that matter.

headline: When Labor and Private Equity Shake Hands
abstract: Who says buyout firms and unions can’t be friends?

headline: Private Equity Firm Seeks to Block Imax Filing Delay
abstract: Shares of Imax fell nearly 10 percent Monday after a private equity fund manager said it was seeking support from other bondholders to oppose the giant screen maker’s bid for more time to file its 2006 financial results. The Catalyst Capital Group of Toronto said in a statement that it is organizing opposition to Imax’s move to seek consent from bondholders for a waiver from certain financial reporting defaults.

headline: K.K.R. Hires Bankers for a Potential I.P.O.
abstract: Even as the Blackstone Group prepared to price its initial public offering Thursday night amid heightened scrutiny from Washington, one of its major rivals was considering stepping into the limelight. Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has hired Morgan Stanley and Citigroup to prepare a possible I.P.O. later this year, people familiar with the matter told DealBook. The news was first reported by CNBC’s Charles Gasparino.

headline: Walgreen to Buy Operator of In-Store Health Clinics
abstract: Walgreen said Wednesday that it planned to buy Take Care Health Systems, which operates in-store health clinics, as it moves to offer more patient services in its drugstores. The terms of the all-cash deal, which is expected to close next week, were not disclosed.

headline: HowStuffWorks Raises $75 Million
abstract: HowStuffWorks, an informational Web site for the mechanically minded, said it closed a new $75 million funding round that included investors Capital Research & Management and Chilton Investment Company. Billionaire financier Carl Icahn also participated in the round, The Deal said.

headline: Carlyle to Hire Coca-Cola’s Top Asia Executive
abstract: The Carlyle Group is expected to announce on Monday the hiring of Coca-Cola‘s most senior executive in Asia to spearhead regional investments across consumer-related businesses. The recruitment of the executive, Patrick Siewert, Coca-Cola’s chief operating officer for Asia-Pacific, is the second such hiring in recent weeks by the buyout firm and highlights the maturing of private equity in Asia.

headline: British Airways Signs Onto Iberia Bidding Group
abstract: British Airways said Tuesday it had joined a consortium led by a private equity firm, the Texas Pacific Group, that is considering a bid for Spain’s Iberia airline. British Airways is Iberia’s largest shareholder, with a 10 percent stake, and some analysts saw the move as an attempt to retain some influence over Iberia.

headline: Punishing Court Day for Black’s Ex-Deputy
abstract: F. David Radler, the chief witness against the media baron Conrad M. Black, endured more withering cross-examination on Thursday, and was again called a liar before a federal jury hearing the case against Mr. Black and others accused of stealing millions from the publishing company Hollinger International.

headline: Northwest Creditors Approve Reorganization Plan
abstract: Taking another step toward leaving bankruptcy, Northwest Airlines said a majority of its creditors has approved its reorganization plan. Based on its unofficial count, 97 percent of the creditors that voted approved Northwest’s plan, the airline said.

headline: PNC Financial Acquires a New Jersey Bank for $403 Million
abstract: The PNC Financial Services Group said Thursday it would pay $403 million to acquire the Yardville National Bancorp a central New Jersey bank.

headline: BA Shares Rise as Buyout Rumors Mount
abstract: Shares of British Airways, Europe’s third-largest airline, rose the most in almost a year on speculation the carrier might attract a private-equity bid, Bloomberg News reported Monday. Shares of the airline advanced as much as 22.5 pence, or 4.9 percent, to 483.5 pence, the biggest gain since June 15, 2006 at midday.

headline: Wells Fargo’s New C.E.O. on Deals and Buffett
abstract: Analysts said that the sudden promotion of John G. Stumpf, Wells Fargo‘s chief operating officer, to chief executive, signaled that the bank would probably continue to focus on increasing sales in its core markets in the West rather than merging with an East Coast partner like Wachovia or SunTrust, as many on Wall Street have advocated for years.

headline: Former Top UBS Banker Jumps to Distressed Investing
abstract: After 23 years advising companies on how to spend millions on takeovers, Jeffrey A. McDermott, the former co-head of investment banking at UBS, is setting up a private equity firm that focuses on buying companies in trouble.

headline: Citigroup Listens and Listens to Holders
abstract: Companies are increasingly being urged to listen more closely to shareholders. There could be such a thing as too much. In sharp contrast to the Home Depot annual meeting last May that investors decried as unresponsive, Citigroup‘s session yesterday dragged on, writes The New York Times’ Eric Dash. And on. And on.

headline: McClatchy Draws Interest From Big Hedge Fund
abstract: A couple of days after an unusual spike in shares of McClatchy prompted talk — highly speculative talk — that the newspaper chain was a takeover target, there is another intriguing, though inconclusive, development.

headline: Masters of the New Universe
abstract: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

headline: Lehman to Buy Energy Services Firm
abstract: Lehman Brothers said it would acquire Eagle Energy Partners, a Houston-based energy services company, becoming the latest investment bank to bolster its presence in the physical energy markets. “Commodities over the last several years have become a very significant asset class,” Skip McGee, Lehman’s head of global investment banking, told MarketWatch.

headline: Cerberus Said to Consider Bid for Bell Canada
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is also circling.

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Another Swing at Topps
abstract: A New York hedge fund, Crescendo Partners, on Thursday alleged that certain Topps board members have conflicts of interest that prevent the trading card and confection company from negotiating in good faith with its rival, Upper Deck, on a potential acquisition.

headline: Apollo Seeks to Sell Stake to Investors
abstract: Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black. The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said. DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.

headline: Why Should A Sale Scare Wall Street?
abstract: Why Wall Street Fears A Real Market In Mortgage Securities

headline: Are Airline Bids Like Potato Chips?
abstract: Why did W. Douglas Parker, the chief executive of US Airways, launch a hostile bid for Delta Air Lines so soon after the merger of US Airways and America West? Partly “to maximize value,” he told Fortune magazine’s Barney Gimbel as he was awaiting a decision from Delta’s creditors’ committee in January. “But it’s also kind of fun, too.”

headline: Wall St. Lobby Firm Says It Investigated Former Co-Chief
abstract: Wall Street’s largest and most important trade association acknowledged Wednesday that one of its co-chief executives resigned abruptly earlier this year after an internal investigation uncovered loose financial management by him.

headline: Big Union Takes Skeptical Look at Private Equity
abstract: In Europe, private equity firms are accustomed to feeling the heat from unions. Now, the temperature is rising in the United States as well.

headline: Amid iPhone Buzz, AT&T Does a Deal
abstract: For 1.7 million cellphone users, getting an iPhone just got a little bit easier.

headline: Alibaba.com of China Said to Plan I.P.O.
abstract: Alibaba.com, China’s leading e-commerce company, is planning to go public later this year in what could be the biggest initial public offering ever for a Chinese Internet company, The New York Times reported, citing people briefed on the deal. Three Wall Street investment banks, Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and Deutsche Bank, are advising Alibaba on the public offering, which The Times said could raise $1 billion.

headline: KPMG Resigns as New Century Auditor
abstract: KPMG has quit as auditor of the bankrupt subprime lender New Century Financial, which has hired forensic accountants to investigate how the company valued its stake in mortgage-backed bonds.

headline: Baron Guy de Rothschild Dies at 98
abstract: Baron Guy de Rothschild, the patriarch of the French branch of the famous banking dynasty who rebuilt and expanded its Paris bank after it was seized during World War II and then saw it survive another government takeover in the 1980s, died Tuesday in Paris. He was 98.

headline: Goldman and SBI Team Up for Japan Venture
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group and Japanese venture capital firm SBI Holdings have agreed to form a joint venture to provide growth capital to mid-sized companies Japan and overseas. SBI said Goldman would buy a 40 percent stake in its subsidiary SBI Capital for an undisclosed sum, and the venture would aim to manage 100 billion yen ($825 million) in assets within three years.

headline: Blackstone to Acquire Alliance Data
abstract: Blackstone Capital Partners said on Thursday it would buy Alliance Data Systems, a provider of transaction, credit and marketing services, for $7.8 billion including debt. It will pay $81.75 per share in cash, which it said was a premium of about 30 percent over Alliance Data’s closing share price of $62.96 on May 16 on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Subprime Mortgage Giant New Century Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: Once a highflier in the booming market for making risky mortgage loans, New Century Financial tumbled to earth Monday as it filed for bankruptcy. In the largest bankruptcy to date in the subprime arena, New Century listed liabilities of more than $100 million in its Chapter 11 filing with the federal bankruptcy court in Wilmington, Del.

headline: Hedge Fund Manager’s Comments Irk Macquarie
abstract: At a charity event in New York last week, during which some of the biggest names in hedge funds offered investment advice, James Chanos, the short seller who catapulted to fame by questioning Enron, offered the Macquarie Bank, the Australian financial group, as a stock that might be in for a fall. He even drew some comparisons between Enron and Macquarie, which has raised a lot of big investment funds that it used to buy assets and sell them to related entities.

headline: WiMax Start-Up Picks Up $50 Million from V.C.’s
abstract: A WiMax equipment startup, Telsima, announced a new $50 million Series D round of venture funding that will bankroll the company’s expansion plans in India and Eastern Europe. Telsima, which makes WiMax-based broadband wireless access technology, received the money from its initial investor syndicate, which includes NewPath Ventures, New Enterprise Associates, CMEA Ventures, and Intel Capital.

headline: Q&A: Ask About iPod Pricing
abstract: The authors of a study that tries to figure out the source, and cost, of the parts that go into an iPod will be answering questions here.

headline: Kerkorian’s Vegas Moves Ignite Talk of MGM Deal
abstract: What is Kirk Kerkorian up to now?

headline: Web Measurement Firm ComScore to Go Public
abstract: ComScore, one of the leading companies that measures Web traffic, filed Monday to raise as much as $86.2 million in an initial public offering. Backed by the venture firm Accel Partners, which owns a 27 percent stake, comScore said it plans to use the proceeds for working capital, capital expenditures and possibly for acquisitions. ComScore, which competes with measurement firms such as NetRatings and Hitwise, reported $66.3 million in revenue in 2006. It said one customer, Microsoft, accounted for 12 percent of those revenues.

headline: Treehouse Buys Private Food Manufacturer
abstract: The E. D. Smith Income Fund, a trust that owns a variety of private-label food manufacturing operations, said it planned to sell all of its assets to TreeHouse Foods of the United States in a deal valued at about C$217 million ($203 million).

headline: Biovail C.E.O. Sues Former Analyst for Slander
abstract: The founder of Biovail, the Canadian pharmaceutical company, has filed a $1 million slander suit against a former Banc of America Securities analyst, claiming he was defamed when the analyst called him a “criminal,” The New York Post reported Tuesday. The Biovail founder, Eugene Melnyk, claimed he “suffered serious injury to his personal and professional reputation” as a result of comments made by the former analyst, Jerry Treppel.

headline: EMI Accepts $4.7 Billion Bid From Terra Firma
abstract: The EMI Group, the British music giant that has drawn heavy takeover interest in the last year, said Monday it had agreed to be bought by Terra Firma, the private equity firm led by the financier Guy Hands. EMI, whose recent talks with another buyout firm, Permira, ended without a deal, said it was recommending Terra Firma’s offer to its shareholders. The bid values EMI at 2.4 billion pounds ($4.7 billion).

headline: Mission: Acquirable? Breaking the Code
abstract: By PETER EDMONSTON

headline: Fried Frank Adds M&A Partner
abstract: Fried Frank Harris Shriver & Jacobson, one of the law firms advising Dow Jones as it considers a takeover bid from News Corporation, said Friday it hired a new corporate partner for its mergers and acquisitions practice. John E. Sorkin, previously a partner at Latham & Watkins, joins Fried Frank in its New York office.

headline: Dow Chemical: The First $50 Billion L.B.O.?
abstract: A consortium of Middle Eastern investors and American buyout firms is reportedly preparing a $50 billion bid for the Dow Chemical Company in what could be the biggest leveraged buyout ever. According to The Sunday Express, a financing package has been put in place for a break-up bid of between $52 and $58 a share and a formal offer valuing the company at at least $50 billion could come by the end of this week.

headline: CanWest’s Alliance Deal Under Fire
abstract: The unitholders of the Movie Distribution Income Fund are going to court in a bid to halt CanWest‘s purchase of Alliance Atlantis Communications until they are given a say in who their Canadian partner will be, The Globe and Mail reported.

headline: Saudi Prince to Offer His Kingdom to the Public
abstract: Kingdom Holding, the Saudi Arabian investment firm owned by billionaire Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, plans to sell a 3.15 billion-riyal ($840 million) stake in an initial public offering.

headline: How Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg Shames Terry Semel
abstract: Terry Semel failed more than any other reason, of course, because he didn’t respond properly to the challenge of Google. Number two on Mr. Semel’s list of failures, however, is he didn’t respond properly to the challenge of Facebook.

headline: A Refresher Course in English
abstract: Oh, lordy, how long I’ve been waiting for this!

headline: Western Digital to Pay $1 Billion for Komag
abstract: In a $1 billion cash deal, Western Digital said late Thursday it plans to purchase Komag a San Jose, Calif.-based media manufacturer. Western Digital, a hard drive maker, will pay $32.25 per share through a cash tender offer and also pay down $220 million in debt issued by Komag in March that is due in 2014.

headline: ICE Steps Up Battle Ahead of Exchange Merger Vote
abstract: IntercontinentalExchange on Monday commenced its proxy battle to block the merger of Chicago Board of Trade Holdings with Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings, urging C.B.O.T. shareholders to vote against the deal.

headline: Who Buys This Stock?
abstract: Who Buys Universal Services stock?

headline: Altadis Is Said to Reject Imperial Tobacco’s Revised Bid
abstract: The board of Altadis is preparing to reject a revised bid from Imperial Tobacco, its British rival, that could come as early as this week, the Telegraph reported. Altadis, a Franco-Spanish tobacco group, is being courted by a number of private equity groups, a development that is thought to be behind the board’s decision to reject Imperial’s bid.

headline: Murdoch’s Bid for Dow Jones: Reading Between the Lines
abstract: The headline number is eye-catching, but the logic behind Rupert Murdoch’s $5 billion offer for Dow Jones & Company may be even more interesting. Mr. Murdoch’s News Corporation already has an array of broadcasting, film, print and Internet assets. What does he want with Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal?

headline: D.E. Shaw to Buy Insurer in ‘Take-Under’
abstract: The James River Group, an insurance company that went public two years ago, said Monday it had agreed to be acquired by D.E. Shaw & Company, a hedge-fund firm, for $575 million. At $34.50 a share, D.E. Shaw’s offer did not come with a premium to Friday’s closing share price for $35.18; it was nearly 2 percent below it.

headline: Extradition of Former Comverse Chief Delayed in Namibia
abstract: Lawyers for Jacob Alexander, the former chief executive of Comverse Technologies, who faces charges of options fraud and is regarded as a fugitive, won a fresh delay Wednesday of attempts to extradite him to the United States.

headline: U.S. Attorney Charges Pakistani Banker with Insider Trading
abstract: Federal prosecutors on Tuesday charged a high-profile investment banker in Pakistan with taking part in a $7.5 million insider-trading scheme that they say was run by a former Credit Suisse banker. In a new complaint filed in federal district court in Manhattan, the United States attorney’s office accused Ajaz Rahim, the former head of Faysal Bank Limited, of profiting from confidential information fed to him by Hafiz Mohammed Zubair Naseem, at the time a junior associate in Credit Suisse’s energy team.

headline: Philadelphia Inquirer Owner Casts Eye on Dow Jones
abstract: Another investor has expressed interest in the idea of putting together a rival bid for Dow Jones, the family-controlled publishing company that is fielding a $5 billion takeover offer from Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation.

headline: Board Divided on Renewing Contract for Siemens Chief
abstract: Klaus Kleinfeld’s future as the chief executive of Siemens, the scandal-ridden engineering giant, was left hanging Tuesday as the company’s supervisory board wavered over the extension of his contract.

headline: British Buyout Chief Questions Industry Tax Break
abstract: Like their counterparts in the Unites States, European private equity firms are facing criticism for the relatively low taxes they pay on “carried interest,” which makes up the bulk of income for buyout fund managers. A leading figure in the industry, Nicholas Ferguson, has “broken the sector’s taboo on tax,” as the Financial Times puts it, making the observation that he and his cohorts “pay less tax than a cleaning lady.” (We’re not sure what his cleaning lady earns, but we assume he means a lower tax rate, not a lower dollar figure.)

headline: Buyout Firms Said to Consider Virgin Media Bid
abstract: Providence Equity Partners is leading a group that is considering a $15 billion bid for Virgin Media, the cable company in which Sir Richard Branson is the largest shareholder, The Observer reported Monday. The United States-based private equity firm is said to be speaking with its partners, including Blackstone, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Cinven, about the possibility of making an approach in the coming weeks.

headline: Airvana Files for I.P.O.
abstract: Mobile broadband technology start-up Airvana on Thursday filed to raise as much as $75 million in a proposed initial public offering. The maker of hardware and software for high-speed networks is backed by Qualcomm, Matrix Partners, Commvest, and Sycamore Networks Chairman Gururaj Deshpande.

headline: Losses Narrow at Trump Casinos, but Buyers Remain Elusive
abstract: With its three Atlantic City casinos being eyed by potential buyers, Trump Entertainment Resorts said Thursday that its first-quarter loss shrank, despite increasing competition from slot-machine parlors in Philadelphia and New York. Perhaps more worrisome news is that potential white knights have yet to materialize.

headline: Hefty Maker Buys Rival for $1 Billion
abstract: Pactiv, maker of the Hefty brand line of plastic bags, said Thursday it has agreed to pay $1 billion to acquire closely held Prairie Packaging, a maker of disposable tableware. Prairie, with five U.S. manufacturing facilities, employs 1,200 people and is expected to generate revenue this year of about $500 million, Pactiv said.

headline: 3i to Invest in Hedge Fund Administrator
abstract: 3i, the private equity firm, said Friday that it has invested $57 million in Fulcrum, a hedge fund administrator, through its Growth Capital division. As part of the deal, Akshaya Bhargava of 3i will become Fulcrum’s chief executive. The private equity firm said that its investment will help Fulcrum expand its ability to administer to hedge funds’ back-end operations, as well as broaden its reach to funds in Europe and Asia.

headline: Senate Bill Threatens to Derail Private Equity I.P.O.’s
abstract: Senate legislation would force Blackstone Group to pay taxes as a corporation instead of as a partnership after 2012, a move that may threaten the buyout firm’s initial public offering later this month.

headline: Like Buffett, Icahn’s Working on the Railroads
abstract: Carl C. Icahn has bought a $122 million stake in CSX, joining Warren Buffett and TCI Fund Management in purchasing railroad shares. Mr. Icahn held 2.68 million shares of Jacksonville, Fla.-based CSX, the nation’s third-largest railroad, as of March 31, according to filings Tuesday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Mr. Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway and hedge fund TCI also detailed their purchases in the industry, which they disclosed in the past month.

headline: Barclays Would Slash Jobs at ABN Amro, Report Says
abstract: Barclays is planning to make cost cuts of more than 3 billion pounds in its proposed merger with ABN Amro, the Dutch bank. The move will likely lead to the loss of hundreds of jobs at ABN Amro’s investment banking operations in London, the Telegraph reported.

headline: Are Online Pet Stores Gaining New Allure?
abstract: Break out that sock puppet. Investors are backing online pet stores again.

headline: Mexico: Chief of Drug Intelligence Shot and Killed
abstract: Gunmen killed José Nemesio Lugo, a veteran government intelligence officer and the new chief of the National Center for Analysis, Planning and Information to Combat Crime, a unit of the attorney general’s office that gathers and analyzes intelligence on organized criminal organizations, including drug traffickers. He was appointed to the post just a month ago.

headline: An Entrepreneur Makes Death a Business
abstract: J. Robert Hillier is turning his attention from the design company he started 40 years ago to a venture that runs obituaries of people, pets and even inanimate objects.

headline: Germany: Labor Deal at Deutsche Telekom
abstract: Deutsche Telekom agreed with the Ver.di union on terms to transfer 50,000 workers to jobs that pay less, paving the way to end five weeks of strikes at the company.

headline: Tip of the Week: Undoing Changes in Microsoft Word
abstract: Want to undo a whole bunch of changes in a Microsoft Word document — without having to repeatedly hit Control-Z (Command-Z on the Mac) to back up one change at a time?

headline: 7 Children Killed in Airstrike in Afghanistan
abstract: The death of the children may well add to the crescendoing anger many Afghans feel about civilian casualties from American and NATO military operations.

headline: The Greatest Mystery: Making a Best Seller
abstract: The advance is usually the estimate of the first year's royalties. It's often wrong.

headline: Finding a Hassle-Free Way to Transfer Files
abstract: In a pinch, David Pogue re-discovered Pando, a Web-based file-sharing program.

headline: Hamas Forces Seize Control Over Much of Gaza
abstract: The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, faces the collapse of Fatah power in Gaza and a putative Palestinian state divided between Fatah and Hamas.

headline: Talks Under Way Over Sunni Official Named in Warrant
abstract: An arrest warrant for the Iraqi culture minister continued to draw fire from some Sunni Arab leaders, and negotiations were under way to review the investigation.

headline: Read Fortune’s ‘Portfolio’ or Portfolio’s ‘Fortune’
abstract: Last week two rival business magazines — Fortune and Portfolio — saw their names bump up against each other a bit.

headline: Marketers Are Joining the Varsity
abstract: Marketing and media companies are now capitalizing on consumer interest in high school sports and becoming big boosters of them.

headline: Zambia: Ex-President Told to Repay Stolen Millions
abstract: A British judge delivered what some experts called a signal verdict against African corruption, ordering the former Zambian president Frederick Chiluba, left, and 19 others to return at least $46 million it said they had stolen while in power in the 1990s and early this decade. The London judge, Peter Smith, ruled that Mr. Chiluba, in power from 1991 to 2001, “was uniquely positioned to stop corruption” in government, but that he elected instead to join in it. Zambia’s government sued in London because it alleged that Mr. Chiluba and his associates had bought assets in Britain and elsewhere in Europe. Mr. Chiluba said in a statement that he did not recognize a British court’s authority in Zambian issues, arguing that the case circumvented Zambia’s justice system. Other African experts said the verdict, the first against a current or former head of state, could set an anticorruption precedent.

headline: Owner of Bell Canada in Talks to Go Private
abstract: BCE, Canada’s largest telecommunications company, is in discussions with KKR and three Canadian pension funds.

headline: A Little Company May Help Some Big Ones Grow Bigger
abstract: Cambridge Heart, a tiny maker of heart stress test equipment, could spur growth in the sluggish $6 billion market for implantable cardioverter defibrillators.

headline: Ex-Newsweek Editor to Join NBC as a Senior Vice President
abstract: Mark Whitaker was named senior vice president for news, a job that will make him the No. 2 executive in the network’s news division.

headline: Ivica Racan,  Former Croatian Premier, Is Dead at 63
abstract: While prime minister of Croatia, Mr. Racan rebuilt economic and trade ties with Europe following the civil wars of the 1990s.

headline: Keeping Early Retirees Afloat
abstract: Some of the nation’s biggest companies will announce a new program meant to make health insurance available to their former employees ages 55 to 64.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Accounts.

headline: McClatchy Draws Interest From Big Hedge Fund
abstract: A couple of days after an unusual spike in shares of McClatchy prompted talk — highly speculative talk — that the newspaper chain was a takeover target, there is another intriguing, though inconclusive, development.

headline: Masters of the New Universe
abstract: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

headline: Lehman to Buy Energy Services Firm
abstract: Lehman Brothers said it would acquire Eagle Energy Partners, a Houston-based energy services company, becoming the latest investment bank to bolster its presence in the physical energy markets. “Commodities over the last several years have become a very significant asset class,” Skip McGee, Lehman’s head of global investment banking, told MarketWatch.

headline: Cerberus Said to Consider Bid for Bell Canada
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is also circling.

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Another Swing at Topps
abstract: A New York hedge fund, Crescendo Partners, on Thursday alleged that certain Topps board members have conflicts of interest that prevent the trading card and confection company from negotiating in good faith with its rival, Upper Deck, on a potential acquisition.

headline: Apollo Seeks to Sell Stake to Investors
abstract: Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black. The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said. DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.

headline: Why Should A Sale Scare Wall Street?
abstract: Why Wall Street Fears A Real Market In Mortgage Securities

headline: Are Airline Bids Like Potato Chips?
abstract: Why did W. Douglas Parker, the chief executive of US Airways, launch a hostile bid for Delta Air Lines so soon after the merger of US Airways and America West? Partly “to maximize value,” he told Fortune magazine’s Barney Gimbel as he was awaiting a decision from Delta’s creditors’ committee in January. “But it’s also kind of fun, too.”

headline: Wall St. Lobby Firm Says It Investigated Former Co-Chief
abstract: Wall Street’s largest and most important trade association acknowledged Wednesday that one of its co-chief executives resigned abruptly earlier this year after an internal investigation uncovered loose financial management by him.

headline: Big Union Takes Skeptical Look at Private Equity
abstract: In Europe, private equity firms are accustomed to feeling the heat from unions. Now, the temperature is rising in the United States as well.

headline: Steakhouses Accept Offer
abstract: The Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group agreed to be bought by the Patina Restaurant Group for $94.6 million.

headline: Bush, Feeling Ill and Resting, Attracts Notice by Absence
abstract: A counselor to President Bush reported that the president had awakened “not feeling well to the stomach.”

headline: 3 Suspects Freed in London Transit Attacks
abstract: Two men and the widow of one of the bombers who carried out the 2005 attack were released without charge, while another man arrested a week ago remained in custody.

headline: Secret Prisons in 2 Countries Held Qaeda Suspects, Report Says
abstract: Investigators have confirmed the existence of clandestine C.I.A. prisons in Romania and Poland housing leading members of Al Qaeda.

headline: Italy: Terrorism Suspects Held in Italy and Britain
abstract: The authorities in Milan issued arrest warrants for nine men suspected of providing logistical and financial support to Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, North Africa’s most active terrorist group. By evening, at least two of the suspects were in Italian custody. British authorities made a separate arrest in North London as part of the sweep. The North African group, formerly the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat, claimed responsibility for the suicide bombings in Algiers in April that killed 33 people.

headline: 12 Guilty in Serbian Premier’s Death
abstract: PRISTINA, Kosovo, May 23 — A Serbian court found two former paramilitary police officers guilty of the assassination of Zoran Djindjic, the pro-reform prime minister who was gunned down in Belgrade in March 2003.

headline: Minky Viagra? Pfizer Doesn’t Want You to Understand It, Just Buy It
abstract: Pfizer has always straddled a line marketing Viagra, insisting that the drug treats a serious medical condition while promoting it with wink-and-a-nod ads.

headline: Afghanistan: Hostages Swapped for Taliban Body
abstract: The Taliban released four members of an Afghan medical team kidnapped and held hostage since March after the government handed over the body of the senior Taliban commander Mullah Dadullah, said Qayum Pukhla, the director of the health department in Kandahar. The four, a doctor, two nurses and a driver described as thin and frail, were quickly reunited with their families. Members of the Taliban said that the Afghan government handed over the body of Mullah Dadullah, killed in fighting last month, on Wednesday evening and that was why they released the four hostages. They said they had killed the fifth member of the team, a pharmacist, because the government did not hand over the commander’s body within the ultimatum set earlier this week.

headline: Nuclear Plant Owner Seeks Payment for Lost Production
abstract: The owner of an Ohio nuclear plant has asked its insurer to pay for two years of lost production because of corrosion that it called “unexpected and unforeseeable.”

headline: Recalling D-Day, Gates Urges a Stronger Alliance
abstract: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said that disagreements between the U.S. and France should not overshadow what the two nations had in common.

headline: Dow and S.& P. End the Week at Record Highs
abstract: It was a short but glorious week for the stock market, with both the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index closing on Friday at record highs.

headline: Banking Group Names Chief Executive
abstract: The Australia and New Zealand Banking Group hired Michael Smith, head of Asia for HSBC Holdings, as chief executive to drive expansion in Asia, where the bank plans to double investment. Mr. Smith, 50, who worked for HSBC for 29 years, succeeds John McFarlane, who ran the bank for a decade. “I’ve watched the Australian banks for a number of years and often wondered why they haven’t done more in Asia,” Mr. Smith said in an interview. ‘‘When a market like Australia becomes mature, you have to look for opportunities elsewhere and I really do feel there is a significant opportunity in Asia.”.

headline: Moving Web-Based Software Offline
abstract: Google will make applications like Gmail and Docs and Spreadsheets available offline, in a move that will challenge Microsoft.

headline: Japan: Consumer Prices Slow
abstract: Consumer prices fell at a slower pace in April, the government reported. Core consumer prices, which exclude fresh food, declined 0.1 percent from a year earlier. The measure of inflation fell 0.3 percent in March, the steepest drop in two years, matching the median estimate of 44 economists surveyed by Bloomberg News. Core prices in Tokyo, a harbinger of nationwide prices, were unchanged for a second month, also in line with economists’ expectations.

headline: In Fierce Competition, Google Finds Novel Ways to Feed Hiring Machine
abstract: Pizza parties, treasure hunts and programming contests are meant to create excitement around a company and impress potential recruits as young as college freshmen.

headline: Google Buys DoubleClick for $3.1 Billion
abstract: The sale gives Google access to DoubleClick’s software and its relationships with Web publishers and advertisers.

headline: The Hague: Bosnian Serb Wins Genocide Appeal
abstract: An appeals court of the United Nations war crimes tribunal overturned a 2005 conviction for complicity in genocide against a former Bosnian Serb officer, Vidoje Blagojevic, saying it had no proof that he had known of the “genocidal intent” of the perpetrators of the 1995 massacre of Muslims at Srebrenica and provided only logistical support. The court reduced his prison sentence to 15 years from 18, and upheld several related war crimes charges.

headline: For Advice on Pay, the New Money Turns to Wall Street
abstract: The new kings of Wall Street are turning to a small but influential group of pay consultants and lawyers for compensation advice.

headline: Central Bank Leaves Interest Rate Unchanged
abstract: Australia’s central bank kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged at a six-year high, giving policy makers time to study an inflation report later this month that may prompt an increase. The governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia left the overnight cash rate target at 6.25 percent for a fourth consecutive meeting after raising it a quarter percentage point in November.

headline: Very Young Populations Contribute to Strife, Study Concludes
abstract: In recent decades, most civil conflicts broke out in countries with youthful populations and autocratic rulers or weak democracies, according to a study.

headline: Ecuador: U.N. Declares Galápagos Endangered
abstract: The Galápagos Islands have been added to a list of endangered World Heritage sites maintained by the United Nations. The archipelago, home to a array of species that inspired Charles Darwin to form his theory of natural selection, has seen annual tourist visits grow to 120,000 from 40,000 in 1996. Introduced plants now outnumber native plants, according to a report prepared by naturalists for a United Nations committee that keeps track of cultural and natural sites of international significance. Altogether 29 out of 830 heritage <a href=

headline: Defense Rests in Trial of Ex-Qwest Chief
abstract: Joseph P. Nacchio, charged with insider trading, never took the stand on his own behalf.

headline: Stocks Rise as the Media Sector Is Rediscovered
abstract: Buoyed by reports of possible mergers and acquisitions, stocks surged last week, pushing the Dow Jones industrial average to another record close on Friday.

headline: South Africa Strike Foreshadows Political Contest
abstract: South Africa’s public-service unions, leading a nationwide strike, accuse President Thabo Mbeki of betraying the nation’s vast lower class.

headline: A High-End Remote for a High-Tech Life
abstract: A new universal remote is designed to be lord of the living room, and connects to a computer so consumers can set it up and maintain it themselves.

headline: A Good Summer to Leave the Car in the Garage
abstract: Retail prices for gasoline are projected to average $2.95 a gallon, compared with $2.84 last summer.

headline: United Nations to Help Lebanon Investigation
abstract: The Security Council approved a request from Lebanon’s prime minister to have the United Nations commission investigating the 2005 assassination of the former Lebanese prime minister, Rafik Hariri, help investigate last week’s killing of a legislator, Walid Eido. Mr. Eido died in an attack similar to the one that had killed Mr. Hariri, when a vehicle parked along the same road in Beirut blew up as his car passed. Like Mr. Hariri, Mr. Eido was opposed to past Syrian domination of Lebanon’s politics. Preliminary findings of the commission have implicated Syrian intelligence services in Mr. Hariri’s murder.

headline: Who Needs Pocket Change When You’ve Got Plastic?
abstract: Some credit card companies and banks speak of Gen P, or Generation Plastic: young spenders who are using debit or credit cards for most on-the-go purchases.

headline: With Help, Could Ethanol Be the Next Internet?
abstract: Many of the same venture capitalists who financed Internet companies in the 1990s are now financing alternative energy start-ups.

headline: Russia Tries to Save Polar Bears With Legal Hunt
abstract: Scientists, environmentalists and native villagers express hope that a legal hunt could rein in rampant poaching.

headline: IPod Audio at Home, Cleaned and Delivered to Speakers Near You
abstract: Creative Labs’ Xdock can play video and pictures on any TV through an S-video connection.

headline: Israel Reveals New Details of Allegations Against Ex-Lawmaker
abstract: Azmi Bishara, an Israeli Arab suspected of passing information to Hezbollah during the war waged against the Lebanese militia, could be charged with treason.

headline: G.E. and Pearson Decide Against Dow Jones Bid
abstract: Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation remains the sole bidder for the company, owner of The Wall Street Journal.

headline: An iPod Rival Can Browse the Net and Download Audio and Video
abstract: The Archos 605 Wi-Fi portable media player, which will be available later this summer, has a 4.3-inch touchscreen, built-in PDF and photo viewer.

headline: Iraqi Officials Say Top Qaeda Leader May Have Been Killed
abstract: Iraqi authorities are investigating reports that the alleged leader of Al-Qaeda in Mesopotamia, Abu Ayyub al-Masri, has been killed in a struggle within his own group.

headline: Ceridian Executive Is Fired
abstract: The Ceridian Corporation fired a top executive, accusing him of disclosing confidential information to a hedge fund that is trying to oust the company’s board.

headline: Technology Group Seeks to Save Power
abstract: Google and Intel are leading a consortium of companies in an effort to reduce the amount of power wasted by personal computers.

headline: Britain’s Private Equity Firms Try to Make the Case for Their Low Taxes
abstract: Executives from four large private equity firms went to Parliament and defended the low British tax rate imposed on their profits.

headline: The Loose Reins on U.S. Teenagers Can Produce Trouble or Entrepreneurs
abstract: The success of young entrepreneurs is rooted in the commercial, competitive, nonegalitarian and open nature of American society.

headline: Mubarak Meets Israel’s Foreign Minister
abstract: CAIRO, Egypt, May 10 — President Hosni Mubarak met with Israel’s foreign minister, Tzipi Livni, today and agreed that a team of Arab officials would soon visit Israel to discuss a peace proposal initiated by Saudi Arabia and endorsed by all members of the Arab League.

headline: Painting a Rosy Picture of a Costly Fighter Jet
abstract: Lockheed Martin’s $600 billion Joint Strike Fighter program is only now moving off the drawing board and into first flight.

headline: Voting Sets Up Left-Right Duel to Lead France
abstract: The presidential election is now a classic battle between two candidates with competing visions for France.

headline: At Creative Artists, a Bit of Blushing After a Corporate Kiss-Off
abstract: In the new Hollywood, agencies are finding it can be tougher to meet the needs of a corporate customer than to baby-sit for a temperamental star.

headline: Bush, on European Tour, Perfects the Art of Meet and Run
abstract: Being on the road with President Bush invariably invokes comparisons to that old movie “If It’s Tuesday, This Must Be Belgium.”

headline: Citigroup Listens and Listens to Holders
abstract: Companies are increasingly being urged to listen more closely to shareholders. There could be such a thing as too much.

headline: Flying This Summer? Fasten Your Seat Belt
abstract: Will this be the summer — when a peak travel season meets a tottering system — that finally breaks the poor camel’s back?

headline: Still Another View of Role of Panel Proposed for Wall St. Journal
