abstract: An independent committee would have the power to approve or reject the hiring and firing of top editors, contradicting what another person close to the talks has said.

headline: British Girl Sues  for Right to Wear Chastity Ring
abstract: The case offered a counterpoint to a broader discussion concerning Muslim women wearing the full-face veil.

headline: Away From the Set but Not Away From HDTV
abstract: Plextor has come out with its Mini Digital HDTV Receiver, which connects to a laptop’s U.S.B. port.

headline: Trying to Find the Upside After a Scandal
abstract: An insurance broker is trying to restore its image with an advertising campaign that urges readers to “find the upside.”

headline: Your Plate Is Bigger Than Your Stomach
abstract: The way choices are presented to people — whether it’s 401(k)’s or food — has a huge effect on the decisions they make.

headline: Saudis Round Up 172, Citing Plot Against Oil Rigs
abstract: Officials said a terrorist ring was planning to blow up oil installations and attack public officials and military posts.

headline: Macao Bank Challenges U.S. Ban as Politically Based
abstract: Banco Delta Asia, accused of committing financial crimes for North Korea, challenged a U.S. ruling that bars the bank from access to the U.S. financial system.

headline: One Crisis After Another, but Sony Shares Keep Surging
abstract: Despite a number of challenges, Sony has outperformed the Walt Disney Company, Time Warner and Comcast over the past two years.

headline: How Diversity Makes a Team Click
abstract: Move beyond the idea of cultural differences as a barrier, and reap the benefits.

headline: At Vonage, Sales Increase as Litigation Clouds Future
abstract: Vonage said that its quarterly loss narrowed and sales rose 64 percent amid a fierce legal battle with Verizon Communications that has left its future in question.

headline: Pakistan Suicide Blast Kills 22 Near Afghan Border
abstract: A bomber struck a restaurant in Peshawar, the third major suicide bombing this year in North-West Frontier Province.

headline: Israeli Premier Accused of Impropriety in Previous Post
abstract: A report states that  Ehud Olmert improperly helped an associate during his term as minister of trade and industry in a previous government.

headline: Britain Adopts Conciliatory Tone With Iran
abstract: Britain said it had responded to a diplomatic message and was ready to peacefully resolve the issue of 15 captured sailors and marines held in Iran.

headline: Israeli Leader Resists Calls to Resign
abstract: Prime Minister Ehud Olmert’s aides say the coalition is holding together in the wake of a damning report.

headline: McClatchy Draws Interest From Big Hedge Fund
abstract: A couple of days after an unusual spike in shares of McClatchy prompted talk — highly speculative talk — that the newspaper chain was a takeover target, there is another intriguing, though inconclusive, development.

headline: Masters of the New Universe
abstract: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

headline: Lehman to Buy Energy Services Firm
abstract: Lehman Brothers said it would acquire Eagle Energy Partners, a Houston-based energy services company, becoming the latest investment bank to bolster its presence in the physical energy markets. “Commodities over the last several years have become a very significant asset class,” Skip McGee, Lehman’s head of global investment banking, told MarketWatch.

headline: Cerberus Said to Consider Bid for Bell Canada
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is also circling.

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Another Swing at Topps
abstract: A New York hedge fund, Crescendo Partners, on Thursday alleged that certain Topps board members have conflicts of interest that prevent the trading card and confection company from negotiating in good faith with its rival, Upper Deck, on a potential acquisition.

headline: Apollo Seeks to Sell Stake to Investors
abstract: Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black. The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said. DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.

abstract: Russia’s economy expanded in the first quarter at the fastest pace in six years as production of building materials increased to keep pace with a construction boom and consumer demand remained strong. Gross domestic product rose at an annual rate of 7.9 percent in the period, compared with 5 percent in the first quarter of 2006, the Federal Statistics Service said. The figure is not seasonally adjusted. Industrial output increased 7.9 percent in the first quarter of the year, compared with 4.1 percent in the period last year, according to the Federal Statistics Service.

headline: China Reminds Hong Kong Who’s Boss
abstract: Wu Bangguo, the chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People’s Congress, said at a conference in Beijing that Hong Kong had considerable autonomy only because the central government had chosen to authorize that autonomy. Under the Sino-British Joint Declaration of 1984, China promised Britain that as part of the return of Hong Kong to Chinese rule China would preserve “a high degree of autonomy” for the territory. But Chinese officials focus these days on the Basic Law, a Beijing-drafted document that serves as Hong Kong’s mini-constitution and gives broad powers to the Standing Committee in Beijing to set policy in Hong Kong by interpreting the territory’s laws. Mr. Wu spoke ahead of the 10th anniversary on July 1 of Hong Kong’s return to China.

headline: Coles Stake Acquired
abstract: Wesfarmers, Australia’s biggest home-improvement retailer, said it had bought an 11.3 percent stake in the Coles Group, the country’s second-biggest retailer, and is seeking talks with the company. Wesfarmers paid 16.47 Australian dollars ($13.40) a share for its stake, information from the Australian Stock Exchange shows, valuing Coles at 19.7 billion Australian dollars, or $16 billion. Coles, Australia’s second-biggest retailer, put itself up for sale in February, after saying it would not meet profit forecasts that had been cited to reject a bid of 18.2 billion Australian dollars by the private equity firm Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company.

headline: Russia: Mine Officials Who Turned a Blind Eye to Safety Are Fired
abstract: The authorities dismissed five mine safety officials for allowing a Siberian coal mine to “break safety rules for the benefit of profit,” an action they said led to an explosion in March that killed 108 miners, the biggest mine disaster in Russia’s recent history. An investigation showed that the mine’s managers deliberately disabled a methane gas detector. A buildup of methane, sparked by a short circuit, caused the blast. The dismissals, reported by the Interfax news agency, were an exception to the usual blanket impunity enjoyed by government officials.

headline: Flu Vaccine Maker Seeks U.S. Market
abstract: CSL, an Australian drug maker, asked for quick approval of a seasonal flu vaccine in the United States, where health officials have been battling shortages by encouraging new suppliers. CSL is seeking priority review, which could gain clearance for the shots for people 18 and older by Sept. 30, said Paul Perreault, an executive vice president at the company’s CSL Biotherapies unit.. The application is the first attempt by CSL, which has made the flu vaccine since 1962, to sell shots in the United States, Mr. Perreault said.

headline: Lehman to Buy Energy Services Firm
abstract: Lehman Brothers said it would acquire Eagle Energy Partners, a Houston-based energy services company, becoming the latest investment bank to bolster its presence in the physical energy markets. “Commodities over the last several years have become a very significant asset class,” Skip McGee, Lehman’s head of global investment banking, told MarketWatch.

headline: Cerberus Said to Consider Bid for Bell Canada
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is also circling.

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Another Swing at Topps
abstract: A New York hedge fund, Crescendo Partners, on Thursday alleged that certain Topps board members have conflicts of interest that prevent the trading card and confection company from negotiating in good faith with its rival, Upper Deck, on a potential acquisition.

headline: Apollo Seeks to Sell Stake to Investors
abstract: Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black. The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said. DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.

headline: China: 180,000 Displaced After Strong Quake
abstract: Rescue efforts continued in southwestern Yunnan Province as roughly 180,000 people were evacuated from their homes after a Sunday morning earthquake that registered a magnitude 6.4 killed at least three people and injured more than 300, according to state news media. More than 1,000 aftershocks have rattled the nerves of residents in the city of Pu’er, in a mountainous region of Yunnan. Roughly 2,000 soldiers and rescue workers are at the scene, and evacuees are living in tents or public buildings.

headline: Switzerland: How Ötzi the Iceman Died
abstract: Ötzi, the Neolithic iceman whose well-preserved body was found in the Alps in 1991, bled to death after being hit in the back by an arrow, Swiss scientists said. The arrowhead itself had already been found, but new CAT scans show that it cut an artery, causing internal bleeding, according to Frank J. Rühli of the Anatomy Institute of Zurich University. “A lesion of an artery close to the shoulder has been found, thanks to a CAT scan,” he said.

headline: India: Expansion at Two-Decade High
abstract: India’s economy grew at the fastest rate in almost 20 years in its last fiscal year as companies lifted production to meet surging consumer demand. The economy expanded 9.4 percent in the year, which ended March 31, the biggest gain since 1989 and more than the government’s initial estimate of 9.2 percent, the Central Statistical Organization said. India’s economy grew 9.1 percent in the three months to March 31, according to the report, averaging a quarterly pace of 8.8 percent in the last two years compared with 5.7 percent in the 1990s. Manufacturing gained 12.4 percent while mining rose 7.1 percent and electricity output climbed 6.9 percent in the quarter. Agriculture, which accounts for a fifth of the economy, grew 3.8 percent.

headline: Limits on Roaming Charges
abstract: The European Parliament voted to impose retail price caps on roaming charges, fees that mobile phone consumers pay when making or receiving calls outside of their home calling zones. The European Council of Ministers, which has already endorsed the plan, is scheduled to approve the price caps formally June 7. As early as August, the charges will be limited to 0.49 euro (66 cents) a minute for outgoing calls and 0.24 euro for incoming calls, excluding tax.

abstract: Lone Star Funds said it would divest itself of two of its South Korean holdings, fueling speculation it was planning to exit the country.

abstract: Tishman has joined with Lehman Brothers to buy Archstone-Smith Trust, the second-largest public apartment owner in terms of market cap and asset value, for $13.5 billion.

abstract: China’s car sales rose 23 percent in May, as price cuts and new models attracted more people to showrooms. Customers bought 488,500 passenger cars, multipurpose vehicles and sport-utility vehicles in May, the China Association of Automobile Manufacturers said.

abstract: Small electronic gadgets are the items most easily left behind, but travelers leave all sorts of things on planes and in hotel rooms.

abstract: Bank of America will see if a new name, U.S. Trust, Bank of America Private Wealth Management, can burnish its private bank’s reputation in catering to the very rich.

abstract: A $27.5 billion deal for Alltel Corporation to go private is not sitting well with other private equity bidders.

headline: Exile Is Rebuked for Urging Ouster of Putin
abstract: Boris A. Berezovsky, a self-exiled Russian tycoon, earned sharp rebukes from London and Moscow on Friday when he urged the forceful ouster of Vladimir V. Putin as president of Russia and a new revolution there.

headline: Brazil: Google Steps Up Oversight
abstract: Google agreed to make it easier to remove offensive content posted on its Orkut social-networking site, heeding requests from prosecutors in Brazil. Google will set up a page on Orkut where prosecutors will send requests to remove content, the Rio de Janeiro state prosecutor’s office said. In Brazil, where Orkut is the most-used social networking site, prosecutors complained last year that the company was taking too long to comply with their demands to eliminate some material on the site. Google, based in Mountain View, Calif., said it had added workers to review reports of offensive or illegal content, along with special tools for law enforcement to expedite reviews.

abstract: The banker, charged with masterminding a $7.5 million insider trading ring, will be released after a federal judge questioned the strength of the government’s case.

abstract: The McKinsey Global Institute said markets alone are unlikely to ensure the best product choices.

abstract: Severally unusually large trades in shares of Dow Jones indicate that some investors may have known about the acquisition offer ahead of time.

abstract: Viktor F. Yanukovich today defied an order by President Viktor A. Yushchenko to disband Parliament and called the decision a “fatal mistake.”

headline: Memo Pad
abstract: AIR TRAVEL DELAYS ARE UP Delays on domestic flights rose in the first quarter, with 25.25 percent of flights arriving late, compared with 21.35 percent in the first quarter of last year, the Bureau of Transportation Statistics said yesterday. The number of lost or otherwise mishandled checked bags rose in March  to 7.71 per 1,000 passengers compared with 5.81 per 1,000 passengers in March 2006.

headline: Putting Fresh Ads Into a Recorded Show
abstract: Fox is seeking to patent a way to replace “old” commercials with “new” ones when viewers replay Fox shows they have taped on digital video recorders.

headline: Dear S.E.C., Reconsider Arbitration
abstract: Arbitration was sold to investors as a cheap and fast alternative to the court system. But it has grown more costly and time-consuming.

headline: Hong Kong: North Korean Funds Transferred
abstract: Banking authorities in the United States and Macao began transferring millions of dollars to North Korea to end a dispute that has stalled an agreement to dismantle the North’s nuclear programs, Macao government officials said. The money was transferred from Banco Delta Asia, a small family-owned bank in Macao, in the first step to return the money to the original account holders, the officials said. Under pressure from the United States, the Macao government in September 2005 ordered that about $25 million belonging to either North Korean state agencies or businesses with links to North Korea be frozen in the Macao bank. Diplomats working on putting into effect the agreement reached in February among North Korea, the United States, China, Japan, Russia and South Korea hope the transfer will at last revive stalled attempts to get the North to shut its nuclear facilities.

headline: Liberian Ex-Leader Boycotts War Crimes Trial as It Opens
abstract: Former President Charles G. Taylor of Liberia is on trial on charges of backing rebels who plunged Sierra Leone into civil war.

abstract: Insurance companies are testing one-stop service centers, which handle every aspect of the claim from a car accident.

headline: Switzerland: Massachusetts Challenges U.S. Unit of UBS
abstract: UBS Securities, the investment-banking division of the Swiss-based UBS, was accused by Massachusetts regulators of dishonest and unethical practices in dealings with hedge-fund advisers. The subsidiary, based in Stamford, Conn., gave hedge-fund managers below-market rent, low-interest personal loans and other benefits to retain and increase business, according to a complaint from the office of William Galvin, the secretary of the commonwealth and its top securities regulator. The complaint also accuses UBS of failing to supervise gifts and gratuities. The action, filed with the state’s Securities Division, seeks a cease-and-desist order, a censure and an undisclosed administrative fine, the statement said. Doug Morris, a UBS spokesman in New York, declined to comment.

abstract: Globalization and technical transitions have not always gone smoothly for SAP, a big German software company.

headline: Cerberus Said to Consider Bid for Bell Canada
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is also circling.

abstract: With Eliot Spitzer now in the governor’s mansion, is there another state regulator trying to take up his badge?

headline: 3 Palestinian Militants Killed Near Gaza Border Fence
abstract: JERUSALEM, April 28  The Israeli army shot four Palestinian militants near the border fence in Gaza this morning, killing three and seriously wounding one, an army spokeswoman said. The armed militants were spotted trying to plant an explosive device, she said. A spokesman for the military wing of Hamas said they were members of Hamas’s Izz al-Din al-Qassam Brigades on a “jihad mission.”.

headline: Correction: April 29 and May 6 Country Indexes
abstract: The Country Indexes table on the DataBank page on April 29 and May 6 carried incorrect data from FTSE International for the performance of foreign stock markets. Corrected tables are online at nytimes.com/business/yourmoney.

headline: Violent Protests in Nigeria Over Election Results
abstract: Partial results from highly contested state elections appeared to hand most of the victories to the governing People’s Democratic Party.

headline: Austrians Cast Doubt on Russian Arrests in Murder Case
abstract: Austrian authorities have cast doubt on the quality of Russian sleuthing, possibly linking a recent murder to a multi-million-dollar money-laundering scheme.

headline: China Inflation Hits 3.4 Percent in May
abstract: Inflation in China reached a 27-month high last month, but separate figures for growth in the money supply and loans suggested that the broader economy was not yet overheating.

headline: U.S. Faces More Distrust From World, Poll Shows
abstract: Distrust of the United States has intensified across the world, but overall views of America remain favorable, according to a poll by the Pew Research Center.

headline: Euro RSCG to Create Cracker Ads for Kraft
abstract: Spending for the new cracker campaigns is estimated at $50 million.

headline: Puffing Away That PG Rating
abstract: The Motion Picture Association of America said portrayals of smoking would be considered alongside sex and violence in assessing the suitability of movies for young viewers.

headline: Baron Guy de Rothschild, Leader of French Arm of Bank Dynasty, Dies at 98
abstract: The heir to the House of Rothschild banking family twice rebuilt and expanded its Paris bank after it was seized by France during World War II.

headline: Japan’s Leader Walks Thin Line With Remarks on Sex Slavery
abstract: TOKYO, April 28 — In his first visit to the United States as Japan’s leader, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe quickly got on a first-name basis with President Bush and secured an invitation to the ranch in Crawford, Tex., for the next time.

headline: 2 Accused of ‘Suspicious’ Trading in Dow Jones Bid
abstract: The S.E.C. said a Hong Kong couple bought up shares before Rupert Murdoch’s offer was made public.

headline: Oil Giant Sees Some Strains in the System
abstract: James J. Mulva, chairman and chief executive of ConocoPhillips, spoke about his concerns that Congress and the country were not doing enough to meet the public’s energy needs.

headline: Oil Price ‘Gouging’: A Phantom Menace?
abstract: The broader issue is that refinery capacity has not kept up with American demand for gasoline.

headline: For Dedicated BlackBerry Users, a Way to Stay Connected Abroad
abstract: The new BlackBerry 8830 allows calls and e-mail to be received almost anywhere in the world.

headline: 3 Afghan Employees of French Aid Group Freed by the Taliban
abstract: The three men, held hostage for seven weeks by Taliban insurgents, were freed unharmed after local residents intervened.

abstract: Ray Dalio, the founder of Bridgewater Associates, has some tough questions on why hedge fund returns look so much like returns in the stock market.

headline: Treasury Auctions Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

headline: In Zimbabwe, Mugabe Critics Face Beatings
abstract: Critics of President Robert G. Mugabe are being savagely beaten by the scores — and some say by the hundreds.

headline: What’s Cooking in First Class?
abstract: Eating light or indulging, you can bet it’s not peanuts.

headline: Pope Tightens Voting Rules for Election of Successors
abstract: Pope Benedict XVI has reinstituted the traditional requirement that two-thirds of cardinals agree on a candidate, no matter how long the process takes.

abstract: The embrace of Al Gore by the Cannes Lions International Advertising Festival shows how “green” advertising has galvanized the marketing community.

abstract: Advanced Medical Optics had no explanation yet of why its contact lens care product might be contributing to an outbreak of eye infections.

abstract: Turmoil in the subprime mortgage market took its toll on two Wall Street investment banks today, as second-quarter profit at Bear Stearns dropped 33 percent and Goldman Sachs squeezed out a modest 1 percent rise in profit.

headline: NBC Brings In Programming Help
abstract: NBC Universal hired one of the hottest young production talents in television, Ben Silverman, as a chairman of both its entertainment division and its television studio.

headline: Britain: Fashion Legend Drank Weed Killer
abstract: Isabella Blow, the colorful and influential British fashion editor, talent spotter and aristocrat who died in a hospital in Gloucestershire on Monday, ended her life by drinking the herbicide paraquat, The Times of London reported on its Web site. It said that at the opening of an inquest into her death yesterday, the deputy Gloucestershire coroner, David Dooley, reported that after Ms. Blow, 48, was “found in a poorly state” on Saturday and taken to the hospital, “she told doctors she had taken paraquat, and tests proved positive for this liquid.” Further toxicological tests are to be done before a full inquest in October.

headline: What to Do When Rupert Calls?
abstract: Rupert Murdoch may be the perfect publisher for The Wall Street Journal. Let me explain.

headline: Appeals Court Allows Net Phone Company to Continue Signing Up New Customers
abstract: Vonage can sign up new customers as well as maintain service to existing ones as it pursues its appeal of a earlier ruling that it infringed three Verizon patents.

headline: A.M.D. Plans to Cut Back on Spending and Hiring
abstract: The chipmaker, whose forecast was well below Wall Street’s expectations, announced a restructuring to lower costs.

headline: And Gas Saver Makes Three Cars in the Driveway
abstract: Thousands of consumers are lining up to buy small cars, but they are not giving up their S.U.V.’s and pickups.

headline: The More Affordable Pininfarina, Available in Red and Onyx
abstract: The latest offerings from SimpleTech have raised the bar in storage and lowered it for price.

headline: China Seeks Extradition Pacts in Spite of Death Penalty
abstract: Some governments have been reluctant to sign extradition treaties with China because of concerns about its widespread use of the death penalty.

headline: After Shake-Up, What Now for Yahoo?
abstract: All eyes are on the next steps that Jerry Yang, the company’s co-founder, will take to rejuvenate the troubled business.

abstract: A Russian man who had been captured by American forces in Afghanistan and released from Guantánamo Bay was killed in a police raid.

abstract: The paper won the prestigious Public Service medal. The New York Times and The Boston Globe also won awards.

headline: Correction: How to Confine the Plants of the Future?
abstract: The Re:framing column last Sunday, about genetically engineered crops used in medicine, misstated the status of a proposal by Ventria Bioscience to plant its pharmaceutical rice in fields in Kansas. The Agriculture Department is evaluating comments before making a decision; it has not yet approved the permit.

headline: A New Twist on Snooping at Wal-Mart
abstract: Wal-Mart’s chief took the unusual step of releasing portions of a former employee’s sworn testimony that denied surveillance on shareholders and employees.

headline: News Corp. Bidding for Down Jones, CNBC Says
abstract: NEW YORK (AP) -- News Corporation, which includes Fox News Channel among its holdings, is offering to buy Dow Jones, publisher of The Wall Street Journal, according to CNBC.

headline: When a High-Definition Picture Is Too Good to Believe, See How It Handles This Test Disc
abstract: One way to check the quality of a high-definition television before you buy it is to bring an HQV Benchmark disc to the store with you.

abstract: Does “advertainment” cross an unseen line between commercial message and content where consumers ought not to go?

abstract: A deal may ensure an Italian face remains on Telecom Italia.

headline: For an Agency, Life After Wal-Mart Is Called Kmart
abstract: Kmart is teaming up with Draft FCB, the agency that won — then lost — the creative account of its major competitor, Wal-Mart Stores.

headline: Morocco Talks Set in Western Sahara Dispute
abstract: Morocco and the Polisario Front, which are struggling for control of resource-rich Western Sahara, agreed to hold direct talks for the first time under the terms of a unanimously passed United Nations Security Council resolution. Morocco, which annexed the Front in 1979, hopes to incorporate it as an autonomous province with its own regional government. The Polisario Front wants a referendum that will offer the 260,000 residents the choice of autonomy or independence from Morocco.

headline: Borrowing Trouble
abstract: A class-action suit tests the practices of NovaStar Financial, a mortgage lender based in Kansas City, Mo.

headline: Handling House Calls in a Managed-Care World
abstract: Home visits for chronically ill patients may be a way to save, and make, money.

headline: Germany: Concrete Maker Buys a Supplier
abstract: HeidelbergCement, a German concrete maker, has agreed to buy Hanson, a British supplier of building materials, for £7.85 billion ($16 billion). HeidelbergCement will pay £11 ($21.80) a share for Hanson, a premium of 29 percent over Hanson’s share price on May 2 when HeidelbergCement first said it might bid. With the purchase, HeidelbergCement will increase its revenue by two-thirds, expanding in the United States and bolstering output of aggregates, pipes and bricks. “The companies are a perfect fit and overlaps are minimal,” HeidelbergCement’s chief executive, Bernd Scheifele, above, said in a conference call with analysts. “Hanson strengthens our operations in the U.S., U.K. and Europe and adds a business in Australia.” Hanson has 26,000 workers in 14 nations and derives half its sales from North America.

headline: Surprising Finding in Capital Gains Study
abstract: Only 3 percent of capital gains go to people who make less than about $50,000.

headline: Dozens of Shiites Killed in Baghdad Attacks
abstract: BAGHDAD, June 28 — A spate of grisly attacks believed carried out by Sunni extremists killed dozens of Shiites around Baghdad over the past two days, just ahead of a planned huge march of devout Shiites through Sunni Arab heartlands to the remnants of a revered Shiite shrine.

headline: Anarchist’s Head Is Finally Buried, but Outcry Arises Over Timing
abstract: Giovanni Passannante, who tried to kill the king of Italy 120 years ago, is becoming a cause célèbre 97 years after his death.

headline: For Pan-Am Games, the Big Race Is to the Starting Line
abstract: Rio’s high hopes for the Pan-American Games are tempered by huge cost overruns, construction delays, strikes, court battles and internal bickering.

headline: Lens Solution Recall Is Blow to Company’s Stock
abstract: Shares of Advanced Medical Optics plunged in trading on Tuesday as investors reacted to a recall of one of the company’s best-selling contact lens cleaning solutions over health concerns.

headline: Wading Through Formats: JPEG, TIFF and Friends
abstract: Depending on what you want to do with digital pictures, the format in which you save them can make a big difference.

headline: 2 Lawyers Sued by S.E.C. in Penny Stock Fraud Case
abstract: The two lawyers are charged with having played important roles in a penny stock fraud that cost investors at least $160,000 in 2005.

headline: A Virtual Ad Agency for Online Radio
abstract: As more people listen to the radio over the Internet, radio stations have been looking to generate new advertising revenue from the medium.

headline: Libya Court Clears 6 of Slander in H.I.V. Case
abstract: A Libyan court dismissed defamation charges against five Bulgarian nurses and a Palestinian doctor who had been sentenced to death in a separate trial.

headline: 5 Killed and 3 Missing in Attack on American Patrol South of Baghdad
abstract: Seven U.S. soldiers and an Iraqi interpreter came under attack in a Qaeda stronghold south of Baghdad.

headline: Refugees Pour Out of Camp in Lebanon
abstract: About 15,000 Palestinians left the Nahr al Bared refugee camp as the Lebanese Army reinforced its vow to crush a militant Palestinian group inside.

headline: Germany: No Pardons for 2 in Terrorism Gang
abstract: President Horst Köhler turned down a politically contentious request for clemency by a terrorist from the far-left Red Army Faction, also known as the Baader-Meinhof gang. Mr. Köhler met last week with the man, Christian Klar, who has served 24 years of a life sentence for the murder of a German prosecutor in 1977. The meeting drew protests from conservative politicians, who said Mr. Klar had shown no remorse for his crimes. Speculation that he might be freed rose after a fellow gang member, Brigitte Mohnhaupt, was released in March after serving 24 years in prison for murders in the 1970s. The president also denied clemency to another member, Birgit Hogefeld.

headline: AT&T and Mexican Affiliate Seek Stake in Italian Company
abstract: AT&T and its Mexican affiliate, América Móvil, have bid more than $6 billion for control of Italy’s largest cellphone company, Telecom Italia.

headline: McClatchy Draws Interest From Big Hedge Fund
abstract: A couple of days after an unusual spike in shares of McClatchy prompted talk — highly speculative talk — that the newspaper chain was a takeover target, there is another intriguing, though inconclusive, development.

headline: Masters of the New Universe
abstract: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

headline: Lehman to Buy Energy Services Firm
abstract: Lehman Brothers said it would acquire Eagle Energy Partners, a Houston-based energy services company, becoming the latest investment bank to bolster its presence in the physical energy markets. “Commodities over the last several years have become a very significant asset class,” Skip McGee, Lehman’s head of global investment banking, told MarketWatch.

headline: Cerberus Said to Consider Bid for Bell Canada
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is also circling.

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Another Swing at Topps
abstract: A New York hedge fund, Crescendo Partners, on Thursday alleged that certain Topps board members have conflicts of interest that prevent the trading card and confection company from negotiating in good faith with its rival, Upper Deck, on a potential acquisition.

headline: Apollo Seeks to Sell Stake to Investors
abstract: Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black. The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said. DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.

headline: Why Should A Sale Scare Wall Street?
abstract: Why Wall Street Fears A Real Market In Mortgage Securities

headline: Are Airline Bids Like Potato Chips?
abstract: Why did W. Douglas Parker, the chief executive of US Airways, launch a hostile bid for Delta Air Lines so soon after the merger of US Airways and America West? Partly “to maximize value,” he told Fortune magazine’s Barney Gimbel as he was awaiting a decision from Delta’s creditors’ committee in January. “But it’s also kind of fun, too.”

headline: Wall St. Lobby Firm Says It Investigated Former Co-Chief
abstract: Wall Street’s largest and most important trade association acknowledged Wednesday that one of its co-chief executives resigned abruptly earlier this year after an internal investigation uncovered loose financial management by him.

headline: Big Union Takes Skeptical Look at Private Equity
abstract: In Europe, private equity firms are accustomed to feeling the heat from unions. Now, the temperature is rising in the United States as well.

headline: Remington Arms Is Sold
abstract: Remington Arms, the gun maker that has equipped American soldiers for 150 years, has agreed to be acquired by a private equity firm, Cerberus Capital Management, for $118 million, a statement by Remington said yesterday. The company, based in Madison, N.C., reported its first profit in three years in 2006.

headline: Russian Energy Giant to Bundle Carbon Credits With Gas Sales
abstract: Gazprom will sell carbon dioxide emissions credits that companies in the European Union need in order to burn Gazprom’s fuel.

headline: Australian Rate Is Steady
abstract: Australia’s central bank kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged.

headline: Pakistan: Chief Judge Challenges His Judges
abstract: Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry, the chief justice suspended by President Pervez Musharraf last month, appeared before the Supreme Judicial Council to defend himself on charges of misuse of power. He has filed a petition in the Supreme Court, the court he once headed, challenging the constitutional authority of the five-judge council, said his lawyer, Chaudhry Aitzaz Ahsan. The council adjourned the hearing until Tuesday.

headline: Two French Cruise Passengers Missing Off Greece
abstract: Greek Navy divers searched the wreck of a cruise ship today for two missing French passengers after authorities rescued nearly 1,600 tourists and crew members from the ship.

abstract: Health officials discovered 35 tiny bones and at least eight skulls at an illegal nursing home run by an unqualified doctor.

abstract: The world economy may be tough on your industry but look on the bright side: you could be French.

headline: In China, Talk of Democracy Is Simply That
abstract: By permitting an open round of political discussion, China’s leaders are casting themselves as progressives.

headline: At Bristol-Myers, Interim Chief Gets Post Permanently
abstract: Bristol-Myers said it would go with its interim chief, James M. Cornelius, extending his contract for two years.

abstract: YouTube will become an easy way to view content from Al Jazeera English, the English-language version of the TV news station.

abstract: The U.S. and its European allies scheduled a vote on a resolution establishing an international court to try those suspected of killing Rafik Hariri, the former Lebanese prime minister.

abstract: In a surprise facet of the deal, ABN Amro said that it had arranged to sell LaSalle Bank to Bank of America.

abstract: A defense lawyer pointed out the numerous times F. David Radler had lied before he cut a deal with federal prosecutors.

headline: Sporting Goods Maker Is Said to Be Acquired
abstract: The Jarden Corporation will acquire K2, the maker of K2 skis and Rawlings baseball gloves and bats, for about $1.2 billion.

headline: Sudan Defying Security Council on Darfur, U.N. Says
abstract: An unpublished report says the government of Sudan is flying arms and military equipment into Darfur.

headline: Clash of Hope and Fear as Venezuela Seizes Land
abstract: President Hugo Chávez is redistributing his country’s farmland  in a process that is both brutal and legal.

abstract: AOB Media, a small two-year-old company, produced a Chinese TV show that might only otherwise be achieved by vast multinational entertainment companies.

headline: U.S. Holds Direct Talks in North Korea on Arms
abstract: In the first visit by a senior U.S. official in nearly five years, America’s chief nuclear negotiator was in Pyongyang today in an effort to speed up nuclear negotiations.

abstract: Baquba has emerged as a magnet for insurgents and, perhaps, the next major headache for the U.S. military.

abstract: The real debate over private equity is taking place backstage, not in the center ring of the political circus.

abstract: Five American soldiers were killed when insurgents blew up a huge bomb beneath their convoy and then attacked with a hail of gunfire and rocket-propelled grenades.

abstract: American forces began running DNA tests on a body that could be one of the remaining two missing soldiers abducted in an ambush on May 12 south of Baghdad.

abstract: The restaurant chain that operates KFC and Taco Bell reported strong first-quarter earnings, despite public relations disasters.

abstract: The editor of Al Sabah was kidnapped three days ago in a Shiite neighborhood of Baghdad.

abstract: Bed Bath & Beyond said that fourth-quarter profit climbed 4 percent as the company used discount coupons to lure customers.

abstract: Belarus, one of the world’s most repressive states, was outvoted in favor of Bosnia, a late entry.

abstract: An influential Hamas leader in Gaza warned that Fatah’s effort to repress Hamas in the West Bank could lead to Fatah’s downfall there as well.

abstract: Zimbabwe’s government has put forward legislation that would require virtually all publicly traded companies to cede controlling interests to “indigenous” citizens.

abstract: The attacks today brought the four-day death toll for American troops to at least 25 as insurgents continue to use huge roadside bombs to rip through combat vehicles.

abstract: Frank Blake strove to make this year’s shareholders meeting a model of openness.

abstract: A dispute between Groupe Danone, the French dairy and beverage maker, and its Chinese partner, the beverage maker Wahaha, has become even stranger.

abstract: Avaya was near a deal on Sunday night to sell itself to Silver Lake Partners and the Texas Pacific Group for more than $8 billion.

abstract: Until recently, U.S. officials admit, fighting drugs was considered a distraction from fighting terrorists.

abstract: The search for five British civilians kidnapped from an Iraqi government building intensified and the Iraqi government pledged its support for an investigation.

abstract: Brent Bowers, a longtime small-business editor at The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal, is author of The Eight Patterns of Highly Effective Entrepreneurs, due out in paperback next week (Doubleday).

abstract: The market for drugs to control and treat diseases of aging and for appearance-related products and services is expected to reach $71 billion a year by 2009.

abstract: The police said that they mistook Jean Charles de Menezes for a terrorist, who was fatally shot one day after an alleged failed terrorist attack.

abstract: The proposal calls on the F.C.C. to let companies allocate radio spectrum using the same kind of real-time auction that Google uses to sell ads.

abstract: International sports institutions are imposing vigorous controls over the online use of game information and photographs.

abstract: Judges at the International Criminal Court issued arrest warrants for the two men, but the Sudanese government quickly responded that the court had no jurisdiction.

abstract: Being a great technology company is still being learned — the easy way if you own Google and the hard way if your money is in Yahoo.

abstract: A decree by President Hugo Chávez severely limiting alcohol sales in Venezuela for much of Holy Week has generated a public outcry.

abstract: Young protesters overran an oil pipeline hub in the volatile Niger Delta, cutting Nigeria’s oil production by about 30 percent.

abstract: Lebanese Army troops opened fire at Palestinian demonstrators trying to march back to their besieged refugee camp in northern Lebanon, witnesses said.

abstract: Lorene F. Schaefer has accused G.E. of systematically discriminating against women in both pay and promotions.

abstract: The protests follow a damning report on Ehud Olmert’s leadership during Israel’s war with Lebanon.

abstract: Home sellers in Madison, Wis., did not get higher prices for their homes using real estate agents, a study concluded.

abstract: The $25 billion buyout has the potential to not only transform Sallie Mae but shake up the entire lending industry.

abstract: Perhaps more than 20,000 people were shot and buried at the height of Stalin’s purges on the southern edge of Moscow.

abstract: Gen. David H. Petraeus has recommended that troop levels in Iraq be maintained at least through September, Pentagon officials said.

headline: Memo Pad
abstract: MAJOR AIRPORT INVESTMENT URGED Airports need to spend more than $87 billion for infrastructure and other improvements by 2011 to accommodate increasing passenger and air-cargo demand, according to a study by the Airports Council International North America. “Anyone traveling by air today knows that aviation is already stretched to the breaking point,” said Greg Principato, president of the council. In a statement, the group said that “2007 is stacking up to be similar to and in some instances worse than 2000, a year which until now had the dubious distinction of being the peak year for air-travel delays.” Most airport improvement projects — for runways, terminals, gates and the like — are paid for by the so-called passenger facility charge added to the price of airline tickets. That charge has been capped by Congress at $4.50 since 2000, but the council said Congress should increase the cap.

headline: Mexico: Drug Dealers Attack the Military
abstract: Five soldiers were ambushed and killed in the western state of Michoacán late Tuesday during an anti-drug operation, a brazen sign that drug dealers are willing to fight the military as it tries to rid the state of narcotics, the authorities said. Heavily armed men, whom investigators believe to be drug-cartel henchmen, opened fire on the soldiers at 11:30 p.m. as they were driving in pickups through Carácuaro, 85 miles south of the capital, Morelia. One gunmen was also killed in the ensuing exchange of fire. President Felipe Calderón has sent more than 6,000 soldiers into the state as part of a crackdown on drug traffickers that has failed to slow the pace of gangland-style executions.

headline: More Advice Graduates Don’t Want to Hear
abstract: Divert 10 percent of your income to savings; ignore raises and put them into savings, too; learn to cook; and skip the lattes.

headline: Pakistan: 3 Journalists Receive Bullet Threats

Journalists groups reacted quickly, describing the act as an attempt to intimidate the press and linking it to a shady group with ties to the Muttahida Quami Movement, the party that controls Karachi and is allied with the president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf. According to news reports, the group recently issued a list naming a dozen journalists as “enemies,” including two who received the bullets.

headline: China: Virus Suspected in Pig Deaths

China’s Ministry of Agriculture is conducting tests to determine if the disease is porcine reproductive and respiratory syndrome, a viral disease that began attacking North American and European swine farms in the late 1980s and is the costliest virus for swine herds in the United States. The disease does not infect humans, the United Nations agency said. China reported a similar epidemic of the pig disease to the agency in September.

Rinker, based in Sydney, a building materials maker, gets about 80 percent of its sales in the United States.

headline: Lehman to Buy Energy Services Firm
abstract: Lehman Brothers said it would acquire Eagle Energy Partners, a Houston-based energy services company, becoming the latest investment bank to bolster its presence in the physical energy markets. “Commodities over the last several years have become a very significant asset class,” Skip McGee, Lehman’s head of global investment banking, told MarketWatch.

headline: Cerberus Said to Consider Bid for Bell Canada
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is also circling.

headline: Apollo Seeks to Sell Stake to Investors
abstract: Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black. The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said. DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.

headline: Japan Wages Fell in March
abstract: Wages in Japan fell for a fourth month in March, signaling that growth in consumer spending will be limited. Monthly wages, including overtime and bonuses, fell 0.4 percent after dropping 1 percent in February, the labor ministry said. In China, manufacturing activity expanded at the fastest pace in more than two years in April, according to a survey of purchasing managers. The Purchasing Managers’ Index rose to 58.6 from 56.1 in March, the statistics bureau said. That is the highest since the index started in January 2005.

Gates said today that the United States and its European allies should honor the thousands of Americans buried here by strengthening the alliance they died defending.

headline: United Nations: Russia Rejects Kosovo Plan
abstract: The United States and European countries on the Security Council circulated a new resolution calling for independence for Kosovo, the breakaway province of Serbia, and delaying carrying out the plan for four months, but Russia, whose objections to a previous version led to the revision, rejected it. Kosovo has welcomed the plan and has threatened to declare independence on its own if the United Nations does not act, but Vitaly I. Churkin, Russia’s ambassador, called it “unacceptable.”.

headline: Canada: Ex-Officer Returns to Parts Maker
abstract: Magna, the Canadian auto parts manufacturer, said that a former president, Belinda Stronach, left, the daughter of the company’s founder and controlling shareholder, Frank Stronach, would be returning to the company to be the executive vice chairwoman. The company said that Ms. Stronach would not seek re-election to the Canadian Parliament, where she has served since 2004. Magna has been discussed by auto analysts as a possible bidder for the Chrysler division of the DaimlerChrysler Corporation. “My father is looking to the future, the company is facing important strategic decisions, and the Canadian and global auto sector and economy are in a period of great challenge,” Ms. Stronach said in a statement.

headline: U.N. Says Bosnian Police Officers May Reapply
abstract: The Security Council has ruled that 700 former Bosnian police officers dismissed by United Nations police trainers after the 1992-1995 civil war for misconduct or alleged involvement in war crimes can reapply for law enforcement work, though not necessarily the same jobs they had. Emyr Jones Parry, the British ambassador to the United Nations, president of the council in April, said in a letter to Bosnian authorities that the country’s standards for recruitment and selection were now acceptable and that individuals could regain police jobs as long as they met those standards. In recent years, 260 of the officers have protested their firings, saying they were guilty only of minor misconduct. Mr. Jones Parry said that his letter should not be interpreted as guaranteeing reinstatement.

headline: Chile: Trade Surplus Widens as Copper Prices Rise
abstract: The trade surplus widened 21 percent in March from the previous month, because of higher prices for copper, the country’s top export. The trade surplus rose to $2.03 billion in March from $1.68 billion in February, the central bank said. The surplus was smaller than the $2.89 billion surplus in March 2006 but was in line with analysts’ forecasts. Chilean exports rose to $5.5 billion, from $4.57 billion the previous month, while imports climbed to $3.47 billion, from $2.9 billion, the bank said.

Non-government orders excluding shipping and utilities dropped 4.5 percent from a month earlier after declining a revised 4.9 percent in February.

abstract: Vonage can sign up new customers as it pursues its appeal of an earlier ruling that it infringed three Verizon patents.

headline: U.S. Consulate Closes in Morocco Over Security Concerns
abstract: The closing underscored U.S. concerns in Morocco and Algeria about further attacks and possible dangers to Americans.

headline: Hiring Outlook Shows There Is  Life After Finals
abstract: Employers intend to hire 19.2 percent more new college graduates than they did last year, according to a recent poll.

headline: Prepare for the SAT Test, or Play With Your iPod? Have It Both Ways
abstract: Kaplan Test Prep and Admissions, a traditional test preparation company, is offering interactive programs for downloading to iPods with video screens.

headline: G.M. Expects to Take a $1 Billion Charge for Delphi Costs
abstract: The automaker will take a $1 billion charge and pay a total of $7 billion to cover retirement costs for workers at the Delphi Corporation.

headline: Greece: Conviction in C.I.A. Death Upheld
abstract: A special appeals panel in Athens upheld the 2003 terrorism conviction of Alexandros Yiotopoulos, who led a Marxist terrorist group for 27 years, starting in 1975 with the assassination of the Athens C.I.A. station chief, Richard Welch. The court upheld sentences for 12 other members of the November 17 terrorist organization but cleared two additional suspects because the crimes they were convicted of had fallen outside the statute of limitations. Named after a 1973 student uprising that was crushed by the tanks of a military junta that ruled Greece, November 17 killed 23 people, including American and British diplomats and military officers. It disbanded after a botched bomb attack in 2003.

headline: After BP Executive’s Exit, a Fleet Street Debate
abstract: Did John Browne, who quit as chief executive of BP,  trip himself up, or was he pushed by an overzealous press?

headline: The iPhone Matches Most of Its Hype
abstract: Apple’s new phone does so many things so well, and so pleasurably, that you tend to forgive its foibles.

headline: Spain: Madrid Bombing Suspects on Hunger Strike
abstract: Nine defendants in the Madrid train-bombing trial began a hunger strike, joining four others who stopped eating last Thursday to protest the trial, the prison authority and a lawyer for the suspects said. Javier Gómez Bermúdez, the presiding judge, ejected two of the original hunger-strikers from the Madrid courtroom yesterday after they slumped to the floor, apparently weak from dehydration. He said he would authorize prison officials to force-feed them, if necessary. He added that the trial would “not be suspended under any circumstances.” The 13 men, mainly Moroccans, are among 29 suspects who have been on trial since Feb. 15 on charges connected to the bomb attacks on Madrid commuter trains that killed 191 people in 2004.

headline: Coke Struggles to Keep Up With Nimble Rivals
abstract: As its rivals have diversified and taken risks, the Coca-Cola Company has struggled to reinvent itself.

headline: Reader Responses
abstract: Excerpts from reader responses to David Leonhardt’s June 27.

headline: Report Criticizes Marines’ Actions in Afghanistan
abstract: American marines shot at bystanders in a rampage after a bomb ambush last month, a report released today said.

abstract: Iran’s announcement was greeted with skepticism by Western diplomats and nuclear experts.

headline: Food Safety Joins Issues at U.S.-China Talks

headline: Prominent Iranian-American Academic Is Jailed in Tehran
abstract: Haleh Esfandiari,  the director of the Middle East program at the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars, had endured repeated interrogations about her work.

headline: Hamas Seizes Broad Control in Gaza Strip
abstract: The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, faces the collapse of Fatah power in Gaza and a putative Palestinian state divided between Fatah and Hamas.

headline: Revised Genocide Exhibit Opens
abstract: A United Nations exhibit on the Rwandan genocide that was dismantled three weeks ago after Turkey objected to a reference to the Armenian genocide was opened in revised form by Secretary General Ban Ki-moon. Where the original exhibit had an entry called “What is genocide?” that cited the deaths “following World War I” of a million Armenians “in Turkey,” the revised entry is called “Defining the Crime” and refers to “mass killings of Armenians in the Ottoman Empire during World War I.” Some 1.5 million Armenians were killed by Ottoman Turks, but Turkey says they were victims of war and unrest instead of genocide. The exhibit observes the 13th anniversary of the 100-day slaughter in Rwanda of 800,000 Tutsis by Hutus.

headline: Protests Bog Down Canadian Travelers
abstract: OTTAWA, June 29 — Canadian travelers faced road and rail shutdowns this morning as they set out for the Canada Day holiday weekend amid nationwide protests by native groups.

abstract: The News Corporation and advisers for Dow Jones are close to agreeing on terms to protect The Wall Street Journal’s independence if the company is taken over.

abstract: Two of the world’s most repressive nations restored diplomatic ties with one another today after more than two decades of estrangement.

abstract: Michael Altman has filled most of the low-level jobs at his chocolate factory with ex-convicts. It’s part of a personal mission to be a good corporate citizen after a career as an executive recruiter.

abstract: The division, which has 11,000 employees, will be sold for $11.6 billion to Saudi Arabia’s largest public company.

headline: Japan: Abe Delays National Election
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe delayed the critical upper house election by a week, to July 29 from July 22, by extending Parliament’s current session by 12 days, in what was seen as a desperate move to regain popular support and dampen widespread anger over the government’s admission that it had misplaced payment information for millions of pensioners. Polls show that support for Mr. Abe and his Liberal Democratic Party has fallen dangerously low among potential voters, with the main opposition Democratic Party scoring higher in some polls. A significant defeat could put pressure on Mr. Abe to step down as party leader and prime minister, though his party would keep the prime minister’s post through its control over the lower house.

abstract: Prosecutors say the diversions defrauded shareholders of Hollinger International out of more than $60 million.

headline: Gaza Strip: Protests Over Kidnapped Reporter
abstract: More than a hundred Palestinian journalists and others held a sit-in outside the prime minister’s office in Gaza City to demand increased efforts to find Alan Johnston, the BBC correspondent abducted there three weeks ago. In the West Bank city of Ramallah, local and international journalists also called on the government to do more. The Palestinian journalists’ union declared a three-day news boycott of the government and the office of President Mahmoud Abbas. BBC executives say there has been no information about Mr. Johnston’s whereabouts nor any message from his captors saying what they want.

abstract: The company that recalled Thomas the Tank Engine wooden trains, which were contaminated with paint containing lead, is learning about crisis management.

abstract: A new sports drink brand, Accelerade, will battle Gatorade and Powerade for the hearts and mouths of thirsty athletes.

abstract: Rupert Murdoch’s vast media holdings give him a gamut of tools to enhance his financial interests.

headline: Lehman to Buy Energy Services Firm
abstract: Lehman Brothers said it would acquire Eagle Energy Partners, a Houston-based energy services company, becoming the latest investment bank to bolster its presence in the physical energy markets. “Commodities over the last several years have become a very significant asset class,” Skip McGee, Lehman’s head of global investment banking, told MarketWatch.

headline: Cerberus Said to Consider Bid for Bell Canada
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is also circling.

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Another Swing at Topps
abstract: A New York hedge fund, Crescendo Partners, on Thursday alleged that certain Topps board members have conflicts of interest that prevent the trading card and confection company from negotiating in good faith with its rival, Upper Deck, on a potential acquisition.

headline: Apollo Seeks to Sell Stake to Investors
abstract: Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black. The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said. DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.

headline: Macedonian Is New Assembly President
abstract: Srgjan Kerim, a former foreign minister of Macedonia who has served as his country’s ambassador to Germany, Switzerland and Lichtenstein, and the United Nations, was elected president of the General Assembly for the 62nd session of the 192-member body, which begins in September. The post rotates by regions, and Mr. Kerim’s candidacy was put forward by the Eastern European group. He succeeds Haya Rashed al-Khalifa of Bahrain.

abstract: The original promise of subprime mortgages dissipates.

abstract: Residents were left wondering whether the killing of the mayor was a simple crime, or politically motivated.

abstract: The Patent and Trademark Office said the patents for cells held by the University of Wisconsin appeared to be either the same or obvious variations of cells described in previous patents.

abstract: Animal feed has been regularly supplemented with a cheap additive that is at the center of a pet food recall.

abstract: The first round of the election is under way, and many French people face a dilemma: whether to vote with the heart or the head.

headline: London Exchange May Bid $2 Billion for Borsa Italiana
abstract: The London Stock Exchange was considering making a bid of $2 billion to acquire Borsa Italiana, the operator of the stock exchange in Milan, two people close to the companies said. The two exchanges discussed a potential merger and were set to continue discussions today, a spokesman for Borsa Italiana said. The spokesman, Alessandro Pavesi, said the proposal from the London exchange is the only one being considered. Both exchanges have fended off takeover approaches in the last year, and a merger might help them avoid a takeover in the future, said Rupak Ghose, an analyst at Credit Suisse in London. “It is not surprising that the L.S.E. is looking at different alternatives to become larger and hence avoid becoming acquired,” Mr. Ghose said in a note to investors.

headline: Democracy in Nigeria Falters but Is Far From Dead
abstract: Eight years into civilian government after a long spell of military dominance, Nigeria’s institutions are blossoming despite the recent electoral chaos.

abstract: The former chairman of Simon & Schuster alleged he was not compensated for his role in the $2.6 billion acquisition of the music company three years ago.

headline: Paint Drying? Sorry, Wrong Link. This Is Cheddarvision.
abstract: An aging round of cheddar has become a media sensation in England as the star of Cheddarvision TV, a Web site that carries live images of its life on a shelf.

abstract: Prosecutors say a former Morgan Stanley compliance officer and her husband were part of the largest insider-trading scheme on Wall Street since the 1980s.

headline: Vatican City: Pope Appeals for Help for Africa
abstract: The Vatican announced the release of Benedict XVI’s first book as pope, “Jesus of Nazareth,” to be issued in Italian, German and Polish on his 80th birthday, April 16. The book is the first of two volumes on the life of Jesus Christ, which he has said he began working on in 2003, while still a cardinal. In an excerpt printed in the Italian newspaper Corriere della Sera, Benedict drew modern-day lessons from the Parable of the Good Samaritan, saying that rich nations that had “plundered and sacked” Africa had an obligation to help the world’s poor.

headline: Love Is a Many-Flavored Thing

abstract: The success of free market autocracies is leading intellectuals to back away from the notion that capitalism and democracy need each other to survive.

abstract: Sprint Nextel selected Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, part of the Omnicom Group, for its creative account.

headline: New Ways to Do It Make Giving Away Books a Bit Less Painful
abstract: Parting with treasured books can be hard enough, but then there is the problem of what to do with them.

headline: Sirius Loss Narrows and Beats Estimates
abstract: Sirius Satellite Radio posted a narrower first-quarter loss as the company attracted more subscribers than analysts estimated.

headline: China: Optimism on Pollution
abstract: China has reached a “turning point” in reversing its runaway pollution problems and expects to see reductions in air and water pollution in the coming months, according to Zhang Lijun, a top official with the State Environmental Protection Administration. Mr. Zhang, left, used a news conference to predict that emissions of sulfur dioxide in the air and levels of water pollution measured by a process known as chemical oxygen demand would fall this year. Cutting those areas of pollution are the main indicators in China’s nationwide plan for a 10 percent reduction in pollution by 2010. Last year, China failed to meet its goal of two percent reductions in each category and instead registered small increases. But Mr. Zhang said improvements had become evident after government programs to install pollution technology on coal-fired power plants, as well as the installation of new wastewater treatment equipment. He acknowledged that other pollutants, including ammonia, continued to rise. And greenhouse gas emissions like carbon dioxide are increasing rapidly.

headline: Lehman Profit Climbs 27%
abstract: The second-quarter report, a record for the firm, potentially augurs a good week for Wall Street earnings reports.

headline: Private Equity Deal Expected for Lexicon Pharmaceuticals
abstract: Lexicon Pharmaceuticals is expected to announce on Monday that it has signed deals with two private equity firms.

headline: Citigroup to Eliminate 17,000 Jobs
abstract: The banking giant announced a restructuring plan that eliminates 17,000 jobs and shifts another 9,500 positions overseas.

abstract: Russia called for a meeting with the United States and Europe to discuss the future of a conventional arms treaty from which it has threatened to withdraw.

abstract: The stock market dropped last week on Congressional testimony of Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, on Wednesday.

abstract: A suicide car bomber struck near a bus station in Karbala, a holy city that is a main destination for Shiite pilgrims.

abstract: Last spotted in Cambodia in 2003, nobody knew until now that members of an endangered species from Cantor’s giant soft-shelled turtles still existed.

abstract: A growing number of matchmaking services in South Korea, where families still arrange many marriages, rely heavily on the Internet.

abstract: Officials described overnight rocket attacks from across the Afghan border in the Shawal area of the North Waziristan tribal region of Pakistan.

headline: Japan: Chinese Premier Ends Visit With a Charm Offensive
abstract: Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China wrapped up a three-day visit to Japan, saying that the two nations had “reached broad consensus” on how to move their relations forward but still needed time to resolve their many differences. Mr. Wen spent his last day trying to show the softer side of China’s leadership to Japanese who have grown anxious in recent years of China’s economic rise and growing military strength. Mr. Wen met farmers and played baseball with students at Ritsumeikan University in Kyoto.

abstract: Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black. The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said. DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.

headline: Why Should A Sale Scare Wall Street?
abstract: Why Wall Street Fears A Real Market In Mortgage Securities

headline: Are Airline Bids Like Potato Chips?
abstract: Why did W. Douglas Parker, the chief executive of US Airways, launch a hostile bid for Delta Air Lines so soon after the merger of US Airways and America West? Partly “to maximize value,” he told Fortune magazine’s Barney Gimbel as he was awaiting a decision from Delta’s creditors’ committee in January. “But it’s also kind of fun, too.”

headline: Wall St. Lobby Firm Says It Investigated Former Co-Chief
abstract: Wall Street’s largest and most important trade association acknowledged Wednesday that one of its co-chief executives resigned abruptly earlier this year after an internal investigation uncovered loose financial management by him.

headline: Big Union Takes Skeptical Look at Private Equity
abstract: In Europe, private equity firms are accustomed to feeling the heat from unions. Now, the temperature is rising in the United States as well.

headline: Gates Assures Israel on Plan to Sell Arms to Saudis
abstract: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said the sale would not threaten Israel’s military superiority and was necessary to counter a threat from Iran.

headline: Where Now, for the Wind?
abstract: The staying power of wind energy companies is dependent on tax benefits from the capricious hands of lawmakers in Congress.

headline: A Music Player That Needs Seasoning
abstract: The Sansa Connect offers access to two million songs through Yahoo. Yes, there’s a catch.

headline: Marketers Struggle to Get Folks to Stay Put for the Commercials
abstract: Viacom says it has come up with several new formats to keep its viewers glued to the television set during commercials.

headline: More Than 20 Killed in Pakistani Tribal Region
abstract: What appears to have been a missile attack struck buildings described by Pakistani officials as a training camp for foreign militants near the Afghan border.

headline: Focus of Video Games Shifts to Lure More Casual Players
abstract: By fall, software developers will start introducing offerings aimed at nudging players to bond with Grandma, balance their hormones and eat their peas.

headline: Before the Flight, a Taste of Lounge Life
abstract: Why do some airline lounges offer gourmet meals and spa treatments, while others dole out only soda and stale pretzels?

headline: Israel Wary of U.S. Proposals on Palestinians
abstract: Israeli officials say that some of the American ideas, a set of modest goals to improve relations between Israel and the Palestinians, are unlikely to be implemented.

headline: U.S. and Iranian Officials Meet in Baghdad, but Talks Yield No Breakthroughs
abstract: The United States and Iran held the first high-profile, face-to-face talks in nearly three decades Monday, adhering to an agenda that focused strictly on Iraq.

headline: Battle Over Control of Troops Escalates Political Crisis in Ukraine
abstract: President Viktor A. Yushchenko’s decree in putting Ukraine’s Interior Ministry troops under presidential command has escalated a political crisis.

headline: BHP Billiton Selects a Chief Executive
abstract: BHP Billiton, the mining company, chose the head of its copper and aluminum division, Marius Kloppers, to succeed its American chief executive, Charles W. Goodyear, when Mr. Goodyear steps down Oct. 1. Mr. Goodyear has overseen a wave of record-setting earnings since taking charge of the company in 2003 as the company benefited from a China-led boom in demand for iron and other metals. But in the last two years, soaring prices for copper have fueled BHP’s results. Mr. Kloppers, a 44-year-old South African, played a crucial role in BHP’s merger with Billiton in 2001 and in the $7.6 billion takeover of WMC Resources in 2005.

headline: Trying to Keep the Viewers When the Ads Come On
abstract: The growing popularity of alternatives to watching TV on sets is forcing networks to change their habits.

headline: Before French Vote, Candidate Asks Women to Pick Her
abstract: Ségolène Royal’s plea has been seen as ill-advised, even desperate, to win votes by stressing gender over competence.

headline: As Japan Ages, Universities Struggle to Fill Classrooms
abstract: Japan has one of the oldest systems of higher education in Asia, but its universities are scrambling to find new ways to attract students.

headline: Oversight Report Says U.S. Food Aid Practices Are Wasteful
abstract: Wasteful practices and rising logistical costs have halved the amount of food delivered to the hungry in Africa, Asia and Latin America over the past five years, a report states.

headline: Getting Law Firms to Like Commercials
abstract: Television advertising has long been frowned on in the legal profession. But Spot Runner, an online advertising agency, is trying to change that.

headline: Activists at the Boardroom Door
abstract: Shareholder activism is “threatening the future of American business,” argues Martin Lipton of the New York-based law firm of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz.

headline: Pearson Is Said to Seek a Partner for a Takeover of Dow Jones
abstract: Pearson, the publisher of The Financial Times, is exploring a rival takeover offer for Dow Jones and has discussed a joint bid with G.E. and the Hearst Corporation.

headline: Publisher of Men’s Magazines Is Sold to Private Equity Fund
abstract: Dennis Publishing was acquired for an undisclosed price by the private equity fund, Quadrangle Capital Partners II.

headline: Word of Mouth, and How to Get It
abstract: Providing a great product or service is not enough; you have to have customers talking about it.

headline: Tentative Dow Jones Sale Pact Said to Give Murdoch Power to Hire and Fire at The Journal
abstract: It remains to be seen how the Bancrofts — most of whom have not been told what was in the agreement — will react.

headline: Rate in Europe Held Steady; Currency Rise Stirs Concern
abstract: The European Central Bank signaled that it would lift borrowing costs as early as June to prevent a robust European economy from stoking inflation.

headline: Who Should Run Your Company After You?
abstract: Even small-business owners must tackle the problem of succession.

headline: Hotel Chain Compromises With Publisher After Rejecting Book Over Language
abstract: The Ritz-Carlton chain got cold feet after a short-story collection that it planned to give away turned out to be a tad rougher than, say, the Gideon Bible.

headline: C.I.A. Arrest Warrants Strain U.S.-German Ties
abstract: The arrest warrants German authorities have issued against 10 CIA agents have strained German-American relations. Now, prosecutors in Munich want the agents extradited to Germany so they can stand trial for their alleged roles in the illegal kidnapping of terror suspects.

headline: Cutting Costs While Appearing Savvy
abstract: We live in such an affluent society that you can eliminate plenty of expenses without becoming a cheapskate.

headline: Pizza to Go, Shares to Stay
abstract: Employee Stock Ownership Plans — or ESOPs — provide small-business owners an alternative marketplace for selling equity.

headline: German Industry Would Alter Law Requiring Labor Seats on Boards
abstract: An unusual law that shapes the oversight of German companies is again being re-examined after corruption scandals at Siemens and Volkswagen.

headline: In Corporations They Don’t Trust
abstract: There is a “trust gap between consumers and global corporations,” The McKinsey Quarterly finds.

headline: Sleuth Expands the Case File
abstract: Does the fact that the Web site Sharesleuth published an article about a private company mean that billionaire entrepreneur Mark Cuban has changed his thinking?

headline: How Great Leaders Juggle Ideas
abstract: When we look for ways to improve our life at work or how we can make better decisions, one thing we do is look at what great leaders have done.

headline: Putin Offers Alternatives on Missile Defense
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin suggested that Russia would not object to U.S.  interceptor missiles in Iraq or Turkey.

headline: Training to Be Old
abstract: While financial planning is important, there are also psychological and physical implications to retirement preparation.

headline: Fast Cellphones Aim to Unseat Laptops
abstract: Wireless phone companies are accelerating their rollout of new phones and services.

headline: Shell Settles With Europe on Overstated Oil Reserves
abstract: Shell agreed to pay about $450 million to help resolve legal disputes stemming from its overstatement of oil reserves.

headline: The Industry’s Critics Turn to Washington
abstract: A movement to impose more checks and balances -- to protect the interests of investors -- has been testing its strength in the mutual fund industry.

headline: The Times Names Clark Hoyt as New Public Editor
abstract: Clark Hoyt, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter and editor, was the Washington editor at Knight Ridder from 1999 until the company was sold last year.

headline: Siemens Chief Says He Will Step Down
abstract: Klaus Kleinfeld is the latest casualty in the German engineering company’s widening corruption scandal.

headline: Do Your Homework (or Buy an Index Fund)
abstract: If they’re not willing to switch funds often, fund investors should simply buy and hold an index fund for the long term, according to a new study.

headline: They’ll Keep the Smoking Sign On
abstract: Extended Stay Hotels recently announced it planned to keep its smokers welcome policies in place.

headline: Microsoft, Trying to Avoid a European Fine, Defends Demand for Royalties
