abstract: Microsoft filed documents defending its demand to be paid royalties for releasing some software code to competitors.

headline: Newspaper Circulation in Steep Slide Across Nation
abstract: Despite the slide, two New York City tabloids continued to buck the trend, posting the largest gains among major papers.

headline: The Micro-Mini Startup
abstract: The rise of widgets is letting people build applications and companies with very little investment.

headline: Comcast to Acquire Cable Operator
abstract: Comcast, the nation’s largest cable operator, said Tuesday that it was buying a small New Jersey cable operator for $483 million. Analysts said the price was high in light of the number of subscribers but understandable given the customers’ affluence. The operator being acquired, Patriot Media and Communications, serves 81,000 video subscribers in central New Jersey, many of them in upscale neighborhoods that fit in with Comcast’s service area.

headline: Carlyle Said to Plan Publicly Traded Fund
abstract: Carlyle Group, the private equity giant, plans to file to list its first publicly traded fund by the end of June, BusinessWeek.com’s Deal Flow blog reported, citing people familiar with the transaction. The Washington-based firm will list a leveraged finance fund made up primarily of mortgage-backed securities on the Euronext.

headline: Prosecutors Invite a Dismissal in KPMG Case
abstract: Federal prosecutors trying to bolster their faltering tax-shelter investigation have essentially dared a federal judge to dismiss charges against former employees of the accounting firm KPMG so that they can appeal the ruling and get the case moving again.

headline: Hertz Prices Offering
abstract: Hertz Global Holdings said Wednesday that the offering by certain of its stockholders of 51.8 million shares of its common stock was priced at $22.25 a share. The shares are being sold by the private equity funds Clayton Dubilier & Rice, the Carlyle Group and Merrill Lynch Global Private Equity. Hertz raised $1.32 billion from its initial stock offering, most of which paid for a dividend for owners Clayton Dubilier, Carlyle and Merrill Lynch.

headline: Newspaper Stocks Feel the ‘Murdoch Effect’
abstract: Shares of several newspaper publishing companies posted big gains after Dow Jones disclosed that it received an unsolicited takeover offer from News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch’s global media empire. Dow Jones said Tuesday it was considering the proposal but warned that a deal might not happen; nevertheless, investors bid up shares of its peers, apparently hoping that they might also become takeover targets.

headline: An Idea From Down Under: Law Firm I.P.O.’s
abstract: Given that it’s not legal, American law firms are unlikely to be holding initial public offerings any time soon. But it has already happened in Australia, and, according to American Lawyer, it is apt to happen in Britain within a few years.

headline: Enron, the Supreme Court and Shareholders on the Brink
abstract: The investment banks that helped Enron managers conceal the truth about Enron could get off, but Ben Stein writes in the New York Times that the Supreme Court could correct what he suggests is the mistreatment of shareholders.

headline: Financial Gymnastics: A Spinoff, With a Twist
abstract: There was a time that conglomerates were all the rage. This is not such a time.

headline: Rexam Acquires Plastics Unit
abstract: Rexam, the world’s largest maker of beverage cans, will acquire the plastics business of Owens-Illinois for $1.83 billion, adding as much as 50 percent to its sales in the industry.

headline: WPP Lays Money Down on VideoEgg
abstract: WPP Group, the global advertising and marketing giant, said Monday it had invested $3.5 million for an undisclosed stake in VideoEgg, the online video platform and advertising network company.

headline: Advanced Medical Has Eyes on Bausch & Lomb
abstract: Is a bidding war looming for Bausch & Lomb?

headline: Ecumenicalism and the iPhone
abstract: The words used to describe the iPhone reflect the miraculous qualities conferred unto this electronic device by the fervent Apple acolytes.

headline: Bank of America’s Private Banking Chief to Step Down
abstract: The Bank of America, which expects to complete its $3.3 billion purchase of Charles Schwab‘s U.S. Trust private banking arm this fall. said Thursday that its private banking chief, Jane Magpiong, plans to leave the company.

headline: NYSE Euronext Enters Bidding for Italian Exchange, Report Says
abstract: NYSE Euronext has joined the bidding fray for Italian markets operator Borsa Italiana, which is currently considering an offer from the London Stock Exchange Group reportedly worth $2 billion, according to The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Germany Stands Alone in Battle to Rein in Hedge Funds
abstract: Germany will make a last-ditch effort Friday to persuade the world’s top economic powers to tighten their grip on hedge funds and private equity firms. But even before these countries’ finance ministers convened at a Group of 8 meeting, the push was being written off as futile, illustrating Germany’s isolation in its desire to rein in the booming industry.

headline: Flavio Briatore’s and Jean Todt’s Telling Slips
abstract: During today’s official FIA press conference both Flavio Briatore and Jean Todt showed their true feelings about the loss of their world champion drivers this year, for Renault, Fernando Alonso and for Ferrari, Michael Schumacher.

headline: Real Estate Notes From All Over
abstract: This house did not sell, even with a Ferrarri thrown in.

headline: McClatchy Draws Interest From Big Hedge Fund
abstract: A couple of days after an unusual spike in shares of McClatchy prompted talk — highly speculative talk — that the newspaper chain was a takeover target, there is another intriguing, though inconclusive, development.

headline: Masters of the New Universe
abstract: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

headline: Lehman to Buy Energy Services Firm
abstract: Lehman Brothers said it would acquire Eagle Energy Partners, a Houston-based energy services company, becoming the latest investment bank to bolster its presence in the physical energy markets. “Commodities over the last several years have become a very significant asset class,” Skip McGee, Lehman’s head of global investment banking, told MarketWatch.

headline: Cerberus Said to Consider Bid for Bell Canada
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is also circling.

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Another Swing at Topps
abstract: A New York hedge fund, Crescendo Partners, on Thursday alleged that certain Topps board members have conflicts of interest that prevent the trading card and confection company from negotiating in good faith with its rival, Upper Deck, on a potential acquisition.

headline: Apollo Seeks to Sell Stake to Investors
abstract: Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black. The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said. DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.

headline: Why Should A Sale Scare Wall Street?
abstract: Why Wall Street Fears A Real Market In Mortgage Securities

headline: Are Airline Bids Like Potato Chips?
abstract: Why did W. Douglas Parker, the chief executive of US Airways, launch a hostile bid for Delta Air Lines so soon after the merger of US Airways and America West? Partly “to maximize value,” he told Fortune magazine’s Barney Gimbel as he was awaiting a decision from Delta’s creditors’ committee in January. “But it’s also kind of fun, too.”

headline: Wall St. Lobby Firm Says It Investigated Former Co-Chief
abstract: Wall Street’s largest and most important trade association acknowledged Wednesday that one of its co-chief executives resigned abruptly earlier this year after an internal investigation uncovered loose financial management by him.

headline: Big Union Takes Skeptical Look at Private Equity
abstract: In Europe, private equity firms are accustomed to feeling the heat from unions. Now, the temperature is rising in the United States as well.

headline: A little night racing
abstract: Night racing in Formula One has been one of the big topics of the year, with the idea of doing a night race in Singapore or other circuits in Asia in order to bring the races closer to prime time in Europe, rather than having viewers have to wak up at between 4 and 8 in the morning to watch a race.

headline: Orbitz Prospectus Gets Mixed Reviews
abstract: The online travel site Orbitz Worldwide “isn’t a bad company,” Kevin Kelleher writes on GigaOM.com. It is nevertheless a contender for “the worst I.P.O. candidate of the year,” he concludes.

headline: For One Hedge Fund, April Was the Cruelest Month
abstract: For all the talk about how hedge funds are raking in cash and earning double-digit returns all the time, it’s helpful to remember that they can lose — and lose big. Witness the letter that Jurg Buhler, managing director of Dighton Capital, recently sent to investors in his small ($34 million) fund registered in the Cayman Islands.

headline: In Tribune Deal, Possible Conflicts Ran Deep
abstract: In many multibillion-dollar deals, conflicts of interest are an unavoidable way of life. The multiple roles that Merrill Lynch and Citigroup played in the $8.2 billion sale of Tribune — advising the company in the sale process as well as providing financing to the winning bidder, Samuel Zell — show these conflicts on a grand scale, DealBook wrote in a column in Sunday’s New York Times. Tribune, a publishing and broadcasting giant, did take steps to preserve objectivity, forming a special committee and hiring an outside adviser. But the situation still raises questions about whether Mr. Zell was given a privileged seat at the negotiating table.

headline: Building a Hedge Fund, With No Manager Required
abstract: The New Yorker’s John Cassidy this week takes a close look at the mystique of hedge funds, and, in a way, sees an industry that would rather not let you look behind its curtain.

headline: A War of the Quotes for Motorola and Icahn
abstract: In its proxy fight with billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn, Motorola is giving as good as its getting. One day after Mr. Icahn used a full-page ad in The Wall Street Journal to compare comments by Motorola chief executive Ed Zander to “something straight out of Alice in Wonderland,” Motorola is trying a similar strategy of using its adversary’s words against him.

headline: Amp’d Mobile Seeks Bankruptcy Protection
abstract: Amp’d Mobile, a niche cellphone startup that raised $360 million from backers including MTV Networks and Universal Music, has filed for bankruptcy protection to restructure its business.

headline: Bristol’s Court Victory May Inspire Suitors
abstract: Shares of Bristol-Myers Squibb jumped nearly 5 percent Tuesday after a judge upheld the patent on Plavix, a lucrative anticlotting drug that it co-markets with Sanofi-Aventis. The ruling was not a surprise: The judge had been sending signals all along that he was inclined to rule in Bristol-Myers’s favor.

headline: Bid in Hand, Intelsat Looks for More
abstract: Intelsat, which runs the world’s largest network of communications satellites, has been put up for sale by the private equity funds that own it, according to The New York Times. And they apparently have the Blackstone Group to thank for giving them the idea.

headline: Citigroup’s Sporting Deal for Hedge Fund
abstract: Citigroup‘s announcement Friday that it will buy hedge fund Old Lane Partners and bring its founder, former top Morgan Stanley banker Vikram S.Pandit, on board, unleashed a a wave of sport metaphors. The New York Times notes that Citigroup is paying a steep price — estimated at between $600 million and $800 million to win Mr. Pandit to its alternative investments division.

headline: Australia’s Publishing & Broadcasting to Split Gaming, Media Assets
abstract: Australia’s richest man, James Packer, will split his Publishing & Broadcasting empire into two listed gaming and media companies and return 2 billion Australian dollars ($1.7 billion) to shareholders, sending the firm’s stock up 6 percent, Reuters reported Tuesday. Mr. Packer, who took control of Publishing and Broadcasting following the death of his father, said he would separate the company’s fast-expanding gaming and casino operations from its traditional businesses of television and magazines to raise the stock price and pursue growth.

headline: From the Banking World, More Bitter Beach Reading
abstract: Bankers can be forgiven for being very careful about what they say around the office. Acid-laced books, both fictional and nonfictional, written by former employees of investment banks, seem to have replaced drug-strewn memoirs as the current era’s “it” genre.

headline: Apple Shareholders to Vote on Compensation Proposals
abstract: Even as its stock is riding high off the success of the iPod and anticipation of the iPhone, Apple will face some restive shareholders at its annual meeting Thursday, TheStreet.com reported. Labor unions who own Apple shares through pension funds, have put up proposals that require options to be priced on the day they are granted to eliminate the practice known as backdating; that give investors a nonbinding vote on executive compensation, known as “say on pay”; and that tie executive bonuses to the company’s stock performance.

headline: Google v. Microsoft: What’s the Better Workplace?
abstract: Circulating online, the thoughts of an employee who’s worked at both places, comparing the offices, pay and perks.

headline: Former Edocare Executives Charged With Fraud
abstract: Two former executives at Endocare, a medical products company based in Irvine, Calif., were indicted Monday for allegedly helping to inflate company revenue in a fraud that cost investors more than $200 million. A former chief executive, Paul W. Mikus, and a former chief financial officer, John V. Cracchiolo, were charged with wire fraud, securities fraud, filing false statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission and lying to Endocare’s accountants.

headline: Chicago Is Major Battleground for ABN Amro Bid War
abstract: To paraphrase William Carlos Williams, so much depends upon a Chicago bank.

headline: Clear Channel Postpones Shareholder Vote on Buyout
abstract: Clear Channel Communications, owner of the largest network of radio stations in the nation, on Monday postponed a shareholder vote on a revised buyout offer by two private equity firms.

headline: Fishing for a Buyer, Trump Entertainment Gets Some Nibbles
abstract: Trump Entertainment Resorts, the casino company controlled by Donald J. Trump, has received preliminary offers from possible buyers, although details on who the potential suitors might be were not disclosed.

headline: Is Ford Gearing Up to Sell Volvo?
abstract: After unloading its Aston Martin brand in March for $925 million, Ford Motor might be gearing up to sell another unit in its luxury division. According to reports, the money-losing car maker is planning to sell Volvo, possibly to BMW of Germany.

headline: Xstrata Raises Bid for LionOre
abstract: Xstrata, a Swiss mining company, increased a cash offer for LionOre Mining International by 35 percent, to 6.2 billion Canadian dollars ($5.6 billion), to top a bid from Russia’s Norilsk Nickel.

headline: For New BP Chief, Rusted Pipes and a Tarnished Image
abstract: Tony Hayward’s honeymoon is likely to be quite brief.

headline: Financial Adviser Sentenced to 5 Years for Fraud
abstract: Martin A. Armstrong, the financial adviser who has spent seven years in jail for contempt of court, was sentenced Tuesday to five additional years in prison for running what prosecutors say was a $3 billion Ponzi scheme. Judge John F. Keenan of the Southern District of New York also ordered Mr. Armstrong to pay restitution to the fraud victims, who are to receive $80 million — plus one dollar more — from Mr. Armstrong and others involved in the alleged scheme.

headline: For Advice on Pay, the New Money Turns to Wall Street
abstract: By ERIC DASH

headline: Bausch & Lomb to Go Private in $4.5 Billion Deal
abstract: Sometimes, unsubstantiated deal chatter is right on the money.

headline: Internet Start-Up Gets Debt Financing from Hercules
abstract: Hercules Technology Growth Capital said on Monday it had provided $22.5 million of debt financing to Ikano Communications, a provider of Internet services. Hercules is a specialty finance company providing growth capital to venture capital and private equity backed technology and life science companies.

headline: Broadcasters’ Research Firm Slams XM-Sirius Deal
abstract: The Carmel Group, the influential research firm whose analysis helped kill the 2003 merger of EchoStar and DirecTV, will release a new report Tuesday that outlines the strongest arguments yet against merging satellite radio companies Sirius and XM, The New York Post reported. Sponsored by the National Association of Broadcasters, which has already come out against the deal, the 11-page independent white paper includes a point-by-point rebuttal to the six main arguments put forth by Sirius and XM in favor of a merger.

headline: Dow Chemical Insists It Isn’t for Sale
abstract: Wall Street’s collective heart was set aflutter earlier Monday after a report from a British newspaper said that Dow Chemical would be the target of a $50 billion leveraged buyout. If true, the deal would have been the biggest trophy yet for private equity firms, two of whom have not even completed the $45 billion takeover of TXU, the Texas energy giant.

headline: Being Goldman Sachs’ Mr. Blankfein
abstract: While Goldman Sachs is the most imitated, envied and at times griped-about investment bank around, its chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, is still intent on proving himself and his firm to the world, writes The New York Times’ Jenny Anderson, who in her profile describes Mr. Blankfein as a far cry from central casting’s idea of a chief executive.

headline: Simons Antes Up for Buyout Fund
abstract: James Simons, founder of the hedge fund Renaissance Technologies and a top earner in his field, is putting some of his cash into a new leveraged buyout fund, according to Long Island Business News. Mr. Simons, who led Alpha Magazine’s list of the top 25 hedge fund earners, is the largest investor in a new $115 million leveraged buyout fund raised by Topspin Partners, the report said.

headline: Blackstone: Tax Law Could Shrink Firm’s Valuation
abstract: Just how much of a hit would Blackstone Group take if, as two United States senators have proposed, it had to pay the same tax rate as other publicly traded companies?

headline: Heidfeld’s Nurburgring ride nearly dominates the Friday press conference
abstract: The Friday press conference returned to a discussion of Nick Heidfeld’s drive on the Nordschleife last month. That is significant. The questions came not only from the official FIA interviewer, but from journalists and…another driver.

headline: V.C.’s Just Can’t Get Enough Clean Tech
abstract: Recently published research confirms what any venture capital investor would tell you: clean tech is hot.

headline: Paulson Criticizes Bills Raising Buyout Taxes
abstract: Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. warned that raising taxes on hedge funds and buyout firms may have “unintended consequences” and said Congress shouldn’t target firms that go public, such as the Blackstone Group, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Barclays Agrees to Buy ABN Amro in $91 Billion Deal
abstract: ABN Amro, the largest Dutch bank, said Monday it had agreed to be acquired by Barclays of Britain in a $91 billion deal that would be the largest financial-services merger in history. To fend off a rival group of bidders seeking to break up the 183-year-old bank, ABN Amro and Barclays struck a separate agreement Sunday to sell the LaSalle Bank of Chicago, a unit of ABN, to the Bank of America for more than $21 billion.

headline: Fund Presses Pier 1 to Close Stores
abstract: Elliott Associates has some advice for Pier 1 Imports, and it isn’t decorating tips.

headline: Ferrari’s Surprise Move
abstract: Just when everyone expected to arrive at the first European race of the season – notice I avoid using that phrase “the start of the European season,” since this particular European season will only last two races before the circus moves on for the start of the North American season?! – and everyone expected to see all sorts of new motor homes representing various states of team dreams of grandeur…and when everyone expected that the most ostentatious display of the motor home art would likely come from McLaren, it turns out that the greatest example of motor home decadence yet to appear in the paddock comes from the team one least expected to see it come from: Ferrari. (That run-on Jamesian sentence, by the way, would be accept nowhere else today outside this blog…. My apologies.)

headline: Asking the Crowd to Spread the News
abstract: “Web 2.0,” as I understand it, refers to Web sites whose contents are supplied by us, the people. What would Flickr be without its photos, YouTube without the videos, Craigslist without the ads, eBay without the auctions, TripAdvisor without people’s travel reviews? These mega-sites would be only empty white pages if the audience didn’t supply their materials.

headline: Advertising Group WPP Takes 24/7 Real Media
abstract: A week after confirming that it hired an investment bank to explore “strategic alternatives,” 24/7 Real Media has decided that a sale is the way to go. The company, which provides online marketing services, said it agreed to be bought by advertising and marketing firm WPP Group for $11.75 per share in cash, or about $649 million net of cash acquired. The sale of 24/7 is just the latest in a string of deals involving online advertising companies: Google recently bought DoubleClick for $3.1 billion, and Yahoo  paid $680 million for the part of Right Media that it didn’t already own.

headline: Harrah’s Shareholders Approve $17 Billion Buyout
abstract: Harrah’s Entertainment shareholders approved a $17.1 billion buyout by two private equity groups Thursday in the largest deal ever to take a publicly held casino company private, officials said. Shareholders controlling 66 percent of outstanding stock approved selling Harrah’s, the world’s largest casino company, to the Apollo Management Group and the Texas Pacific Group, Harrah’s officials announced. Harrah’s board had unanimously recommended approval.

headline: Warner’s Third EMI Bid May Go Right to Investors
abstract: The Warner Music Group is considering a merger with EMI by making a direct appeal to shareholders to undermine the opposition of EMI’s management, The Times of London reported on Sunday. The EMI board last month rejected what it described as a “preconditional offer” at 260 pence per share. Any deal between the two companies, which rank No. 3 and No. 4 in recorded music sales, would require clearance by competition regulators.

headline: Weighing in on the Next Buyout Targets: Cramer
abstract: The market pundit Jim Cramer apparently wants to help the little guy get into the private equity action.

headline: Investment Bankers and The China Syndrome
abstract: After the Lenovo Group acquired I.B.M.‘s personal-computer division two years ago, many investment bankers started to believe that Chinese companies would soon increase their overseas acquisitions. And they have — but not by much, Reuters reports. The analysis of China’s buying habits comes amid a steep selloff in the Chinese stock markets, volatility that could make it even harder for Chinese firms to broker cross-border deals.

headline: Loews to Acquire Gas Assets from Dominion for $4 Billion
abstract: The conglomerate Loews said on Monday it would buy gas exploration and production assets in three states from Dominion Resources for $4.025 billion in cash, betting on rising natural gas prices as it diversifies its revenue stream. The company said it will retain Dominion’s existing management, led by Timothy Parker, a senior vice president of exploration and production.

headline: Hedge Funds to Manage Part of Illinois Teachers’ Pension
abstract: The Illinois Teachers’ Retirement System said Friday it would allocate more than $1.6 billion of its $39.7 billion pension fund to hedge funds strategies and $425 million to private equity firms as part of a new fund manager mix. Among those chosen to help manage the funds were the hedge funds Bridgewater Associates and AQR Capital Management as well as fund-of-fund groups K2 Advisors and Grosvenor Capital Management.

headline: The Myth of (the Original) Cerberus
abstract: It has forged a historic deal to buy Chrysler for $7.4 billion, one of most audacious deals in private equity’s history. It has taken stakes in 50 companies around the world, often after bare-knuckled negotiations. It has even purchased Remington Arms and Bushmaster Firearms, two of the top makers of so-called black rifles, styled after the assault weapons used by the military.

headline: Nacchio Jury Ends 3rd Day of Deliberations
abstract: Jurors went home Monday after a third day of deliberations in the $101 million insider trading trial of Joe Nacchio, the former head of Qwest Communications International. “You’ve put in another long day so I’m going to let you go home for the evening,” the presiding Judge, Edward W. Nottingham, of United States District Court, said.

headline: Longtime Hollinger Partner Says He Diverted Millions
abstract: Conrad M. Black’s longtime business partner, F. David Radler, testified Tuesday at Mr. Black’s criminal fraud trial that the two men conspired to divert millions of dollars of payments for assets of the newspaper company Hollinger International.

headline: G.E., Dow Jones and the MSNBC Factor
abstract: As General Electric casts around for partners in a possible rival bid for Dow Jones, its chief executive, Jeffrey Immelt, might want to keep five letters in the back of his mind: MSNBC.

headline: Nasdaq Plans Market for VC’s
abstract: The Nasdaq Stock Market plans to offer venture capitalists and other private equity players a new avenue to liquidity when it rolls out a computerized trading platform intended to market private placements to institutional investors, such as mutual funds and pension funds, The Red Herring reported.

headline: Who’s Next: Regional Brokers
abstract: After learning of Wachovia‘s plan to buy A.G. Edwards for $6.8 billion, Wall Street immediately set about betting on which regional brokerage firms might be acquired next.

headline: Genzyme Buys Out Bioenvision Stake in Drug Venture
abstract: As part of its push to become a bigger player in cancer drugs, Genzyme said Wednesday that it would buy out a business partner, Bioenvision, for $345 million, consolidating its ownership of a cancer treatment to which the two companies had been sharing rights.

headline: Friendly Sale Ends Not-So-Friendly Battle Within
abstract: Friendly Ice Cream‘s decision to sell the Northeast chain, known for its Fribble milkshake, to a private equity firm has headed off a proxy battle showdown and ended a lawsuit filed by the company’s cofounder that accused Friendly’s chairman of mismanagement.

headline: Indian Miner to Raise $1.65 Billion in U.S. and Japan Offerings
abstract: A copper and zinc miner, Vedanta Resources, is raising $1.65 billion through a share offering in the United States and Japan by its main subsidiary, Sterlite Industries. The proceeds of the offer will be used to fund a move into power generation and to buy back a minority shareholding in its zinc business from the Indian government.

headline: Friedman Billings to Hive Off Capital Markets Unit in I.P.O.
abstract: Investment banking firm Friedman Billings Ramsey Group plans to raise as much as $243.3 million through an initial public offering of its capital markets subsidiary. The bank will sell up to 13.5 million shares of its FBR Capital Markets unit at a price of $16 to $18 each, the bank said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Candidates, Meet Your Corporate Twins
abstract: With all the hype and analysis surrounding presidential candidates’ quarterly fund-raising reports, Slate’s Dan Gross has decided to cut to the chase and start matching the contenders with the actual corporations he thinks they resemble most. Try to figure out which candidates are the steady but staid juggernauts, the rock-star upstarts and, well, Halliburton.

headline: J.P. Morgan Expands Boston Operations
abstract: J.P. Morgan Chase said it plans to add up to 100 people to its mutual fund services division in Boston and move the unit to new space downtown. The financial services giant said it has hired more than 150 for the Boston group since last year, which now numbers 450 and provides custody, accounting, and investment operations for mutual fund companies.

headline: Few Choices for Workers at Dow Jones
abstract: Looking at the potential bidders for Dow Jones & Company – Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation and a joint effort by General Electric and Pearson – some reporters and editors at The Wall Street Journal are calling the decision a choice between “trash or slash.” And they are wondering which might be worse.

headline: When Lawyers Bring Conflicts to the Table
abstract: When it comes to throwing brickbats, DealBook doesn’t discriminate.

headline: Will the iPhone Get Cheaper?
abstract: A look at Apple’s pricing strategy

headline: Weekend Project: Steve Jobs’s Other Thing
abstract: How to spend your time when you aren’t blogging.

headline: McClatchy Draws Interest From Big Hedge Fund
abstract: A couple of days after an unusual spike in shares of McClatchy prompted talk — highly speculative talk — that the newspaper chain was a takeover target, there is another intriguing, though inconclusive, development.

headline: Masters of the New Universe
abstract: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

headline: Lehman to Buy Energy Services Firm
abstract: Lehman Brothers said it would acquire Eagle Energy Partners, a Houston-based energy services company, becoming the latest investment bank to bolster its presence in the physical energy markets. “Commodities over the last several years have become a very significant asset class,” Skip McGee, Lehman’s head of global investment banking, told MarketWatch.

headline: Cerberus Said to Consider Bid for Bell Canada
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is also circling.

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Another Swing at Topps
abstract: A New York hedge fund, Crescendo Partners, on Thursday alleged that certain Topps board members have conflicts of interest that prevent the trading card and confection company from negotiating in good faith with its rival, Upper Deck, on a potential acquisition.

headline: Apollo Seeks to Sell Stake to Investors
abstract: Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black. The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said. DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.

headline: Why Should A Sale Scare Wall Street?
abstract: Why Wall Street Fears A Real Market In Mortgage Securities

headline: Are Airline Bids Like Potato Chips?
abstract: Why did W. Douglas Parker, the chief executive of US Airways, launch a hostile bid for Delta Air Lines so soon after the merger of US Airways and America West? Partly “to maximize value,” he told Fortune magazine’s Barney Gimbel as he was awaiting a decision from Delta’s creditors’ committee in January. “But it’s also kind of fun, too.”

headline: Wall St. Lobby Firm Says It Investigated Former Co-Chief
abstract: Wall Street’s largest and most important trade association acknowledged Wednesday that one of its co-chief executives resigned abruptly earlier this year after an internal investigation uncovered loose financial management by him.

headline: Big Union Takes Skeptical Look at Private Equity
abstract: In Europe, private equity firms are accustomed to feeling the heat from unions. Now, the temperature is rising in the United States as well.

headline: China Adds Billionaires With I.P.O.
abstract: After more than two decades of spectacular economic growth, China has a rising number of entrepreneurs who are forming private companies, going public and getting extremely rich. But the family of Yang Guoqiang, a dirt-under-the-fingers property tycoon, may be the richest yet.

headline: Novartis Leads $13.4 Million Round for MicroChips
abstract: MicroChips has secured $13.4 million in a round of funding led by the Novartis Venture Fund, the venture capital arm of Swiss drug giant Novartis. Other investors include CSK Venture Capital of Japan, Polaris Venture Partners, IDG Ventures, Medtronic, Boston Scientific, and the Boston University Community Technology Fund.

headline: Midwest Air Urges Shareholders to Delay Decision on AirTran Bid
abstract: The Midwest Air Group‘s board asked shareholders on Monday to hold off on responding to AirTran Holdings‘ revised bid for the airline. In a statement, the board said it would review the new offer of $15 ashare in cash and stock, and would make a recommendation to shareholders by April 13.

headline: Bear Stearns Won’t Bail Out Second Subprime Fund, Report Says
abstract: Bear Stearns does not plan to bail out a $1.1 billion struggling fund that invests in repackaged subprime-mortgage securities, Reuters reported Tuesday citing an unnamed source.

headline: Tax Increase Batters Chinese Stocks
abstract: Chinese stock markets plummeted Wednesday and continued their decline in early trading Thursday after the authorities in Beijing moved to impose higher taxes on trading activity.

headline: ESL Is Said to Seek Billions in New Investments
abstract: With private equity and hedge funds in the ascendant and investors clamoring to get in, what better time for one of the top figures in alternative investments to trawl for more money?

headline: Ion Board Urges NBC and Citadel to Raise Their Bid
abstract: The board of Ion Media Networks is pushing the media giant NBC Universal and the hedge fund Citadel Investment Group to raise their already-sweetened takeover offer before a deadline next month that could plunge the troubled TV network into bankruptcy, the New York Post reported, citing sources it did not identify.

headline: NBC and Citadel Increase Ion Bid
abstract: NBC Universal and the hedge fund Citadel Investment Group have increased their takeover bid for Ion Media Networks in an attempt to appease a disgruntled investor group. That group, which includes AIG and Gradient Partners, were upset over the original bid, which they saw as short-changing preferred shareholders.

headline: After Nuveen, Who’s Next?
abstract: Have private equity firms found a new place to spend their overflowing buyout funds?

headline: Buyout Group Abandons Qantas Bid
abstract: The buyout group bidding for Qantas Airways of Australia on Tuesday declared its offer of 11 billion Australian dollars ($9 billion) had lapsed after deciding not to pursue a legal case to keep the takeover alive. The group, Airline Partners Australia, said it believed “that Qantas shareholders need more certainty and, accordingly, it has determined that its bid should be treated as having lapsed on May 4, 2007.”

headline: France’s Areva Bids $2.3 Billion for Uranium Producer
abstract: The French nuclear giant Areva has presented a cash bid worth 2.5 billion Canadian dollars ($2.3 billion) for UraMin, a South Africa-headquartered company interlisted on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Areva said Friday it is bidding 7.75 Canadian dollars per share for UraMin stock, which closed Thursday at 7.94 Canadian dollars.

headline: DoubleClick May Entice Buyers With Ad Exchange
abstract: If Google and Microsoft are circling DoubleClick — a bidding feud that has been reported but never acknowledged by any of the parties — it may be based partly on a new initiative that the online advertising firm announced Wednesday.

headline: Accounting Rule Is Eased for Foreign Companies
abstract: Federal regulators tentatively agreed Wednesday to ease an accounting requirement for foreign companies that trade on United States exchanges. The move comes amid concerns that U.S. stock markets are losing out to overseas competitors due, in part, to what critics see as a overly-burdensome regulatory environment.

headline: Salesforce Launches Start-Up Incubator
abstract: Marc Benioff, the chief executive of Salesforce.com, a provider of online customer management software, is opening the company’s first incubator for start-ups that are developing online software that complements that of Salesforce, BusinessWeek reports.

headline: Hologic’s $6.2 Billion Deal Cytyc Deal Aimed at Women
abstract: Patrick J. Sullivan, the chief executive of the Cytyc Corporation, and Jack W. Cumming, the chief of Hologic, like to joke about their companies splitting the geography of the female body. Hologic, a leader in breast cancer diagnostics, focuses on the top half, while Cytyc, a leader in diagnostics for cervical cancer, focuses on the bottom half.

headline: Friendly’s Delays Shareholder Meeting Amid Proxy Fight
abstract: Friendly Ice Cream, the struggling restaurant chain, postponed next week’s annual shareholder meeting, delaying a showdown with activist investors who are trying to gain more control of the company. Friendly said its executives needed more time for a review of the company’s strategic alternatives, including a possible sale of the business, that was disclosed in March.

headline: Whole Foods to Unload Wild Oats Stake to Apollo
abstract: Whole Foods Market, the largest American natural-foods grocer, agreed yesterday to sell 35 of Wild Oats Markets‘ stores to the private equity firm Apollo Management.

headline: Scrushy Cuts a Deal
abstract: Richard Scrushy has cut a deal that leaves open the possibility he could be hired at a public company again. But who would hire him?

headline: Who Got Burned in the Amp’d Flameout
abstract: In March, when Amp’d Mobile announced what would soon prove to be its last round of venture capital — the last in its current incarnation anyway — DealBook noted that the company “apparently knows how to push the right buttons with venture investors.” Three months later, the exceptionally well-funded reseller of wireless phone service (it raised $350 million from investors including MTV Networks) has pushed the panic button, filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection Friday in a move that will almost certainly leave some venture backers a lot poorer.

headline: Hedge Funds and Private Equity: An Uneasy Alliance?
abstract: Hedge funds and private equity funds seem to have a good routine going, with activist funds goading many companies into buyout deals and then buying the debt used to fund them. But Thorold Barker of The Financial Times cautions that this symbiosis could unravel if and when many of these big buyout deals start to go bad.

headline: L.S.E. May Offer $2 Billion for Italian Rival, Report Says
abstract: The London Stock Exchange is planning to offer about 1.5 billion euros ($2.01 billion) for Borsa Italiana, Reuters reported Thursday citing an unnamed source. The deal would value the Borsa, which is privately-owned by Italian banks, above the 1.2 billion to 1.4 billion euros valuation placed on it last year when the Milan-based bourse planned for an initial public offering.

headline: The Billion-Dollar Hedge Fund Club
abstract: The latest ranking of the top-paid hedge fund managers has reignited a debate about just what these guys (and on this list, they are all guys) are doing, and whether it is worth all that money.

headline: Ex-Merrill Executive’s Enron Appeal Is Denied
abstract: A former executive at Merrill Lynch whose Enron-related fraud and conspiracy convictions were overturned last year by an appeals panel will remain a felon on two other counts. On Monday, the Supreme Court declined, without comment, to review the 2004 convictions of perjury and obstruction of justice in a jury trial against the executive, James Brown.

headline: MAF Deal Puts Wind in National City’s Chicago Sails
abstract: One possible suitor may be out of the battle over ABN Amro‘s LaSalle Bank, the Chicago institution that its Dutch parent agreed to sell to Bank of America for $21 billion.

headline: Coca-Cola Buys Stake in a Bottler in Tokyo
abstract: Coca-Cola will buy a 34 percent stake in the Tokyo Coca-Cola Bottling Company to increase sales in Japan after volume declined last year. The Japanese subsidiary of Coca-Cola will buy new shares of the closely held Tokyo-based bottler, the companies said in a statement. The financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: BP and Rio Tinto Team Up for Venture
abstract: The Rio Tinto Group, a mining company that is a major producer of coal, will join BP to develop power generation plants that will pump their carbon dioxide emissions underground to help curb global warming. The companies said Thursday that Rio would pay BP $32 million for a 50 percent stake in a new company, to be called Hydrogen Energy. BP will fold its carbon capture and storage operations into the new entity.

headline: Dominion to Sell Oil and Gas Assets for $6.5 Billion
abstract: Dominion Resources said Monday it agreed to sell most of its onshore oil and gas exploration business to holding company Loew’s Corporation and XTO Energy for about $6.5 billion.

headline: Severstal’s Mordashov Settles for Reduced Dividend
abstract: Russian billionaire Alexey Mordashov is set to receive a $324 million dividend from his steel company Severstal. With his worth estimated at $8.5 billion, Mr. Mordashov was recently ranked Russia’s seventh richest man by Forbes magazine. Although pre-tax profits at Severstal fell to $1.75 billion for 2006, Mr. Mordashov said the company’s outlook for 2007 was positive. He added: “We will continue to drive value through strong organic growth and a disciplined approach to M&A.”

headline: S.E.C. Is Said to Open Inquiry into Bear Stearns Fund
abstract: Bear Stearns may have a lot of explaining to do about a big restatement of losses at one of its troubled hedge funds-and not just to its investors. According to BusinessWeek, the Securities and Exchange Commission recently opened a preliminary inquiry into the near-collapse of Bear Stearns’ High-Grade Structured Credit Strategies Enhanced Leveraged Fund.

headline: Alitalia Seeks Another Suitor After Aeroflot Withdraws
abstract: The Italian government was dealt a setback on Wednesday in its efforts to find a suitor to rescue Alitalia, the nation’s flagship carrier, after Aeroflot of Russia abandoned its bid to buy the airline.

headline: Crunching Numbers on Data Domain’s I.P.O.
abstract: Data Domain has filed for an initial public offering of as much as $100 million in stock, despite a choppy market for tech I.P.O.’s. The 451 Group, an analyst firm, assesses the outlook for the venture-backed data deduplication specialist, which some have touted as the ‘next Network Appliance.’

headline: Citigroup’s Hedge Fund Head Steps Down
abstract: A Citigroup executive, Dean S. Barr, resigned Wednesday as head of the bank’s hedge funds less than a week after the bank agreed to buy a hedge fund, Old Lane Partners, and name its co-founder, Vikram S. Pandit, to oversee alternative investments including private equity. Mr. Barr also resigned as chief executive of the bank’s Tribeca global management unit, Citigroup said Wednesday in a memorandum to employees.

headline: Activists Keep Pressure on TD Ameritrade
abstract: Raising the pressure in their campaign to have TD Ameritrade Holding join with another brokerage, hedge funds Jana Partners and SAC Capital sent the brokerage firm a letter Thursday demanding company records and urging Ameritrade to exclude directors appointed by its largest shareholder, Canada’s TD Bank, from merger discussions.

headline: Roche Strikes $600 Million Deal for BioVeris
abstract: The health care company Roche Holding agreed to buy BioVeris for $600 million to expand its medical testing business. The move strengthens Roche’s position in diagnostics, where it is already a global leader. BioVeris said it had agreed to be acquired for $21.50 a share, a 58 percent premium to Tuesday’s closing price of $13.60. The purchase will allow Roche to expand its immunochemistry business from human diagnostics into segments like life science research, patient self-testing, veterinary testing, drug discovery, drug development and clinical trials.

headline: AT&T Chief Executive to Retire
abstract: Edward E. Whitacre Jr., who led an aggressive acquisition strategy that built AT&T into the world’s largest telephone company, said Friday he will retire as AT&T’s chairman and chief executive on June 3. The announcement comes just a few months after AT&T completed its $86 billion purchase of BellSouth, which was the largest deal of 2006. Mr. Whitacre will be succeeded by Randall L. Stephenson, currently the company’s chief operating officer, who is expected to focus on execution and integration at the company, The New York Times’s Matt Richtel reported. Investors and analysts said they were not surprised by the change in command.

headline: V.C.-Backed Pure Digital Aims for YouTube Users
abstract: Pure Digital, a tech firm with some impressive financial backing, is hoping to piggyback on the success of YouTube and other online video sites with a new, inexpensive camcorder geared to older consumers who may not be as tech-savvy as their kids.

headline: Buyout Battle for EGL Rages On
abstract: The battle for EGL continued over the weekend, with a company backed by Apollo Management offering $1.95 billion, or $46 a share, Saturday, to top a sweetened management-led buyout proposal for the company.

headline: G.M. Pledges GMAC Stake for $4 Billion Credit Line
abstract: General Motors has put up a 49 percent stake in its former financial arm as collateral for a $4.1 billion revolving line of credit, the company said late Wednesday. It also announced plans to replace $1.1 billion in convertible securities with new ones with a later maturity date. After the announcement, Fitch Ratings cut its debt rating for G.M. deeper into junk territory, citing increased leverage from new financing efforts. Separately, G.M. said it received a new request from the Securities and Exchange Commission for information about its accounting practices.

headline: Citadel’s Next Venture: Funding New Hedge Funds
abstract: Citadel Investment Group, the giant hedge fund, has hedged its businesses over the years, expanding from convertible arbitrage into options market-making and, now, an incubator for other hedge funds. Financial News takes a look at Citadel Alternative Asset Management, the new fund of hedge funds business that will also seed new managers.

headline: With Zenter Deal, Google Makes Its Own PowerPoint
abstract: Google has acquired an online slide presentation company, Zenter, filling out its web-based office software portfolio with an application similar to Microsoft‘s popular PowerPoint.

headline: French Director’s Production Company Prices I.P.O.
abstract: EuropaCorp, the film production company founded by the French director Luc Besson, set a price range on Tuesday for a stock market listing, which it said would raise more than 70 million euros ($94.2 million).

headline: A New Pecking Order for Private Equity
abstract: Who is the world’s biggest private equity firm?

headline: Is the Key to Dow Jones in the Bancrofts’ Wallets?
abstract: Given his repeated entreaties to the Bancroft family and his recent promises to shield The Wall Street Journal’s newsroom from his own meddling as owner, News Corporation chief Rupert Murdoch seems almost desperate to buy Dow Jones. He has written three letters to pitch his proposal and offered to hold tetes-a-tetes with the family members, who have a controlling stake in the company — all this on top of the rich premium contained in his $5 billion offer. But there is something else the media mogul can do, according to Breakingviews: Throw more bags of money at the Bancrofts, while leaving common shareholders with his current offer.

headline: Russian Billionaire Buys Stake in Lyondell Chemical
abstract: News that a Russian-born billionaire is buying a stake in Houston’s Lyondell Chemical fueled an 11 percent surge in shares of the company on Friday in anticipation of a possible takeover.

headline: A Blackstone Retirement: No Jet, But Maybe a Book?
abstract: Given the pecuniary hugeness of pretty much everything having to do with Blackstone Group, the retirement perks for senior chairman Peter Peterson — disclosed Thursday in a “founding member agreement” attached to a Blackstone regulatory filing — seem downright modest.

headline: Union Negotiations May Hold Up Chrysler Sale
abstract: A deal to sell the Chrysler Group likely will get tied up in the upcoming contract negotiations between Detroit automakers and the United Auto Workers, according to the Detroit Free Press. That means a final deal to sell Chrysler is unlikely to be made before Sept. 14, the day the labor contract expires, complicating both the talks for a new labor agreement and negotiations with DaimlerChrysler to sell its United States operations.

headline: Bear Chief Faces Task of Saving Firm’s Name
abstract: James E. Cayne has a bellyache. And it is not from the crash diet that has caused Mr. Cayne, the chief executive of Bear Stearns, to shed 20 pounds over the last year.

headline: RBC Capital to Buy Ohio Bond Firm
abstract: Royal Bank of Canada‘s investment banking arm said it would acquire Seasongood & Mayer, a municipal bond firm based in Cincinnati, for an undisclosed price. RBC Capital Markets said in a news release that the deal, which it expects to close in the second quarter, would bolster its position in the municipal investment banking market in the United States.

headline: Alexandra Investment Gets a New Partner
abstract: A hedge fund, Alexandra Investment Management, said on Friday it was hiring John Hock as president and partner.

headline: Microsoft Picks Up Data Management Firm
abstract: Microsoft said Thursday it had acquired Stratature, a privately held company that specializes in so-called master data management software. Through the acquisition, Microsoft will build master data management tools into its Office System line.

headline: For One UBS Media Banker, Business Gets Personal
abstract: One UBS media banker has gotten a crash course on what it’s like being on the other side of the business. Aryeh Bourkoff, who on May 1 officially moves from the analyst side to his new position as vice chairman of technology, media and telecommunications investment banking at the bank, has scored a producer credit on a film directed by his mother that will show at the TriBeca Film Festival this week.

headline: Buyout Firms Are Said to Court Genesco
abstract: Genesco, the maker of Johnston & Murphy and Dockers brand shoes, has received several preliminary takeover offers from private-equity firms that could rival a rejected $1.2 billion hostile offer from Foot Locker, the New York Post reported Thursday citing unnamed sources.

headline: Jones Apparel in Talks to Sell Barneys to Dubai Fund, Report Says
abstract: The Jones Apparel Group is nearing a deal to sell its Barneys New York luxury department store chain to a private-equity firm owned by the Dubai government, The New York Post reported, in a deal that may worth about $950 million.

headline: Qantas Buyout Comes Down to the Wire
abstract: Macquarie Bank and its partners said shareholders owning 36 percent of Qantas Airways, Australia’s largest airline, have agreed to their A$11.1 billion ($9.1 billion) takeover offer, due to expire Friday. The buyout will fail unless the group reaches 50 percent by 7 p.m. in Sydney Friday. The bidders held about 33 percent of the airline yesterday, they said in a statement.

headline: Bank of America to Remake Its Private Bank
abstract: The Bank of America built its brand as a financial supermarket that could be all things to all people. Now, it will see if a new name can burnish its private bank’s reputation in catering to the very rich.

headline: Wall Street Rakes It In
abstract: Record profits, and payroll, on Wall Street

headline: In Battle for CBOT, Tub-Thumping Continues
abstract: IntercontinentalExchange stepped up its efforts Thursday to acquire the Chicago Board of Trade, appealing to shareholders as the vote nears on a bid from Chicago Mercantile Exchange Holdings.

headline: Onex to Unload More of Spirit in Offering
abstract: Canadian buyout firm Onex said Tuesday it plans to sell another billion-dollar share of its stake in Spirit AeroSystems Holdings. Nigel Wright, managing director of Onex, said the sale will come through a secondary offering of about 31.5 million Class A shares at $33.50 each.

headline: Hollywood Meets Hedge Funds, Courtesy of Milken
abstract: As Hollywood and hedge funds enjoy an ever closer relationship, a conference that began this week at the Beverly Hilton may help to strengthen those ties. The gathering, held by the Milken Institute, a think-tank founded by the former junk-bond king, Michael Milken, features more than 100 sessions and 300 speakers.

headline: Are Tech I.P.O.’s on the Rebound?
abstract: Seven years after the Internet bubble burst, investors say it’s time to recoup their Silicon Valley losses. Technology firms backed by venture capitalists raised $701 million in seven initial public offerings last quarter, equaling the third period of 2004 as the busiest since 2000, according to Dow Jones VentureOne, which does research on the industry.

headline: McClatchy Draws Interest From Big Hedge Fund
abstract: A couple of days after an unusual spike in shares of McClatchy prompted talk — highly speculative talk — that the newspaper chain was a takeover target, there is another intriguing, though inconclusive, development.

headline: Masters of the New Universe
abstract: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

headline: Lehman to Buy Energy Services Firm
abstract: Lehman Brothers said it would acquire Eagle Energy Partners, a Houston-based energy services company, becoming the latest investment bank to bolster its presence in the physical energy markets. “Commodities over the last several years have become a very significant asset class,” Skip McGee, Lehman’s head of global investment banking, told MarketWatch.

headline: Cerberus Said to Consider Bid for Bell Canada
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is also circling.

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Another Swing at Topps
abstract: A New York hedge fund, Crescendo Partners, on Thursday alleged that certain Topps board members have conflicts of interest that prevent the trading card and confection company from negotiating in good faith with its rival, Upper Deck, on a potential acquisition.

headline: Apollo Seeks to Sell Stake to Investors
abstract: Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black. The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said. DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.

headline: Why Should A Sale Scare Wall Street?
abstract: Why Wall Street Fears A Real Market In Mortgage Securities

headline: Are Airline Bids Like Potato Chips?
abstract: Why did W. Douglas Parker, the chief executive of US Airways, launch a hostile bid for Delta Air Lines so soon after the merger of US Airways and America West? Partly “to maximize value,” he told Fortune magazine’s Barney Gimbel as he was awaiting a decision from Delta’s creditors’ committee in January. “But it’s also kind of fun, too.”

headline: Wall St. Lobby Firm Says It Investigated Former Co-Chief
abstract: Wall Street’s largest and most important trade association acknowledged Wednesday that one of its co-chief executives resigned abruptly earlier this year after an internal investigation uncovered loose financial management by him.

headline: Big Union Takes Skeptical Look at Private Equity
abstract: In Europe, private equity firms are accustomed to feeling the heat from unions. Now, the temperature is rising in the United States as well.

headline: Are Warner and Cerberus Planning a Suprise Attack on EMI?
abstract: Is Warner Music Group teaming up with Cerberus Capital Management for an 11th-hour surprise bid for the rival music outfit EMI Group? The Sunday Telegraph reported that Warner and the private equity firm have explored a novel two-stage bid for EMI to rival the $4.7 billion recommended offer from Terra Firma, an investment vehicle controlled by the British financier Guy Hands.

headline: Asthmatx Gets $50 Million Injection
abstract: Forgoing earlier plans for an initial public offering, a medical device maker, Asthmatx, said it has taken on $50 million in new funding from a strategic investor, Olympus Medical Systems, to fund regulatory approval and commercialization of catheter-based products to treat asthma. Olympus joins previous venture investors including Polaris Venture Partners and Menlo Ventures.

headline: For Tribune Buyer, a Storm to the West
abstract: As Samuel Zell, the jeans-clad motorcycle rider, prepares to take over the conservative Tribune Company, he may have to deal with a bigger culture clash. The Los Angeles Times, the chain’s marquee California newspaper, was nothing but trouble for Tribune, and it may prove even more of a challenge for Mr. Zell.

headline: Proposal for Hedge Fund Registration Resurfaces
abstract: Hedge fund registration is back on the menu.

headline: Golden West Deal Helps Lift Wachovia Earnings
abstract: Wachovia said Monday that its first-quarter earnings rose 33 percent, helped by growth in lending income and the acquisition of Golden West Financial. The Charlotte, N.C., bank said it remained on track to meet its goals from its $24.2 billion acquisition of Golden West, which it acquired in October, though chief executive officer Ken Thompson said “it’s a trying time to be a participant in the mortgage market.”

headline: Consortium Sets New Deadline for ABN Amro Bid Decision
abstract: A consortium of banks led by the Royal Bank of Scotland has pushed back the date by which it will decide whether to bid for ABN Amro, not for any complex strategic reason, but because, as it turns out, the date it chose falls around a holiday.

headline: Citigroup’s First-Quarter Net Income Declines
abstract: Citigroup said Monday that first-quarter net income fell 11 percent, hurt by a charge related to its plans to eliminate 17,000 jobs and slash costs. But profit excluding special items topped analysts’ forecasts, helped by surging trading gains, including 20 percent revenue gains from fixed-income capital markets and 26 percent from equity markets.

headline: Cerberus Affiliates Seek to Raise $11 Billion
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management, the private equity firm that recently agreed to buy Chrysler, has created affiliates that plan to raise more than $11 billion for investments, Reuters reported, citing regulatory filings. The six affiliates have already raised about $10.5 billion, Reuters said.

headline: Collins Stewart to Buy CE Unterberg, Report Says
abstract: British broker Collins Stewart, continuing its push into the U.S. market, is buying CE Unterberg, Towbin, the privately owned New York-based investment bank, for $44 million, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Enel Pays Big for Stake in Russian Power Company
abstract: Italy’s Enel , which is poised to take over Spain’s biggest utility, will expand its presence in Russia after it beat rivals to buy a one-quarter stake in the Russian wholesale generation company OAO OGK-5 for about $1.52 billion.

headline: A Feast of Buyouts, But Can It Last?
abstract: CFO magazine begins a long article on the private equity boom with a quote from the Carlyle Group‘s co-founder, Bill Conway, that seems to sum up the extreme confidence in the industry these days. “We should have done every single deal, everywhere in the world,” Mr. Conway said during a speech in January. “Every deal worked.”

headline: L.S.E. Confirms Talks with Borsa Italiana
abstract: The London Stock Exchange may finally have found an acceptable partner: the stock market on Wednesday confirmed that it was in talks with Borsa Italiana of Milan about a possible merger. “London Stock Exchange Group PLC confirms that it is in discussions with Borsa Italiana SpA. to establish whether a merger of the two businesses can be agreed,” the exchange said.

headline: Cerberus May Put Together Bid for BCE, Report Says
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management, fresh from signing its $7.2 billion deal for Chrysler, is courting Shaw Communications and CanWest Global Communications to join a possible buying group for one of Canada’s biggest companies, BCE, according to The Globe and Mail.

headline: Private Equity Fund-Raising Up 67% in 1st Quarter
abstract: For those wondering if private equity could sustain it’s run of record fund-raising, the answer is: yes, it apparently can. Fund-raising by private equity firms in the United States rose 67 percent in the first quarter, according to Dow Jones Private Equity Analyst. Sixty-eight funds have raised $44.3 billion in the first quarter of 2007, compared with the 46 funds that raised $26.6 billion in the first quarter of last year, the newsletter said. In 2006, private equity firms raised a total $246.3 billion in 359 funds.

headline: MetroPCS Climbs 19% in First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of MetroPCS, whose all-you-can-talk business model provides low-cost cell phone service, bolted out of the gate Thursday in the first billion-dollar initial public offering of 2007.After raising $1.15 billion by selling 50 million shares for $23 each, above the expected $19 to $21 range, stock in the Dallas-based company climbed $4.35, or 19 percent, at $27.35 on the first day of trading on the public markets.

headline: Blackstone Makes Its First Management Buyout in India
abstract: The private equity firm Blackstone Group said Monday that it had agreed to buy an Indian back-office company, Intelenet Global Services, for an undisclosed sum, in its first management buyout in India.

headline: Tribune Executives Opt Out of Bonus Pool
abstract: Several top officers of Tribune have joined the chief executive, Dennis FitzSimons, in limiting or declining their slice of a “transaction bonus pool” related to the company’s $8.2 billion bid to go private.

headline: Tyco Board Approves Split
abstract: Tyco International, the industrial conglomerate, said Thursday that its board had formally approved its separation into three publicly traded companies.

headline: Banking Giants Bring the Fight to Chicago
abstract: Like deep-dish pizza, the Cubs and a mayor named Daley, LaSalle Bank has long been a Chicago institution. But until a few weeks ago, few would have called it a global banking prize. Now, LaSalle is at the center of what could be the biggest bank deal ever, as a trophy for at least two banking titans: Bank of America and the Royal Bank of Scotland.

headline: Union Wants Daimler to Keep Chrysler
abstract: The president of the United Auto Workers said Wednesday he hopes to persuade DaimlerChrysler not to sell the Chrysler Group, even as a German magazine reported that Daimler could make a decision on a buyer in the next four weeks. Ron Gettelfinger, the union head who was speaking to reporters at Chrysler’s headquarters, said the union believed that it was still an option for Daimler to keep Chrysler, which reported an operating loss of $1.5 billion last year. “There is a lot of value in keeping it there right now because of the synergy, even though you don’t hear a lot about that,” he said. “It has worked well.”

headline: Goldman Sachs’s Emergency $50 Billion Stash
abstract: The troubles at Bear Stearns have shown that even bulge-bracket investment banks can find themselves in a jam when their investments go south. But Bear is just dealing with a troubled hedge fund — what would happen in a broader market collapse, or a worldwide liquidity crisis?

headline: Flextronics to Buy Rival in $3.6 Billion Deal
abstract: Flextronics International, a company that manufactures electronics for customers such as Cisco, Dell and Eastman Kodak, said Monday it will acquire rival Solectron in a deal it valued at $3.6 billion. The combination would create company with annual revenue of more than $30 billion, Singapore-based Flextronics said in a press release.

headline: Cemex Rival Agrees to Sweetened Offer
abstract: The Mexican cement maker Cemex said that an Australian rival, Rinker, had accepted an increased takeover bid of $15.85 a share. Cemex’s initial offer on Oct. 27, 2006, was $13 a share. The $15.3 billion offer is the biggest ever by a Mexican company and one of the largest in Australian corporate history.

headline: As Murdoch Looms, a Shake-Up in Newsroom of Journal
abstract: The Wall Street Journal, already roiled by a proposed takeover by Rupert Murdoch, will announce on Wednesday a major newsroom shake-up, including the reassignment and replacement of several top editors, The New York Times reported.

headline: Chrysler Employee Group in Buyout Maneuvers
abstract: A group of Chrysler workers that has proposed an employee-led buyout of the company is apparently looking to hook up with one of the possible bidders for DaimlerChrysler‘s United States unit. The Los Angeles Times reported that billionaire Kirk Kerkorian, who has thus far been shut out by DaimlerChrysler’s board, is planning to meet with the group, which calls itself the Employee Buyout Committee.

headline: Maker of a Well-Known but Risky Drug to Sell Shares
abstract: Is a pharmaceutical company whose biggest-selling drug is considered as dangerous as heroin or LSD a good investment?

headline: Retailers Turn Up on Citi’s Buyout List
abstract: Two decades ago, a favorable environment for junk-bond financing helped fuel a wave of leveraged buyouts. Citi’s equity strategists say they are feeling a bit of a flashback these days, as yields on risky debt are relatively low, making it cheaper to borrow money to take companies private. The atmosphere “is reminiscent of the L.B.O. heyday back in the latter 1980’s,” they wrote in a report published Tuesday. Citi’s analysts compared companies’ cash flows with junk-bond yields and found that certain sectors look especially ripe for buyouts: These included the commercial services industry (which includes waste management, employment services, etc.) and retailing.

headline: Under Pressure, Biomet Agrees to Higher Takeover Bid
abstract: Biomet, the orthopedic device maker, accepted a sweetened takeover bid of $11.4 billion on Thursday from a group of private equity firms after an influential shareholder advisory firm urged the company’s shareholders to reject a previous $10.9 billion offer.

headline: Blackstone’s First-Day Poplet
abstract: After month’s of hype, hoopla and controversy, reviews of Blackstone Group‘s actual market debut appear to be a little like that Peggy Lee song, “Is That All There Is?” While the offering was clearly a success by most measures — it priced at the high end of the expected range at $31, opened 18 percent higher at $36.55 and recently traded at $35.95 — the relatively modest jump seemed to leave many observers underwhelmed. The stock closed the day at $35.06.

headline: China Says Blackstone Deal Is All About Returns
abstract: The Chinese government’s $3 billion purchase of a nonvoting stake in the Blackstone Group appears to be a move to pounce on a strategy many foreign banks have adopted in China: buy into a company just before it begins its initial public offering. That strategy has given many banks, like Bank of America and Goldman Sachs, significant initial gains, at least on paper, on their early investments, The New York Times writes.

headline: Satoil to Acquire North American Oil Sands
abstract: Statoil, Norway’s largest oil and gas company, on Friday made a $2 billion cash offer to acquire North American Oil Sands, its third significant acquisition in the Americas in less than a year.

headline: Remember Macintosh?
abstract: Apple does make computers too. And its new Leopard operating system has a nifty new backup feature it got from Sun Microsystems.

headline: Making Podcast Ads More Nimble
abstract: Conde Nast adds dynamic ad insertion to podcasts

headline: Deutsche Hires 8 Bankers for Asia Region
abstract: Deutsche Bank, Germany’s biggest, hired eight investment bankers and equity market specialists in Asia after slipping in advising on mergers in the region.

headline: America is Catching Up
abstract: Often, the best way to know what will be in the stores next year is to look at what the chip makers are doing now.

headline: In Brocade Case, Firm May Face Conflict of Interest
abstract: A judge in United States district court raised concerns Friday that the law firm Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati might have a conflict of interest in litigation over options backdating at Brocade Communications Systems. The conflict of interest, it seems, is the law firm’s own chairman, the famed Silicon Valley lawyer Lawrence W. Sonsini.

headline: Swedish Steel Maker Acquiring Canadian Supplier of Oil Pipes
abstract: In announcement that took Canada’s financial industry by surprise, Ipsco, a leading Canadian supplier of steel pipes to the oil and gas industry, agreed to be acquired by a Swedish steel maker, SSAB Svenskt Stal, for $7.7 billion in cash, the two companies said on Thursday.

headline: Deutsche Bahn Buys U.K. Railway Company
abstract: Germany’s Deutsche Bahn, the state-owned railway company, has acquired the English Welsh and Scottish Railway in a 280 million pound deal. The takeover is expected to take place later this summer subject to regulatory approval, The Guardian wrote.

headline: The End of the Bargain Era?
abstract: Economists argue over the impact of minimum-price retail agreements. We want to know: will prices still be deep discounted?

headline: Alltel’s $27.5 Billion Buyout Creates Static
abstract: Alltel‘s agreement to go private in a $27.5 billion deal — the largest leveraged buyout ever in the telecommunications industry — is not sitting well with some of the other private equity firms who lined up to bid for the wireless phone company. The deal to be acquired by a consortium including the Texas Pacific Group and a unit of Goldman Sachs effectively short-circuits the auction process, in which other groups, such as the Blackstone Group with Providence Equity Partners, and the Carlyle Group with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, had hoped to participate.

headline: Friends Again, Sort of . . .
abstract: The Boston standoff between Google and eBay appears to be over. The result of the confrontation: only minor scrapes and bruises for Google.

headline: A Ticket for Shareholders Into a Private Equity Deal
abstract: Among the details of Thursday’s $8 billion deal for Harman International Industries, one leaped out: Shareholders in Harman, which makes speakers and radios, could end up with an exceptionally large stake in the company once it goes private. Such a provision, known as stub equity, is relatively rare in dealmaking in the United States. But if buyouts keep getting bigger and public shareholders grow more resistant to approaches from private equity funds, it would not be surprising to see stub equity crop up more often.

headline: MetroPCS Raises $1.15 Billion in I.P.O.
abstract: MetroPCS Communications, a mobile-phone company that sells flat-rate calling plans in metropolitan areas, raised $1.15 billion in the biggest initial stock sale of 2007, Bloomberg News reported. The company, based in Dallas, sold 50 million shares for $23 each. The price was more than the $19 to $21 range it had predicted.

headline: Now It’s Spam on Stationery
abstract: Foiled by software that blocks advertisements in images, spammers now have found a new way to pitch their pills and penny stocks: e-mail stationary. b

headline: Top Tokyo Banker at Merill to Start His Own Investment Firm
abstract: Jesper Koll, one of the best known foreign commentators on Japan’s economy, resigned from Merrill Lynch in Tokyo to form an investment company. The move is the latest in a string of departures of investment banking executives looking to start their own firms.

headline: Spain Files Suit Against Hedge Funds’ Treaure Hunter
abstract: The Spanish government filed a lawsuit in a United States federal court on Wednesday seeking to block claims to any Spanish property recovered from shipwrecks by Odyssey Marine Exploration, whose biggest investors include several hedge funds.

headline: A (Fictional) Wall Street Predator to Make a Comeback
abstract: Greed is still good.

headline: Two New Guilty Pleas in Insider Trading Case
abstract: A former Morgan Stanley compliance lawyer and her husband pleaded guilty to insider trading in federal court Thursday, the latest pleas in a wide-ranging investigation that has touched employees at some of Wall Street’s top firms.

headline: Wharton Picks Marketing Man for Dean’s Post
abstract: The Wharton School has a new dean, and he is well-versed in the art of the pitch.

headline: Murdoch Is Taking MySpace to China — as a Start-Up
abstract: Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation is bringing MySpace.com to China, a latecomer that is betting it can overcome that handicap by competing unconventionally as a start-up.

headline: In Canada, New Concern Over Foreign Takeovers
abstract: A recent series of acquisitions or potential acquisitions of Canadian corporations has prompted a growing public debate over foreign control. On Monday, in the latest sign that the takeovers had become a growing political issue, the opposition Liberal Party said that it wanted to freeze foreign takeovers of Canadian companies for three months to allow a review of investment laws.

headline: About.com Buys ConsumerSearch.com
abstract: About.com, a Web information service owned by The New York Times Company, plans to announce Monday that it has bought ConsumerSearch.com, a Web site that compiles reviews of consumer products, for $33 million.

headline: Weekend Reading: Inside Macquarie’s Money Machine
abstract: Few companies have done more to make toll roads sexy than Macquarie Bank. Though not exactly a household name in the United States, the Australian bank has blazed a trail in infrastructure investments, wringing billions of dollars in profits from buying up bridges, airports and utilities in more than 100 countries, using a model that has inspired much bigger and better-known rivals.

headline: H.P.’s Disclosure About Resignation Fell Short, S.E.C. Says
abstract: Hewlett-Packard, the computer maker, put to rest one aspect of the spying scandal that rocked its boardroom last year as it settled an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into how it disclosed the resignation of Thomas Perkins, a prominent venture capitalist, from its board. Though the settlement came with no financial or other penalty, the S.E.C. said it found that Hewlett-Packard “failed to disclose the reasons for his resignation as required by federal securities laws” after Mr. Perkins left the board in May 2006 because of his objection to an internal investigation into leaks to the press. Hewlett consented to an order that it stop violations of disclosure provisions, but did not admit or deny the commission’s findings.

headline: UBS Hires Financial Institutions Banker
abstract: William A. Houlihan, who most recently was chief financial officer of Sedgwick Claims Management Services, has joined UBS as a managing director in its financial institutions group. He will report to Oliver Sarkozy, joint global head of investment banking. Earlier this year, two bankers from the same UBS group, Joe Jiampietro and Eric Warmstein, left for J.P. Morgan Chase.

headline: SAP Buys OutlookSoft to Advance in Battle Against Oracle
abstract: The German software maker SAP said Tuesday that it had agreed to buy OutlookSoft, a planning, budgeting, forecasting, and consolidation software maker that competes with Oracle.

headline: Farallon to Buy Affordable Residential Unit
abstract: A hedge fund manager Farallon Capital Management said Tuesday that it had agreed to buy the manufactured-home unit of Affordable Residential Communities for $1.8 billion. Farallon already owns 10 pecent of Affordable Residential, which owns and operates about 57,264 home sites in 275 communities in 23 states. Analysts said the deal could help Farallon benefit from the downturn in the subprime lending market.

headline: Warner’s Loss Widens Amid Fading Deal Hopes
abstract: The Warner Music Group posted a wider quarterly loss Tuesday and said it would cut about 400 jobs as it shifts resources to increase digital distribution of music and video.
