The announcement comes as Warner’s hopes for a deal with its British rival, the EMI Group, are fading in the face of private equity bids for EMI.

headline: So What’s a Little Line Rage Between iPhone Maniacs?
abstract: By noon today outside the Apple Store at a pleasant outdoor mall in Corte Madera, 20 minutes north of San Francisco, a touch of line rage had already set in. When five big young guys sauntered up to the line where 90 of us had already been standing — some since 6 a.m. yesterday morning — they settled down into camping chairs directly in front of me that had been set up for them earlier by a friend who happened to be an Apple employee.

headline: New York Fed Warns On Hedge Funds
abstract: In what Reuters describes as its “sternest warning to date” on the state of the hedge-fund business, the New York Federal Reserve said Wednesday that the funds could represent the biggest risk for a financial crisis since 1998, when the implosion of Long-Term Capital Management threatened global markets.

headline: McClatchy Draws Interest From Big Hedge Fund
abstract: A couple of days after an unusual spike in shares of McClatchy prompted talk — highly speculative talk — that the newspaper chain was a takeover target, there is another intriguing, though inconclusive, development.

headline: Masters of the New Universe
abstract: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

headline: Lehman to Buy Energy Services Firm
abstract: Lehman Brothers said it would acquire Eagle Energy Partners, a Houston-based energy services company, becoming the latest investment bank to bolster its presence in the physical energy markets. “Commodities over the last several years have become a very significant asset class,” Skip McGee, Lehman’s head of global investment banking, told MarketWatch.

headline: Cerberus Said to Consider Bid for Bell Canada
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is also circling.

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Another Swing at Topps
abstract: A New York hedge fund, Crescendo Partners, on Thursday alleged that certain Topps board members have conflicts of interest that prevent the trading card and confection company from negotiating in good faith with its rival, Upper Deck, on a potential acquisition.

headline: Apollo Seeks to Sell Stake to Investors
abstract: Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black. The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said. DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.

headline: Why Should A Sale Scare Wall Street?
abstract: Why Wall Street Fears A Real Market In Mortgage Securities

headline: Are Airline Bids Like Potato Chips?
abstract: Why did W. Douglas Parker, the chief executive of US Airways, launch a hostile bid for Delta Air Lines so soon after the merger of US Airways and America West? Partly “to maximize value,” he told Fortune magazine’s Barney Gimbel as he was awaiting a decision from Delta’s creditors’ committee in January. “But it’s also kind of fun, too.”

headline: Wall St. Lobby Firm Says It Investigated Former Co-Chief
abstract: Wall Street’s largest and most important trade association acknowledged Wednesday that one of its co-chief executives resigned abruptly earlier this year after an internal investigation uncovered loose financial management by him.

headline: Big Union Takes Skeptical Look at Private Equity
abstract: In Europe, private equity firms are accustomed to feeling the heat from unions. Now, the temperature is rising in the United States as well.

headline: Bad Hair Days Lead to Venture Capital Funding
abstract: For many entrepreneurs in the first dot-com boom, the name of the game was “portal-matic.” Spin a wheel, pick a niche interest group, build a comprehensive Web portal aimed at that group’s needs and cash a venture capitalist’s check.

headline: Cadence Said to Be in Buyout Talks
abstract: Cadence Design Systems, one of the largest makers of the software used to design computer chips, is in talks with at least two buyout firms about a possible sale of the company, The New York Times reported.

headline: Taking a Peek Through the Hedges
abstract: Not so long ago, the talk about hedge funds was about their money — the art their managers bought or the salaries they paid themselves. But now as the discussion has moved to whether hedge funds bid up the price of oil, or even if they are the virus that could kill the market, New York Magazine has devoted its latest issue to those lightly regulated investment pools.

headline: Active Hedge Funds Create New Wealth for Law Firms
abstract: For corporate lawyers of a certain age, it seems like the 1980s all over again. Proxy fights, once the exclusive domain of investors like Carl C. Icahn, are on the rise. The primary cause, says The New York Times, is easy to spot: “The resurgence of shareholder activism is a direct result of the growth of hedge funds,” Marc Weingarten, a partner at law firm Schulte Roth & Zabel, told The Times.

headline: Icahn Firm’s C.F.O. to Leave
abstract: The chief financial officer of an investment vehicle for Carl C. Icahn is leaving to take another job, the firm said in a regulatory filing Tuesday. The executive, Hillel Moerman, gave notice of his resignation to the Icahn company, American Real Estate Partners, last week, and the company said it did not make a counteroffer.

headline: Home Depot Unit to Get Bids from 2 Buyout Groups, Report Says
abstract: The auction for Home Depot‘s supply unit may finally be heating up. Two private equity consortiums are planning to table offers of about $10 billion each for the contractor-supplies unit of the world’s largest home-improvement retailer, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: Ex-Westar Executives to Face a Third Trial
abstract: Two former executives at Westar Energy, David C. Wittig and Douglas T. Lake, will face trial for a third time on criminal charges that accuse them of trying to loot the utility, a federal prosecutor said Monday.

headline: Home Depot May Change Its Mind on Unit Sale
abstract: Several large private equity firms submitted first-round bids for Home Depot‘s HD Supply unit, but Home Depot may not be all that interested in selling the unit, according to The Deal.com. When the company said in February that it was considering strategic alternatives, HD Supply was seen as a distraction to Home Depot’s core business. But with the housing market slowing dramatically in recent months, analysts now say the unit, which is less reliant on the residential housing market, could help the retailer weather the housing storm.

headline: Chinese Bookstore Chain Prices I.P.O. Amid Strong Demand
abstract: Sichuan Xinhua Winshare Chainstore, which will be the first bookstore operator to list in Hong Kong, has priced its initial public offering at the top of the range for a total deal size of 2.2 billion Hong Kong dollars ($274 million).

headline: Terra Firma Gives Up in Alliance Boots Fight
abstract: Rival suitors for Alliance Boots have thrown up their hands and ceded Britain’s largest drugstore chain to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Stefano Pessina, the company’s deputy chairman. Still, Terra Firma Capital Partners, a private equity firm led by Guy Hands, Wellcome Trust and HBOS managed to force the winners into raising their bid to 11.1 billion pounds ($22.2 billion).

headline: British Lobbying Group Defends Private Equity
abstract: Despite recent slamming by public shareholders, labor unions and lawmakers, it seems that private equity still has one ally.

headline: Chase Says It Will Move if New York Balks on Subsidies
abstract: JPMorgan Chase is threatening to move thousands of employees from Midtown to Stamford, Conn., if New York officials do not give it a larger subsidy package to build a 50-story skyscraper near ground zero, The New York Times reported.

headline: Another Carlyle Founder Chats Up an I.P.O.
abstract: Adding more fuel to the fire of speculation that the Carlyle Group may take itself public in the near future, the private equity firm’s co-founder, Daniel D’Aniello, said Tuesday that the buyout shop has been considering an initial public offering for some time.

headline: Apple’s Ex-C.F.O. Reaches for Settlement with S.E.C.
abstract: Apple‘s former chief financial officer, Fred D. Anderson, is preparing to settle with the Securities and Exchange Commission over the dating of an option grant to senior officials in January 2001, The New York Times reported Tuesday.

headline: Putting a Price Tag on Facebook: Round 2
abstract: Much ink has been spilled on the question of whether social networking site Facebook will sell out and, if so, for how much. Following Google‘s $1.65 billion acquisition of YouTube last year, rumors percolated that Yahoo and Viacom were interested, and that Facebook’s founder and chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, was holding out for a $2 billion offer.

headline: In Texas, Hedge Funds Win a Round for Secrecy
abstract: Hedge funds that dabble in distressed assets are celebrating a decision in an obscure Texas bankruptcy case.

headline: Vision Raises $55 Million for Hedge-Fund Incubator
abstract: Vision Investment Management, a manager of an Aisan fund that invests in various hedge funds, has raised about $55 million for a new vehicle that will seed and incubate hedge fund start-ups, Reuters reported. The firm’s Vision Angel Fund is likely to invest with its first two managers within 30 to 45 days, Julius Wang, a managing director with the Hong Kong-based firm, told the wire service. He said that the investment target size will be between $100 million to $150 million.

headline: UBS to Close Hedge Fund After Disappointing Returns
abstract: In a shocking move, UBS said it would scrap its hedge fund, Dillon Read Capital Management, after losses at the unit contributed to a third straight decline in quarterly profit. “We concluded that the DRCM initiative did not meet our expectations,” UBS’s chief executive, Peter Wuffli, said in a statement.

headline: Who Needs I.P.O.’s Anyway?
abstract: So much for peer pressure.

headline: Pershing Square Battles With Ceridian Over Fired Executive
abstract: A battle for control of Ceridian is heating up between the company’s management and Pershing Square Capital, an activist hedge fund that owns 14.2 percent of the provider of payroll and human resources services.

headline: Spitzer Said to Form Panel on Wall St. Rules
abstract: New York Governor Eliot Spitzer, who, when he was attorney general, aggressively policed the financial services industry, is forming a committee of Wall Street chief executives, lawyers, consumer groups and regulators to modernize financial-services regulation in New York State, The Financial Times reported.

headline: Indian Metals Producer Raises $1.75 Billion in U.S. Share Sale
abstract: Sterlite Industries, the copper and zinc producer controlled by the billionaire Anil Agarwal, sold $1.75 billion of stock in the United States. Sterlite, based in Mumbai, sold 130.44 million American depositary receipts at $13.44 apiece, the unit of Vedanta Resources said in a statement to the Bombay Stock Exchange on Tuesday.

headline: Upper Deck’s Topps Bid: Sneaky or Sincere?
abstract: Is Upper Deck‘s bid for venerable bubble gum and card maker Topps really a back-door move to spy on its rival?

headline: Is Dow Jones’s Union Pursuing an ESOP?
abstract: Even as the Bancroft family finally sat down with Rupert Murdoch on Monday, it appeared other players in the Dow Jones saga were trying to take matters into their own hands — possibly literally.

headline: Citi Raises $2.2 Billion in Landmark Japanese Bond Sale
abstract: Citigroup raised 270 billion yen ($2.2 billion) in Japan’s biggest bond sale by a foreign firm, tapping demand for higher returns than investors can receive from the nation’s companies.

headline: Lone Star Confirms Asset Sale
abstract: The investment fund Lone Star confirmed widespread rumors on Wednesday that it would sell two of its South Korean holdings. Following a legal battle that forced it to abort a planned $7.3 billion sale of the Korea Exchange Bank last November, the fund is selling Kukdong Engineering and Construction and STARLease. ABN Amro is serving as Lone Star’s adviser.

headline: Google Forges Deal for PeakStream
abstract: Google said it has purchased closely held PeakStream, a start-up that sells tools for programming chips with multiple processing units.

headline: Qiagen to Buy Digene, Maker of H.P.V. Diagnostic Tests
abstract: Qiagen, a Dutch maker of tools for gene research, has agreed to buy Digene for $1.6 billion in shares and cash to gain tests for a virus that causes cervical cancer and sexually transmitted diseases.

headline: May Is Banner Month for Venture-Backed I.P.O.’s
abstract: Venture-backed initial public offerings had their best month in years last month as 11 companies raised $1.6 billion from I.P.O.s on American exchanges. That figure represents the most money raised since August 2004 when the debut of Google raised that figure to nearly $1.9 billion, according to statistics released Tuesday by Thomson Financial and the National Venture Capital Association.

headline: Debitel Dials Up Deal for Talkline
abstract: Debitel, the largest German reseller of mobile phone services, agreed on Tuesday to buy Talkline from TDC of Denmark for 560 million euros ($756 million), adding 3.8 million customers to its rolls.

headline: Malaysian Mogul in Mobile-Phone Deal
abstract: T. Ananda Krishnan, the second-richest person in Malaysia, plans to buy full control of Maxis Communications, Malaysia’s No. 1 mobile-phone operator, which is valued at $9.6 billion.

headline: Yahoo Hires Thomas Weisel Co-founder as Finance Chief
abstract: Even as rumors swirl that Yahoo might be heading for some kind of deal with Microsoft, the Internet giant has picked a technology deal maker as its next chief financial officer. Yahoo announced Tuesday that it had hired Blake J. Jorgensen, a co-founder of the technology-focused investment bank Thomas Weisel Partners, as its finance chief. He will succeed Susan L. Decker, who took control of the company’s advertising operations in December amid mounting competition from its archrival Google.

headline: S.E.C. to Face Questions in House Committee
abstract: All five members of the Securities and Exchange Commission will appear before the House Financial Services Committee on Tuesday, where they are expected to be asked to defend their agency against accusations that it might favor business interests at the expense of protecting investors. The hearing will mark the first time in more than a decade that all S.E.C. commissioners have been called to testify together, the Associated Press reported.

headline: Steel Company Ipsco in Sale Talks
abstract: The Russians may be planning another multibillion-dollar deal in North America. Ipsco, a Canadian steelmaker with executive offices in the United States, said Thursday that it is in discussions that could lead to a sale of the company. Ipsco did not identify the potential buyer, but the statement followed a report in a Russian newspaper that Russian steel company Evraz Group was in takeover talks with Ipsco. Ipsco’s shares jumped nearly 7 percent on Thursday, giving it a market capitalization of about $6.6 billion.

headline: Carlyle Takes 49 Percent of Chinese Steel Company
abstract: The Carlyle Group announced on Friday that it would invest $80 million for a 49 percent stake in China’s Yangzhou Chengde Steel Tube Company. Yangzhou Chengde makes large-diameter seamless steel pipes and Carlyle’s investment will help the company to expand its business both domestically and abroad. The investment comes from Carlyle Asia Partners II, a $1.8 billion fund that makes control and strategic minority investments in Asia outside Japan.

headline: Highland Makes Fresh Overture to Delphi, Report Says
abstract: A hedge fund, Highland Capital Management, is interested in making another run at the auto parts maker Delphi, the Wall Street Journal reported. In January Delphi signed a $3.4 billion deal with a group of private equity investors, despite a $4.7 billion rival bid from Highland.

headline: Another Couple, Another Pair of Insider Trading Arrests
abstract: We’ve begin to think they might want to add a few words to the traditional wedding vow: ” ‘Til death — or insider trading charges — do us part.”

headline: Is Private Equity Riding a Debt Bubble?
abstract: The chief executive of the private equity firm TA Associates, Kevin Landry, offers a new take on talk of a private-equity bubble. Speaking to The Boston Globe’s Steven Syre about all the private equity cash sloshing around and the unprecedented scale of leveraged buyouts, Mr. Landry said:

headline: Q & A: A Trail of Poisoned Medicine
abstract: A poisonous solvent sold by counterfeiters and mixed into drugs has figured in mass poisonings around the world that killed thousands. In many cases, the precise origin of the poison has never been determined. But records and interviews show that in three of the last four cases it was made in China, a major source of counterfeit drugs.

abstract: James R. Crane raised his buyout offer for the company to $46.25 a share, competing with a $46-a-share offer from the Ceva Group.

headline: Britain: Tool Rental Company Buys a Rival
abstract: Speedy Hire, a British tool-rental company, agreed to buy Finning International’s Hewden Tools business for £115 million ($227 million) to add branches and expand its range of drills, scaffolding and generators. Speedy, based in Newton-le-Willows, northwest England, will pay cash for the operation, part of the Hewden Stuart subsidiary of Finning, which is based in Vancouver, British Columbia. The purchase will increase Speedy Hire’s annual revenue by at least 20 percent, to more than £400 million, the chief executive, Steve J. Corcoran, said on a conference call.

abstract: Drug and medical-device sales representatives hash out their lives and work in tens of thousands of discussion threads at cafepharma.com

abstract: Pressure is building on Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to move forward on legislation to help salvage a rift in the Iraqi government.

headline: Lehman to Buy Energy Services Firm
abstract: Lehman Brothers said it would acquire Eagle Energy Partners, a Houston-based energy services company, becoming the latest investment bank to bolster its presence in the physical energy markets. “Commodities over the last several years have become a very significant asset class,” Skip McGee, Lehman’s head of global investment banking, told MarketWatch.

headline: Cerberus Said to Consider Bid for Bell Canada
abstract: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is also circling.

headline: Hedge Fund Takes Another Swing at Topps
abstract: A New York hedge fund, Crescendo Partners, on Thursday alleged that certain Topps board members have conflicts of interest that prevent the trading card and confection company from negotiating in good faith with its rival, Upper Deck, on a potential acquisition.

headline: Apollo Seeks to Sell Stake to Investors
abstract: Recent reports to the contrary, a Blackstone-style initial public offering is not at the top of the agenda for Apollo Management, the private equity firm founded by Leon D. Black. The firm is actually seeking to sell a minority stake in the business to private investors, people close to the firm said. DealBook first mentioned the possibility of a stake sale in this early Wednesday post, not long after reports surfaced that Apollo was working with investment bankers on a possible I.P.O.

Partly “to maximize value,” he told Fortune magazine’s Barney Gimbel as he was awaiting a decision from Delta’s creditors’ committee in January. “But it’s also kind of fun, too.”

abstract: Nicolas Sarkozy earned a decisive victory on Sunday over Ségolène Royal, keeping the right in power for another five years. Turnout was 84 percent of France’s registered voters.

headline: Gaza: One Dead in Factional Firefight
abstract: A Palestinian man was killed and at least nine other people were wounded in factional fighting in the southern Gaza Strip town of Rafah. Each of the rival factions, Hamas and Fatah, blamed the other for starting the shooting. The dead man belonged to Fatah. A report this week by the Palestinian Independent Commission for Citizens’ Rights said 616 Palestinians had been killed in internal fighting since the beginning of 2006. In the first half of May, fierce factional clashes left about 50 dead in Gaza. The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas of Fatah, warned this week that the Palestinians were “on the verge of civil war.”.

abstract: The two candidates attacked each other today over policies that are expected to be the focus of a crucial, nationally televised debate on Wednesday.

abstract: The stock market tumbled for a second day over fears that inflation is not settling down enough to satisfy the Federal Reserve.

abstract: Home-delivery rates will increase 3 percent to 4 percent and the newsstand cover price will increase to $1.25, from $1.

headline: Penalties for Product Piracy Advance
abstract: Endorsing a set of common criminal penalties across the European Union for the first time, the European Parliament approved legislation that would impose jail sentences and fines on counterfeiters of drugs, toys and other goods in the 27-country bloc. The legislation, which still must be approved by national governments, aims to protect consumers from unsafe products like fake Viagra pills or imitation condoms, while preventing the infringement of intellectual property in the music and film industry. .

headline: Bomber Kills at Least 12 Iraqi Soldiers
abstract: A suicide bomber killed at least a dozen Iraqi soldiers and wounded 30 more in Iskandariya, an insurgent stronghold south of Baghdad.

abstract: A filing that would have allowed Bear Stearns to reduce its exposure to high-risk mortgages has been withdrawn.

headline: France: Alstom Buys a Wind Energy Company
abstract: Alstom, a maker of coal-fired power stations, agreed to buy Ecotècnia of Spain to enter the wind energy market. Alstom will pay 350 million euros ($471 million) for Ecotècnia, which also makes solar panels, it said. The purchase will help Alstom, which is based in Paris, expand in the United States and Asia, it said. Buying Ecotècnia strengthens Alstom’s presence in renewable energy as governments seek alternatives to coal, gas and oil. Alstom also sells hydroelectric equipment and worked with Russia’s state nuclear agency in April to develop atomic plants.

abstract: By next year, more than half the world’s population, 3.3 billion people, will for the first time live in towns and cities, a report said.

abstract: A Manhattan jewelry dealer who directed his employees to inflate the price of goods his company auctioned will settle a civil fraud complaint.

abstract: The practice of collecting blood samples from Amazon Indians has aroused widespread suspicions in Brazil.

headline: France: Profit Up 25% at BNP Paribas
abstract: BNP Paribas, the French bank, reported a 25 percent increase in first-quarter profit on higher corporate and investment bank earnings and gains from asset sales. Income climbed to 2.51 billion euros ($3.4 billion), from 2.01 billion euros a year earlier, BNP Paribas said. Revenue rose 21 percent, to 8.21 billion euros. Profit beat the 2.06 billion euros expected by analysts. BNP Paribas’s stock rose 3.65 euros, to 91.15 euros. Pretax profit at the corporate and investment bank rose 12 percent. Earnings at the French branch network declined 2.2 percent, while pretax profit at BancWest, a unit based in Hawaii, slipped 20 percent. Excluding Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, earnings at BNP Paribas’s international retail bank decreased 5.3 percent.

abstract: Talk radio remains insidiously untamed, full of coarse, explicit banter, despite Don Imus’s firing.

headline: Protests Rage Against Musharraf; Aides Criticize Justice He Ousted
abstract: The political crisis over the suspension of Chief Justice Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry in March has shown no sign of abating.

headline: April Factory Orders and Capital Goods Send Mixed Signals
abstract: Orders placed with American factories rose less than forecast in April, while gains in capital-goods spending might presage stronger business investment.
